sentence: Let H be an almost 5-Ore graph and let w be a special vertex of H. A frame of H with special vertex w is a graph J isomorphic to K_4 such that V(J)=w∪ N_H(w) and H can be obtained from J by Ore-composition with 5-Ore graphs whose replaced edges are in E(J). We call the vertices of J the corners of the frame and the graphs used for the Ore-composition the bars .

sentence:
The maximum independent cover number of a graph G, denoted mic(G), is the maximum of ∑_v∈ Id(v) over all
independent sets I of G.

sentence:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional pure simplicial complex. We recall that the facet graph of  (see White <cit.>), denoted by G(Δ), is defined as follow:


  - The set of vertices is V(G(Δ))= (Δ),

  - The set of egdes is 
    E(G(Δ))={{F,G}: F,G∈ (Δ)  and  |F∩ G|=d-1}.
  



Notice that a pure simplicial complex  is strongly connected if and only if G() is connected.


We say that  Δ is  a Cohen-Macaulay complex without cycles in codimension 1 if Δ is Cohen-Macaulay and G(Δ) is a tree.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Cohen-Macaulay complex without cycles in codimension 1

sentence:
Let G be a tree. For any vertex v  of G, we consider the directed graph (G,v) as follow:


  - The set of vertices is V((G,v))=V(G).

  - The pair (u_2,u_1)∈ E((G,v)) iff there is a path v,u_k,…,u_2,u_1 in G.  We will call it  a directed edge  of (G,v).

sentence: A vector α_i=(α_i(j): v_i ∉ F_j) is called G^i(Δ)-satisfying if α_i(h)≥α_i(k) for all directed edges (F_h,F_k) of (G^i(Δ),V_i). Moreover, α=(α_i(j)) is called Δ-satisfying if α_i is G^i(Δ)-satisfying for all i=1,…,n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a strongly connected quasi-tree with the leaf order F_1,…,F_m. We define a relation tree of Δ , denoted by T(Δ), in the following way:

  
  * The vertices of T(Δ) are the facets of Δ.
  
  * The edges are obtained recursively as follows: 
 
  
  - Take the leaf F_m of Δ and choose a branch G of F_m. 
  
  - Set {F_m,G} to be an edge of T(Δ). 
  
  - Remove F_m from Δ and proceed with the remaining complex as before to determine the other edges of T(Δ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Δ be a strongly connected quasi-tree and α=(α_i(j)) for i=1,…,n and j such that v_i∉ F_j. The collection α is called Δ-satisfying if there exists a relation tree T(Δ) such that if the directed edge (F_h,F_k)∈ E((T^i(Δ),V_i)) then α_i(h)≥α_i(k).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p be a prime, let 𝔽_p be the finite field with p elements, let G be a connected graph with at least 3 vertices, and let [Ψ_G]_p be the number of 𝔽_p-rational points in the affine variety {Ψ_G=0}⊆𝔽_p^|E(G)|.  Then the c_2-invariant of G at p is
  
    c_2^(p)(G) = [Ψ_G]_p/p^2 p.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
* Call a bipartition of the edges of any graph (for our purposes either R, S or T) such that one part gives a spanning tree and the other part gives a spanning 2-forest a valid edge partition.
  
  * Suppose we have a valid edge partition.  This gives a bipartition of all of the vertices of the graph according to which tree of the 2-forest they are in.  Call a cycle C compatible with the edge partition if all vertices of C are in the same part of the vertex partition and exactly one edge of C is in the part of the edge partition corresponding to the spanning tree.

sentence:
Let G be a graph. A partition π={V_1,V_2,…,V_ℓ'} of V(G) is an (ℓ,d)-partition
if ℓ'≤ℓ and for each pair of not necessarily distinct integers i,j ∈{1,2,…,ℓ'} either
Δ(V_i, V_j) ≤ d or Δ(V_i, V_j) ≤ d.
We call the sets V_i bags .
A graph G is an (ℓ, d)-graph if it admits an (ℓ,d)-partition.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
A strong (ℓ,d)-partition is an (ℓ,d)-partition each bag of which contains at least 5 × 2^ℓ d vertices;
a strong (ℓ,d)-graph is a graph which admits a strong (ℓ,d)-partition.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a strong (ℓ,d)-graph G, its sparsification is
ϕ(G)=ϕ(G, π) for any strong (ℓ,d)-partition π of G.

sentence:
Let _d() be the family of independent sets of  of size d,
     and order it as follows. For I,I' ∈_d(), let 
     I ≥ I' if for each a ∈ I there is an aa'-path in 
      with a' ∈ I'.

sentence:
A tree decomposition of a graph G is a pair (T, {A_x⊆ V(G) : x ∈ V(T)}) such that:


  * T is a tree.

  * {A_x⊆ V(G) : x ∈ V(T)} is a collection of sets of vertices of G, each called a bag , indexed by the nodes of T.

  * For all v ∈ V(G), the nodes of T indexing the bags containing v induce a non-empty (connected) subtree of T.

  * For all vw ∈ E(G), there exists a bag of T containing both v and w.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A line-bramble ℬ of G is a collection of connected subgraphs of G satisfying the following properties:


  * For all X ∈ℬ, |V(X)| ≥ 2.

  * For all X,Y ∈ℬ, V(X) ∩ V(Y) ≠∅.

Define a hitting set for a line-bramble ℬ to be a set of edges H ⊆ E(G) that intersects each X ∈ℬ. Then define the order of ℬ to be the size of the minimum hitting set H of ℬ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a vertex v ∈ V(G), the canonical line-bramble for v of G is the set of connected subgraphs X of G such that either |V(X)| > |V(G)|/2, or |V(X)| = |V(G)|/2 and X contains v. Note that if |V(G)| is odd, then no elements of the second type occur.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let X^*_i := X_i∩ (V(Q_1) ∪ V(Q_2)), and say X^*_i is even or odd depending on the parity of its order.

sentence:
Let H be an ℓ-uniform hypergraph of order
  N with average degree d.  Let τ > 0.  Given v ∈ V(H) and
  2 ≤ j ≤ℓ, let
  
    d^(j)(v) = max{ d(σ)   :   v ∈σ⊂ V(H),
        |σ|=j }.

  If d > 0, define δ_j by the equation
  
    δ_j τ^j-1 N d = ∑_v d^(j)(v).

  The codegree function δ(H,τ) is then defined by
  
    δ(H,τ) = 2^ℓ2-1∑_j=2^ℓ
        2^-j-12δ_j.

  If d=0, define δ(H,τ) = 0.

sentence:
A tournament H is said to be a tournament forest if it is possible to partition its vertex set into
two transitive sets[Note that this means that if H is a tournament forest, then χ(H) ≤ 2.] L,R so that if we define an undirected bipartite graph U on the vertex sets L and R by connecting ℓ∈ L to r ∈ R if and only if H has an edge pointing from
r to ℓ, then U is a forest.

sentence: A family of tournaments Q_H is H-useful if every prime tournament which is H-free belongs to Q_H.

sentence:
A word w' is a subword of a word w∈Σ^* iff there exist x_1,x_2,…, x_n, y_0, y_1, …,y_n∈Σ^*, some of them possibly empty, such that

    w'=x_1x_2… x_n  and  w=y_0x_1y_1… y_n-1x_ny_n.

sentence:
Suppose Σ={a_1<a_2< …<a_s} is an ordered alphabet. The Parikh matrix mapping , denoted Ψ_Σ, is the monoid morphism

    Ψ_ΣΣ^*→ℳ_s+1

defined as follows:

if Ψ_Σ(a_q)=(m_i,j)_1≤ i,j≤ s+1, then m_i,i=1 for each 1≤ i≤ s+1, m_q,q+1=1 and all other entries of the matrix Ψ_Σ(a_q) are zero. 
Matrices of the form  Ψ_Σ(w) for w∈Σ^* are called Parikh matrices .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Suppose Σ={a_1<a_2< …<a_s}  is an ordered alphabet.


  * Two words w,w'∈Σ^* are M-equivalent , denoted w≡_M w', iff Ψ_Σ(w)=Ψ_Σ(w').

  * A word w∈Σ^* is M-unambiguous iff no distinct word is M-equivalent to w. Otherwise, w is said to be M-ambiguous .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Suppose  Σ is an ordered alphabet and w,w'∈Σ^*. 
We say that w and w' are 1-equivalent , denoted w≡_1 w', iff w' can be obtained from w by finitely many applications of Rule E1. 
We say that w and w' are elementarily matrix equivalent ( ME-equivalent ), denoted w≡_ME w', iff w' can be obtained from w by finitely many applications of Rule E1 and Rule E2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose Σ is an alphabet.
Two words w, w'∈Σ^* are strongly M-equivalent , denoted w s≡_M w', iff w and w' are M-equivalent  with respect to any ordered alphabet with underlying alphabet Σ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose  Σ is an alphabet and w,w'∈Σ^*. 
We say that w and w' are strongly elementarily matrix equivalent ( MSE-equivalent ), denoted w≡_MSE w', iff w' results from w by finitely many applications of Rule SE.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose Σ is an  alphabet.
Two words w, w'∈Σ^* are weakly M-related , denoted w ∽_M w',   iff w and w' are M-equivalent  with respect to some ordered alphabet with underlying alphabet Σ.

A line L of ^2 is a special secant line of Γ 
if L passes through two distinct points of .

A  non-singular conic Q on ^2 is said to be totally tangent to Γ
if Q intersects Γ at six distinct  points with intersection multiplicity 2.

sentence:
A (rational) polyhedron P is the intersection of finitely many (rational) halfspaces. If it is bounded, then it is called a polytope . If all the halfspaces are linear, then P is a cone.

The dimension of P is the dimension of the smallest affine subspace (P) containing P.

An affine monoid is a finitely generated submonoid of ^d for some d.

sentence:
A quantum k-deck is a collection of quantum marginals, 
     termed (quantum) cards, of size k each. The marginals are unlabeled and thus not associated to any specific subsystems.
     A deck is called complete if it contains nk cards
     and legitimate if it originates from a joint state.

 Given a quantum state , its corresponding k-deck is given 
 by the collection of all its marginals of size k,
 
    _ = {_̊A  |   |A| = k , A ⊆{1… n}} .

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Given a simple graph G = (V,E) having n vertices, its corresponding graph state |G⟩ is defined as
  the common (+1)-eigenstate of the n commuting operators {g_i},
    
    g_i = X_i ⊗_j ∈ N(i) Z_j  .

  Thus g_i |G⟩ = |G⟩ for all g_i. The set {g_i} is called the generator of the graph state.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Let w_1 and w_2 be two walks on a digraph . If the couple (w_1,w_2) is not nestable, we define the nesting product w_1 w_2 = 0, where 0 is the zero walk. Otherwise, let w_1 and w_2 have vertex sequences w_1 = α_1 α_2 ⋯α_m+1 and w_2 = β_1 β_2 ⋯β_nβ_1, and let k be the index of the final appearance of β_1 in w_1. Then we define the nesting product to be

    w_1  w_2 = α_1α_2⋯α_k-1β_1β_2⋯β_nβ_1
    α_k+1⋯α_m+1.

     The walk w_1 w_2 has length m + n and is said to consist of w_2 nested into w_1 (off vertex β_1). The vertex sequence of w_1  w_2 is formed by replacing the final appearance of β_1 in w_1 by the entire vertex sequence of w_2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A generalised tree  consists of a root node T plus a (possibly empty) ordered sequence of hedges, where a hedge is an ordered sequence of generalised trees:

    = [T.root, [ H_1, H_2, …, H_n ] ], 
    _i     = [T_i,1,T_i,2,…, T_i,k_i].

     Here n ≥ 0 is the number of hedges proceeding from T, and k_i ≥ 0 is the number of generalised trees in the hedge _i. Adopting standard terminology, we say that each of the nodes _i,1,…,_i,k_i is a child node of T, and has T as a parent. A node that has no children is a leaf node. Given a node n, nodes in the same hedge as n are said to be siblings (specifically, right or left siblings, according to their position in the hedge relative to n).


     Every node in  has a depth and a height: the depth of a node n is equal to the length of a path from n to T, and the height of n is the length of the longest downward path from n to a leaf node. The height of the entire tree  is defined to be the height of T.root.

     A subtree of  consists of a node n and all its descendants (i.e. all children, grandchildren, etc.) in . We denote the subtree rooted at node n by t(n): thus t() =, while for n≠, t(n) is a proper subtree of .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a digraph , a syntax tree over  is a generalised tree  together with a collection of elements of W_, one associated with each node in . We denote the walk associated with node n by n.contents, and define the contents of  (as distinct from the contents of its root node) to be


    T.contents = T.root.contentsH_n.contents⋯H_2.contentsH_1.contents,

where the contents of a hedge are given by

    H_i.contents = T_i,1.contentsT_i,2.contents⋯T_i,k_i.contents.


     The syntax tree  is valid for a walk w if and only if it satisfies the following conditions:


  (i) T.contents = w,
       
  (ii) h(H_i.contents) ≠ h(H_j.contents) for i ≠ j. In other words, no two hedges contain closed walks off the same vertex.

     The purpose of the second condition is to disallow syntax trees where several closed walks off the same vertex are placed in different hedges, rather than into different generalised trees within the same hedge.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let = [k_0,k_1,…,k_D-1,0] be a dressing signature, and ' = [k_1,…,k_D-1,0] be the dressing signature obtained by deleting the first element of . Then a cycle c is said to be -structured if and only if the base cycle of c has length less than or equal to k_0, and all child cycles c_i,j (if any exist) are '-structured. We denote the set of all -structured cycles off a given vertex α on a digraph  by C_;α^, and the set of all -structured cycles on  by C_^ = ∪_α C_;α^.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a digraph and w be a walk on . Then, for a given dressing signature , w is said to be -irreducible if and only if [w] = w. We denote the set of all -irreducible walks on  by I^_, and the set of all -irreducible walks from α to ω on  by I^_;αω. That is,

    I^_ = {w : w ∈ W_ and [w] = w },

with an analogous expression for I^_;αω.

sentence:

    W_;αω  /  = {[w]_ : w ∈ W_;αω}

sentence:
Given a walk w with associated equivalence class [w]_, we define its canonical representative w^⋆_ to be the shortest element of [w]_:

    w^⋆_ = _u ∈ [w]_  (u).

sentence:
Let  be a canonical syntax tree, and = [k_0,…,k_D-1,0] a dressing signature of depth D. Then the local depth of a node n of  with respect to , denoted (n), is an integer between 0 and D inclusive, defined as follows. The root node  and all its immediate children have a local depth of 0, while every other node n has a local depth given by

    (n) =
    (p)  + 1   [c]
                  if (p.contents) ≤ k_(p) and
    
                  t(n_j).contents is [k_(p)+1,…,0]-structured for 1 ≤ j ≤ i-1,
    
    0    otherwise,

     where p≡n.parent is the parent node of n in , i is the position of node n within its hedge (counting from left to right), n_j is a left sibling node of n, and t(n_j) is a proper subtree of  rooted at n_j. In a minor abuse of terminology, we will frequently refer to the local depth of a simple cycle s, which is to be understood as being shorthand for the local depth of the node containing s.

    Q^;l_;α
    = {c : c ∈ C_;α and ;l[c] = c},

and the set of all (,l)-irreducible cycles on  by Q^;l_ = ∪_α  Q^;l_;α.

sentence:

    w = αμ_2⋯μ_Lω[_j=1^N_L+1c_L+1,j]
    ⋯[_j=1^N_2c_2,j]
    [_j=1^N_1c_1,j],

where αμ_2⋯μ_Lω∈ P_ is a simple path of length L ≥ 0 on , N_i ≥ 0 is the number of child cycles off μ_i, and c_i,j∈ C_\α⋯μ_i-1;μ_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ L+1 and 1 ≤ j ≤ N_i. Then  maps w to the set

    [w] = {αμ_2⋯μ_Lω}   [_j=1^N_L+1(
             C_\α⋯μ_L;ω^ *;0\α⋯μ_L[c_L+1,j])]  C_\α⋯μ_L;ω^ *
        ⋯
       [_j=1^N_1(
             C_;α^ *;0[c_1,j])]  C_;α^ *,

where ;0 is the cycle dressing operator of Definition <ref>.

sentence:
Let  be a digraph, W_ be the set of all walks on , and ℤ be the set of integers. Then a formal power series in W_ over ℤ is a mapping f:W_→ℤ. The value of f at a particular w ∈ W_, also termed the coefficient of w in f, is denoted by (f,w), and f itself is written as a formal sum

    f = ∑_w  ∈ W_ (f,w)  w.

The space of all formal power series in W_ over ℤ is denoted by ℤW_.

sentence:
Let  be a digraph,  be a dressing signature, and α be a vertex on . Then the vertex α dressed by -structured cycles on  (also termed the -dressed vertex), denoted by (α)_^, is the formal power series defined by


    (α)_^ = ∑_w  ∈ C^ *_;αw

where C^_;α is the set of -structured cycles of Definition <ref>. In other words, (α)_^ is the characteristic series of C^ *_;α. Then by exploiting the definition of the Kleene star and formally resumming the geometric series of -structured cycles, we find

    (α)_^
      = ∑_n=0^∞∑_w  ∈ (C_;α^)^nw
       = ∑_n=0^∞[∑_c ∈ C_;α^ c  ]^n
      ≡[1 - ∑_c  ∈ C_;α^ c]^-1,

where the first equality follows from the definition of the Kleene star (see Definition <ref>), the second from the definition of the nesting power of a set of cycles (see Definition <ref>), and the third is to be taken as a definition of the short-hand expression on the right-hand side. The dressed vertex (α)^_ is the sum of all walks off α on  that consist of zero or more -structured cycles off α concatenated together: that is,

    (α)_^ =  (α) + ∑_c ∈ C^_;α c + ∑_c_1 ∈ C^_;α
     c_2 ∈ C^_;α c_1  c_2 + ⋯


If C^_;α is empty then all terms past the first vanish, and (α)_^ is equal to the trival walk (α). Two simple examples of dressed vertices are depicted in Figure <ref>.

sentence: A weighted digraph (, ) is a digraph  paired with a weight function  that assigns a weight [e] to each edge e of . To make the discussion concrete while retaining some generality, we consider here a weight function that assigns a complex matrix of size d_β× d_α to the edge (αβ). We denote the weight of the edge (αβ) by _βα = [(αβ)].

sentence:
Given a weighted digraph (, ), we extend the domain of the weight function  from edges to walks by
defining the weight of a trivial walk (α) ∈ T_ to be the d_α× d_α identity matrix I_α, and the weight of a walk w = αμ_2⋯μ_Lω of length L ≥ 1 to be the right-to-left product of the weights of the edges traversed by w:

    [αμ_2⋯μ_Lω]    = [(μ_Lω)]⋯[(μ_2μ_3)][(αμ_2)]
       = _ωμ_L⋯_μ_3μ_2_μ_2α.

Note that the ordering of the edge weights is suitable for the matrix multiplication to be carried out, the end result being a matrix of size d_ω× d_α.

sentence: We call an edge free if it does not belong to any copy of H, open if it is contained in exactly one copy of H and closed otherwise. Furthermore, we call a copy of H unproblematic if it contains at least two open edges. Otherwise we call the copy problematic .

sentence:
The Voronoi subdivision of a k-simplex divides it 
into k+1 regions, where region i consists of the 
points in the simplex for which i is the closest vertex.
Given a subdivision S of nΔ_d-1, 
we subdivide each fine mixed cell S_1+…  + S_n 
into regions R_1+… +R_n, where R_i is a 
region in the Voronoi subdivision of S_i.
The resulting subdivision of nΔ_d-1 is called
the mixed Voronoi subdivision of S.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
The colored dual of a subdivision S of nΔ_d-1
is the colored polyhedral complex formed by the lower-dimensional faces  
in the mixed Voronoi subdivision of S, excluding those on the boundary of n Δ_d-1. In the mixed cell S_1+… +S_n,
color i is given to  
S_1+…S_i+…  +S_n,
where S_i is the complex of lower dimensional faces  
in the Voronoi subdivision of S_i, 
excluding those on the boundary of S_i.

sentence:
A system of permutations on the edges of the triangle nΔ_2
is a set of three permutations of [n] on the edges of the triangle.
We say that a system of permutations is acyclic if, 
when we read the three permutations in clockwise 
direction, starting from a vertex of the triangle, we never see 
a “cycle" of the form
…  i …  j … , …  i …  j … , …  i …  j ….

[The permutation of an edge]
Since S |_nw_aw_b is a subdivision, for each i ∈ [n] there is a unique cell having i-1 summands equal to w_b, n-i summands equal to w_a, and one summand (which we denote S_σ_ab(i)) equal to w_aw_b. It is easy to see that σ_ab is a permutation of [n], which we call the permutation of the edge nw_aw_b . 
(Note that σ_ab is the reverse of σ_ba for any 1 ≤ a ≠ b ≤ d.)

σ_ab

sentence:
A system of permutations on the edges of n_d-1
is a collection =(σ_ab)_1≤ a ≠ b ≤ d
of permutations σ_ab of [n]
such that
σ_ab is the reverse of σ_ba for all a, b. 
For each pair 1≤ i ≠ j  ≤ n we define the 
directed graph G_ij() of 
as the complete graph on [d], where edge ab is directed
a→ b if and only if the permutation σ_ab
is of the form …  i …  j …. 
We say that a system of permutations  is acyclic
if and only if all the graphs G_ij() are acyclic.

sentence:
[Multiplicities of edges and vertices in rooted or unrooted trees, see Figure <ref>]
Let T, e, T_-, U_+, v_-, v_+ be as above. Then:


  -
The rooted multiplicity of the edge e in T , denoted by m_T(e) is the number of distinct edges in T that are mapped to e by some isomorphism of T (as a rooted tree).

  -
The rooted multiplicity of the vertex v_- in T_- , denoted by m_T_-(v_-) is the number of distinct vertices in T_- that are mapped to v_- by some isomorphism of T_- (as a rooted tree, rooted at the root of T).

  -
The unrooted multiplicity of v_+ in U_+ , denoted by n_U_+(v_+) is the number of distinct vertices in U_+ that are mapped to v_+ by some isomorphism of U_+ (as an unrooted tree).

sentence:
For any 𝐳∈Λ and any T∈, we define its maximum weight with respect to 𝐳, denoted by ω(T,𝐳), to be the largest weight ω (𝐓, 𝐳), where 𝐓 is a _0-admissible decomposition of T.
Note that ω(T,𝐳) is well defined since each tree T has at least one _0-admissible decomposition[Here we do a slight abuse of notation by using ω(𝐓,𝐳) and ω(T,𝐳) to denote, respectively, the weight of a given decomposition 𝐓 and the maximum weight of a decomposition of a given tree T.].

sentence:
A graph is matchable if it has a perfect matching.
	An edge e ∈ E(G) is extendable
		if there exists a perfect matching of G
		which contains e.
	Otherwise, e is free .
	The extendable subgraph ( free subgraph ) of G is 
		the spanning subgraph containing all extendable (free) edges of G.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If the extendable subgraph of a matchable graph G is connected,
		then G is elementary .
	A set S ⊂ V(G) is a barrier[We take the convention that the empty set is a barrier.]
		if the number of connected components 
		with an odd number of vertices
		in 
		G - S (denoted (G-S)) is equal to |S|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph with Φ(G) > 0.
	A chamber 
		is a subgraph of G
		induced by 
		a connected component of the extendable 
		subgraph of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G_1,…,G_k be elementary graphs
		and for each i let X_i ⊆ V(G_i) 
		be a barrier in G_i.
	The spire generated by G_1,…,G_k on X_1,…,X_k
		is the graph given by disjoint union of G_1,…, G_k
		and edges x_iv_j for all x_i ∈ X_i and v_j ∈ V(G_j),
		whenever i < j.

sentence:
A connected graph is 1-extendable if every edge is extendable[
		This term comes from k-extendable graphs, where
			every matching of size k extends to a perfect matching.
	].

sentence:
A graph H with n(H) ≥ 3 is 2-connected if 
		there is no vertex x ∈ V(G) so that H-x is disconnected.

sentence:
A sequence H_0 ⊂ H_1 ⊂ H_2 ⊂⋯⊂ H_k
		of ear augmentations
		is a graded ear decomposition
		if each H^(i) is 1-extendable.
	The decomposition is non-refinable if
		for all i < k, there is no 1-extendable graph H'
		so that H^(i)⊂ H' ⊂ H^(i+1)
		is a graded ear decomposition.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graph H is almost 1-extendable if 
		the free edges of H appear in a single 
		ear of H.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
With this property, all graphs in ^p_N_p can be generated 
	by a recursive process:
Begin at an even cycle H_0 = C_2ℓ.
For each H^(i), try adding each all ears  of order r to all pairs of vertices
	in H^(i) where 0 ≤ r ≤ N_p - n(H^i) to 
	form H^(i+1) +.
If H^(i+1) is 1-extendable or H^(i) is 1-extendable and H^(i+1) is almost 1-extendable,
	recurse on H^(i+1) until Φ(H^(i+1)) > p.
While this technique will generate all graphs in ^p_N_p, 
	it will generate each unlabeled graph several times.
In fact, the number of times an unlabeled H ∈^p_N_p
	appears is at least the number of ear decompositions
	H_0 ⊂⋯⊂ H_k⊂ H
	which match the conditions of Corollary <ref>.
	
We will remove these redundancies in two ways.
First, we will augment using pair orbits of vertices in H^(i).
Second, we will reject some augmentations
	if they do not correspond with a “canonical" 
	ear decomposition of the larger graph.
This technique is described in detail in <cit.>.	
	
	Let (H) be a function which takes a graph H ∈^p
		and returns an ear  in H
		so that H - is in ^p.
	This function (H) is a canonical deletion
		if for any two H_1, H_2 ∈^p so that H_1 ≅ H_2,
		there exists an isomorphism σ : H_1→ H_2
		that  maps (H_1) to (H_2).
	
	Given a canonical deletion (H), 
		the canonical ear decomposition at H
		is given by the following iterative construction:
		(i) Set H_0 = H and i = 0.
		(ii) While H^(i) is not a cycle, define H_i-1 = H^(i) - (H^(i)) 
		and decrement i.
	When this process terminates,
		what results is an ear decomposition 
	H_-k⊂ H_-(k-1)⊂⋯⊂ H_-1⊂ H_0
	where H_-k is isomorphic to a cycle and H_0 = H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A function (H) which takes a labeled graph H
		and outputs a bijection σ_H : V(H) →{1,…,n(H)}
		is a canonical labeling 
		if for all H_1 ≅ H_2
		the map π : V(H_1)→ V(H_2)
		defined as π(x) = σ_H_2^-1(σ_H_1(x))
		is an isomorphism.
	The canonical labeling σ_H = (H) on the vertex set 
		induces a label γ_H on the ears of H.
	Given an ear  of order r between endpoints x and y,
		let γ_H() be the triple (r, min{σ_H(x),σ_H(y)}, max{σ_H(x),σ_H(y)}).
	These labels have a natural lexicographic ordering
		which minimizes the order of an ear and then minimizes
		the pair of canonical labels of the endpoints.

sentence:
Let G be an elementary graph.
	The barrier set (G) 
		is the set of all barriers in G.



	The barrier partition (G) 
		is the set of all maximal barriers in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a 1-extendable graph H, 
		 barriers B_1 and B_2 conflict if
		(a) B_1 ∩ B_2 ≠∅,
		(b) B_1 spans multiple components of H - B_2, or
		(c) B_2 spans multiple components of H - B_1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A set  of barriers in (H)
		is a cover set if each pair B_1, B_2 of barriers in 
		are non-conflicting and  is a partition of V(H).
	Let (H) be the family of cover sets in (H).
	If _1, _2 ∈(H) are cover sets,
		let the relation _1 ≼_2
		hold
		
		
		
		if for each set B_1 ∈_1 there exists a set B_2 ∈_2
		so that B_1 ⊆ B_2.
	This defines a partial order on (H) and the poset ((H), ≼)
		has a unique minimal element given by the partition of V(H) 
		into singletons.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a graph H, the parameter d(H) := e(H)/v(H) is called the density of H, and m(H) := max{d(H') | H'⊆ H} is the maximum density of H. A graph H is called strictly balanced if d(H) > d(H') for every H' ⊊ H.

For i∈{1,2}, if v(H)≥ i+1 we define d_i(H) := e(H)-i+1/v(H)-i to be the i-density of H. Similarly to the previous definitions, we define m_i(H) := max{d_i(H') | H'⊆ H, v(H')≥ i+1 } to be the maximum i-density of H, and a graph H is called strictly i-balanced if d_i(H) > d_i(H') for every H' ⊊ H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: density;maximum density;strictly balanced;i-density;maximum i-density;strictly i-balanced;1-density;2-density;maximum i-density;strictly i-balanced

sentence: A diamond is a K_4-copy with one edge missing. A Double Diamond , denoted by DD,  consists of two diamonds with vertex sets {x,y_1,z_1,z_2} and {x,y_2,z_3,z_4} where z_1z_2 and z_3z_4 are the missing edges (see Figure <ref>). The intersection of the two diamonds, namely the vertex x, is called the center of DD.

sentence:
A graph Γ is an H-chain of length t if it consists of t≥ 1 copies H_1 , … , H_t of H, such that
    
    ∀ 1 ≤ i < j ≤ t:  |V(H_i) ∩ V(H_j)| =  1    j - i = 1,
     0    otherwise.

sentence:
A graph Γ is an
    H-cycle of length t if it consists of t ≥ 3 copies
    H_1, …, H_t of H, such that
    
    ∀ 1 ≤ i,j ≤ t:   |V(H_i) ∩ V(H_j)| =
         1    |j - i| 1t,
     0    otherwise.

sentence: Given a graph G, an edge e ∈ E(G) belonging to two distinct H-copies in G is called dangerous with respect to H. Since H is always clear from the context, we simply refer to such edges as dangerous.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G,H be graphs, where H is connected, and let b be a
positive integer. All the following are defined with respect to G,
H and b. A bad vertex is a vertex v ∈ V(G) which is
not contained in any H-copy in G. A bad edge is an edge
e ∈ E(G) which is not contained in any H-copy in G. A
bad set is a set U  V(G) of size 2 ≤ |U| ≤ b+1
such that there is no H-copy Ĥ G satisfying
|V(Ĥ) ∩ U| = 1. A bad set of size 2 is referred to as a bad pair . A small component is a connected component of
G with at most (b+1)(v(H)-1) vertices.

sentence: Let G be a graph.	Two vertices u,v ∈ V(G) are called evil twins if uv ∈ E(G) and d_G(u)=d_G(v)=2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
A partial matching in a poset P is a partial matching in the underlying graph of the Hasse diagram
of P, i.e., it is a subset M⊆ P × P such that


  * (a,b)∈ M implies b ≻ a; i.e. a<b and no c satisifies a<c<b.

  * each a∈ P belongs to at most one element in M.

When (a,b) ∈ M, we write a=d(b) and b=u(a).

  * A partial matching on P is called acyclic if there does not exist a cycle

    a_1 ≺ u(a_1) ≻ a_2 ≺ u(a_2) ≻⋯≺ u(a_m) ≻ a_1

with m≥ 2 and all a_i∈ P being distinct.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a graph G=(V,E), the neighborhood complex of G is the simplicial complex (G) with vertex set V and faces given by subsets of V sharing a common neighbor in G, i.e. (G) := { F⊂ V: ∃ v∈ V  s.t. ∀ u∈ F, {u,v}∈ E}.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For n≥ 1 and k≥ 0 the Kneser graph , denoted KG_n, k, is the graph whose vertices are the subsets of [2n +k] of size n.
We connect two such vertices with an edge when they are disjoint as sets.

We call an n-set α of [2n+k] stable if α does not contain the subset {1, 2n+k} or any of the subsets {i, i+1} for i=1,… , 2n+k-1.
The stable Kneser graph , denoted SG_n, k, is the induced subgraph of KG_n, k whose vertices are the stable subsets of [2n+k].
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We call a stable n-set α tight if α = {i, i + 2, i + 4, …, i + 2(n-1) } for some i ∈ [2n + 2].
Otherwise, we call α a loose stable n-set.

For α={α_1, …, α_n} and β stable n-sets, we call α and β immediate neighbors if α⊕ 1 = β or α⊖ 1 = β, where α⊕ j:= {α_1 + j, …, α_n + j} and α⊖ j is defined similarly.

We call α and β outer neighbors if there is an ordering of the elements of α such that β =(α_1 + 1, α_2 + 1, …, α_i-1 + 1 , α_i + 2, α_i+1 + 1, …, α_n + 1) and α and β are neighbors in SG_n, 2.

  let _k,s:=⟨ x^[0],x^[s],…, x^[s(k-1)]⟩≤_n,k.
  Any code equivalent to _k,s is called a
  generalized Gabidulin code .
  Any code equivalent to _k:=_k,1 is

sentence:
A weighted tripartite graph ν with vertex sets
  X, Y, and Z satisfies the 3-linear forms condition if
  
    _x,x' ∈ X, y,y' ∈ Y, z,z' ∈ Z
        [ν(y,z) ν(y',z) ν(y,z') ν(y',z')
        ν(x,z) ν(x',z) ν(x,z') ν(x',z') 
    ·ν(x,y) ν(x',y) ν(x,y') ν(x',y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

  Similarly, a function ν_N → [0,∞) satisfies
  the 3-linear forms condition[We will
    assume that N is odd, which simplifies the proof of
    Theorem <ref> without too much loss in generality. Theorem <ref> holds more generally without this additional
    assumption on N.] if
  
    _x,x',y,y',z,z' ∈_N [ν(-y-2z) ν(-y'-2z) ν(-y-2z')
        ν(-y'-2z')
        ν(x-z) ν(x'-z) 
    ·ν(x-z') ν(x'-z')
        ν(2x+y) ν(2x'+y) ν(2x+y') ν(2x'+y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[3-linear forms condition] 
  A weighted tripartite graph ν with vertex sets
  X, Y, and Z satisfies the 3-linear forms condition if
  
    _x,x' ∈ X, y,y' ∈ Y, z,z' ∈ Z
        [ν(y,z) ν(y',z) ν(y,z') ν(y',z')
        ν(x,z) ν(x',z) ν(x,z') ν(x',z') 
    ·ν(x,y) ν(x',y) ν(x,y') ν(x',y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

  Similarly, a function ν_N → [0,∞) satisfies
  the 3-linear forms condition[We will
    assume that N is odd, which simplifies the proof of
    Theorem <ref> without too much loss in generality. Theorem <ref> holds more generally without this additional
    assumption on N.] if
  
    _x,x',y,y',z,z' ∈_N [ν(-y-2z) ν(-y'-2z) ν(-y-2z')
        ν(-y'-2z')
        ν(x-z) ν(x'-z) 
    ·ν(x-z') ν(x'-z')
        ν(2x+y) ν(2x'+y) ν(2x+y') ν(2x'+y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

sentence:
[Linear forms condition]
  
  A function ν : _N → [0,∞) satisfies the
  k-linear forms condition[As in the footnote to
    Definition <ref>, in our proof of
    Theorem <ref> we will make the simplifying assumption
    that N is coprime to
    (k-1)!. In the proof of the Green-Tao
    theorem, one can always make this assumption.] if
  
    _x_1^(0), x_1^(1), …, x_k^(0),x_k^(1)∈_N[
        ∏_j=1^k ∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  = 1 + o(1)

  for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{0,1}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let H be a d-regular d-edge-colorable multi-graph and let G be the line graph of H. Let V(G) = {v_1, …, v_n}. Let C_d denote the set of proper colorings of G with colors {0,1, …, d-1}. For c ∈ C_d, the sign of c, denoted sign(c), is defined to be 1 if P_G(c(v_1), …, c(v_n)) > 0 and -1 otherwise. Then, AT(G) ≤ d if and only if ∑_c ∈ C_d sign(c) ≠ 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P ∈ℝ[x_1, …, x_n] be a polynomial of degree m. Let f : {1, …, n}→ℕ^+ be a function satisfying ∑_i=1^n f(i) = m+n. Let NZ(P) := {(z_1, …, z_n) ∈{0, …, f(1)-1}×…×{0, …, f(n)-1} : P(z_1, …, z_n) ≠ 0} denote the set of non-zeros of P in {0, …, f(1)-1}×…×{0, …, f(n)-1}. If

    ∑_(z_1, …, z_n) ∈ NZ(P) (-1)^∑_i=1^n z_i∏_i=1^n f(i)-1z_i P(z_1, …, z_n) ≠ 0,

then, for every S_1, …, S_n ⊆ℝ, where |S_i| ≥ f(i) for every 1 ≤ i ≤ n, there exists (s_1, …, s_n) ∈ S_1 ×…× S_n such that P(s_1, …, s_n) ≠ 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let ℋ=(V,E) be any hypergraph, where V = {1,2, …, n} and |E|=m. Let f : V →ℕ^+ be a function satisfying ∑_u ∈ V f(u) = m+n. Let Q = Q_ℋ, f(x_1, …, x_n) be any polynomial of degree m such that Q(c(1), …, c(n)) = 0 whenever (c(1), …, c(n)) ∈{0, …, f(1)-1}×…×{0, …, f(n)-1} is not a proper coloring of ℋ. Let NZ(Q) denote the set of non-zeros of Q in {0, …, f(1)-1}×…×{0, …, f(n)-1}. If

    ∑_(c_1, …, c_n) ∈ NZ(Q) (-1)^∑_i=1^n c_i∏_i=1^nf(i)-1  c_i Q(c_1, …, c_n) ≠ 0,

then ℋ is f-AT.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G=(V,E) be a multi-graph with vertex set V = {v_1, …, v_n} and let f : V →ℕ^+. We say that G is Alon-Tarsi f-choosable , or f-AT for brevity, if there exists a monomial c ∏_i=1^n x_i^t_i in the expansion of P_G such that c ≠ 0 (say, in ℝ) and t_i ≤ f(i)-1 for every 1 ≤ i ≤ n. If f(i)=k for every 1 ≤ i ≤ n, then we say that G is Alon-Tarsi k-choosable , or k-AT for brevity. The smallest integer k for which G is Alon-Tarsi k-choosable, denoted by AT(G), is called the Alon-Tarsi number of G .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: Alon-Tarsi f-choosable;Alon-Tarsi k-choosable;Alon-Tarsi number of G

sentence: Let G be a connected graph and let H be a non-trivial graph. Then, every metric generator for G ∘ H is also an adjacency generator, and vice versa .

sentence: A barred pattern is a permutation ρ∈𝒮_k where any entry may have a bar over it.   A permutation π is said to contain ρ if π contains a permutation pattern made up of the non-barred entries of ρ that does not extend to a permutation pattern including all entries of ρ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The graph of a permutation π∈𝒮_n is the set of points 
    {(i,π_i) | 1 ≤ i ≤ n}.

sentence: Let Γ be a finite collection of monomials.  Then Γ is a discrete polymatroid if it satisfies the following two properties:  1) If m∈Γ and m' divides m, then m' ∈Γ, and 2) If m, m' ∈Γ and the degree of m is greater than that of m', there exists an index i such that d_i(m) > d_i(m') and x_im' ∈Γ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let V = {σ_1, σ_2, …, σ_t} be a vertex of 𝒢(μ) for some μ, where again we have written σ_i to mean m(σ_i).  We call the vertex V thin if it has the following two properties: 


  1: For any two paths σ_i, σ_j ∈ V, either σ_i ≽σ_j or σ_j ≽σ_i.  

  2: For any i, the i^th east steps of any two paths in V are at most a unit length apart.

sentence: A matrix ∗-algebra is a collection of matrices that is closed under addition, scalar multiplication, matrix multiplication and transposition.

sentence: Let a,b∈ℤ^n. We said that a is linear equivalent to b, denoted by a∼ b, if they are in a same coset of (G).

sentence:
i) A sequence of vertices (s_1,…,s_k) of V∖ n+1 is called a firing sequence of a if vertex s_1 of a is active and after firing consecutively from a vertices s_1,s_2,…,s_i the vertex s_i+1 is active for each i=2,…, k-1. 

  ii) A firing script of a firing sequence (s_1,s_2,…,s_k) of  on G is a sequence of n non-negative integers τ=(τ_1,τ_2,…,τ_n), where τ_i is the number of occurrences vertex i in the firing sequence (s_1,s_2,…,s_k).

sentence: A configuration a of (G) is called critical if it is stable and there exists a non-negative configuration c such that a=(a_max+c)^o.

sentence:
Let G be a digraph with a global sink and reduced Laplacian matrix Δ. Let σ be an n-script. Then  
  

  i) σ is called a G-positive script if σΔ≻0⃗

  ii) σ is called a G-strongly positive script if σ is G-positive script and the support of σΔ intersects to each strongly connected component except for the sink component of G non-empty.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 1 ≤ℓ < r.
		We say that a sequence 𝐆=(G_n)_n∈ℕ of r-graphs is an (r,ℓ)-sequence if 
		
			
  * v(G_n)→∞ as n→∞ and
			
  * there is a constant p ∈ [0,1] and a sequence of nonnegative reals ε_n → 0 as n →∞ such that δ_ℓ^_n(G_n) ≥ p v(G_n)-ℓr-ℓ for each n. 
	
		We refer to the supremum of all p≥ 0 for which (ii) is satisfied as the density of the sequence 𝐆 and denote it by ρ(𝐆) .

sentence:
[(r,ℓ)-sequence] 
		Let 1 ≤ℓ < r.
		We say that a sequence 𝐆=(G_n)_n∈ℕ of r-graphs is an (r,ℓ)-sequence if 
		
			
  * v(G_n)→∞ as n→∞ and
			
  * there is a constant p ∈ [0,1] and a sequence of nonnegative reals ε_n → 0 as n →∞ such that δ_ℓ^_n(G_n) ≥ p v(G_n)-ℓr-ℓ for each n. 
	
		We refer to the supremum of all p≥ 0 for which (ii) is satisfied as the density of the sequence 𝐆 and denote it by ρ(𝐆) .

sentence:
[(1,2)-quasirandomness]
A 3-graph G is (p, ε, (1,2))-quasirandom if for every set of vertices X⊆ V and every set of pairs of vertices P⊆ V^(2), the number e_1,2(X,P) of pairs (x, uv)∈ X× P such  that {x}∪{uv}∈ E(G) satisfies:
		
    | e_1,2(X, P) - p | X|·| P||≤εv(G)^3.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Vertices x^v and y^v of the polytope (n) are not adjacent if and only if the following conditions are satisfied.
	
		
  * There exists a city i (called left block ) such that the tours x and y on the coordinate i (coordinates i and i+1 for double blocks) have the form of U,L, or i = 1.
		
		
  * There exists a city j (called right block ) such that the tours x and y on the coordinate j (coordinates j-1 and j for double blocks) have the form of U,R, or j = n.
		
		We denote by i_a the first city after the left block: i_a = i+1 for single blocks and i_a = i+2 for double blocks.
		We denote by j_b the last city before the right block: j_b = i-1 for single blocks and j_b = j-2 for double blocks.
		
		Two blocks cut the encoding of the tours into three parts: the left (less than i_a), the central (from i_a to j_b) and the right (larger than j_b).
		
		
  * In the central part, the coordinates of x^0,1 and y^0,1 completely coincide: x^0,1_[i_a,j_b] = y^0,1_[i_a,j_b].
		
		We say that two tours
		
			
  * differ in the left part if x^0,1,sb_[1,i_a-1]≠ y^0,1,sb_[1,i_a-1],
			
  * differ in the right part if x^0,1,sb_[j_b+1,n]≠ y^0,1,sb_[j_b+1,n],
			
  * differ in the central part in ascending order if x^1,sb_[i_a,j_b]≠ y^1,sb_[i_a,j_b],
			
  * differ in the central part in descending order if x^0,sb_[i_a,j_b]≠ y^0,sb_[i_a,j_b].
		
		
		The remaining conditions are divided into four cases depending on the values of x^0,1_i and x^0,1_j.
		
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = x^0,1_j = 1, then the tours differ
			
				
  * in the central part in ascending order;
				
  * in the left part, or in the central part in descending order, or in the right part.
			
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = x^0,1_j = 0, then the tours differ
			
				
  * in the central part in descending order;
				
  * in the left part, or in the central part in ascending order, or in the right part.
			
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = 1, x^0,1_j = 0, then the tours differ	
			
				
  * in the central part in ascending order or in the right part;
				
  * in the central part in descending order or in the left part.
			
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = 0, x^0,1_j = 1, then the tours differ
		
			
				
  * in the central part in descending order or in the right part;
				
  * in the central part in ascending order or in the left part.
			
		
	
	Cities 1 and n can be considered in the encoding as visited in ascending or descending order, if required.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let M=(E,) be a matroid with n elements, of rank r.  For a set X⊆ E, we say that a flat F∈(M) covers X if |F∩ X|>r_M(F).
We say that a set of flats 𝒵 is a flat cover of M if  each non-basis X∈Er∖ is covered by some F∈𝒵.

sentence: For an r-set  X ∈Er, we say that a collection of flats 𝒵_X ⊆(M) is a local cover at X if 𝒵_X covers all the non-bases Y ∈ (N(X) ∪{X})∖.

sentence: Given a set S ⊂^d, the S-Helly number _S (if it exists) is the smallest positive integer with the following property. Suppose that ℱ is a finite family of convex sets in ^d, and that ⋂𝒢 intersects S for every subfamily 𝒢 of ℱ having at most _S members. Then ⋂ℱ intersects S.

sentence: Given a discrete set S ⊂^d, the quantitative S-Helly number _S(k) (if it exists) is the smallest positive integer with the following property. Suppose that ℱ is a finite family of convex sets in ^d, and that ⋂𝒢 intersects S in at least k points for every subfamily 𝒢 of ℱ having at least _S(k) members. Then ⋂ℱ intersects S in at least k points

sentence: Given a set S⊂^d, the S-Tverberg number _S(m) (if it exists) is the smallest positive integer such that among any _S(m) distinct points in S⊆^d, there is a partition of them into m sets A_1,A_2,…,A_m such that the intersection of their convex hulls contains some point of S.

sentence: Given a discrete subset S of ^d, the quantitative S-Tverberg number _S(m,k) (if it exists) is the smallest positive integer such that among any _S(m,k) distinct points in S⊆^d, there is a partition of them into m sets A_1,A_2,…,A_m such that the intersection of their convex hulls contains at least k points of S.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph. An induced subgraph H of G
on m vertices is called p-full if its minimum
degree is at least p(m-1), and is called
p-co-full if its maximum degree is at most
p(m-1). Let f_p(G) be the largest number of vertices
in a p-full subgraph of G, and let g_p(G) be the
largest size of a p-full or p-co-full subgraph of
G. If p happens to be the density of G, then in
fact f_p(G)= f(G) and g_p(G) = g(G). Determining the
smallest possible values of f_p(G) and g_p(G) given
the number of edges and number of vertices in G can be
viewed as generalisations of the Turán and of the
Ramsey problems, respectively, which comprise the case p
= 1; see <cit.> and the references
therein.


The positive p-discrepancy of G is defined to
be disc_p^+(G)=max_X⊆
Vδ_p(X). The negative p-discrepancy of
G is disc_p^-(G)=max_X⊆ V
(-δ_p(X)). The p-discrepancy of G is
disc_p(G)=max(disc_p^+(G),
disc_p^-(G)). Finally, the
p-jumbledness of G is

    j_p(G)=max_X⊆ V|δ_p(X)|/| X|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph on n vertices, and let k:1≤ k≤ n be an integer. The p-jumbledness
of G on k-sets is defined to be

    j_k,p(G)=max_X⊆ V:  | X| =k|δ_p(X) |/| X|.

Similarly, the positive p-discrepancy of G on k-sets is defined to be

    disc_k,p^+(G)=max_X⊆ V:  | X| =kδ_p(X),

with the negative p-discrepancy on k-sets disc_k,p^-(G) and the p-discrepancy on k-sets disc_k,p(G)
defined mutatis mutandis.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O
plain_text_term: positive p-discrepancy of G on k-sets;negative p-discrepancy on k-sets;p-discrepancy on k-sets

sentence:
A graph G is (δ,K)-separable if by removing δ v(G)
  vertices from G one can obtain a graph in which every component has size at
  most K. A family 𝒢 of graphs is separable if for every
  δ>0 there is some K such that each graph G∈𝒢 is
  (δ,K)-separable.

 A formula ϕ(;) is stable in  if for some N ∈ω there are not sequences _1,…,_N ∈ M^|| and _1,…,_N ∈ M^|| such that ϕ(_i;_j)^ i < j.

sentence:
Let (D,w) be a weighted Dyck path of size n.
  
  
  * The total weight of (D,w) (denoted by (D,w)) is
    the sum of the values of w.
  
  * The descent set of (D,w) is
    
    (D,w) = {i | w_i > w_i+1}∪{ i | w_i = w_i+1, D_2i
          = / }

    and the descent composition (D,w) is the composition
    of n whose descent set is (D,w).
  
  * The Genocchi descent set of (D,w) is
    
    (D,w) = { i ∈ [2, n] | D_2i-1 = \}

    then, as for permutations, the Genocchi composition of
      descent of (D,w) (denoted by (D,w)) is the composition of n
    whose descent set is {d-1 | d ∈(D,w)}.

sentence:

       D_2i+1 = / }

  and the descent composition of type 0 (denoted by ^0(D,w))
  is the composition of n whose descent set is ^0(D,w).

sentence:
Let σ∈_n. We define the Genocchi descent set of
   type 0 as
 
    ^0(σ) = {i ∈{1, …,n} | σ_i>σ_i+1}.

 Note that σ_n and n always belong to ^0(σ). We
 also define the Genocchi composition of descents of type 0
 (denoted by ^0) as the composition of n whose descent set is
 ^0(σ)\{n}.

sentence:
Let V be a subspace of _p^n and let q be
a quadratic form on V. A quadratic average with
base (V,q) is a function of the form Q(x)=_y∈
x-Vω^q_y(x), where each function q_y is a 
quadratic map from y+V to _p defined by a formula
of the form q_y(x)=q(x-y)+ϕ_y(x-y) for some Freiman homomorphism
ϕ_y:V_p. The rank of Q is the rank
of the quadratic form q, and the complexity of Q
is the codimension of V.

sentence: Given a rooted graph G_v and an integer k≥ 0, the ℓ-extension of G_v , denoted G_v^ℓ is the graph formed by identifying the root v with one of the endpoints of a (disjoint) path of length ℓ and reassigning the root to the other endpoint of the path.

sentence:
Let 𝒞 be a combinatorial class and C(x):=∑_γ∈𝒞x^|γ| its generating function. 
Given a coherent positive real value of x, i.e., chosen within the disk of
 convergence of C(x)), the  Boltzmann model of parameter x 
assigns to any element γ∈𝒞 the following probability, 

    ℙ_x(γ)=x^|γ|/C(x).

sentence:
<cit.>
Consider x^α∈. 
The Pommaret cone of x^α∈ is the set of terms 𝒞_(x^α)={ x^α x^δ|max(x^δ)≤min(x^α)}.
Let M⊂𝕋(ℓ) be a finite set. The Pommaret span of M is 

    < M >_:=⋃_x^α∈ M𝒞_(x^α).


The finite set of terms M is a weak Pommaret basis if <M>_=(M) and it is a Pommaret basis if the union on the right hand side of (<ref>) is disjoint. 

Let M⊇ M be a finite set in  such that < M>_=(M). We call M a Pommaret completion of M. An obstruction is any element of (M)∖<M>_.

sentence: Let J⊂ be  a stable monomial ideal. The term x^α∈ J is St-minimal if x_jx^β/min(x^β)≠ x^α, for every x^β∈ J and for every x_j>min(x^β).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let I⊂ be a homogeneous ideal. We say that I is Borel-fixed if for every g∈ℬ, g(I)=I.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
For every i<j, for every s>0, we define the s-th increasing move on the term x^α∈ as

    e_i,j^+(s)(x^α)=x_j^sx^α/x_i^s=x_ℓ^α_ℓ⋯ x_i^α_i-s⋯ x_j^α_j+s⋯ x_n^α_n.

We say that the increasing move e_i,j^+(s) on the term x^α  is p-admissible if e_i,j^+(s)(x^α)∈ and s≺_p α_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence: Let J be a p-Borel ideal and consider x^α∈ J. x^α is p-minimal if there is no other term in J smaller than x^α w.r.t <_p.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a graph G and two vertices x,y ∈ V(G), let d(x,y) denote the distance between x and y - the length of the shortest path with x and y as endpoints. If x=y, then d(x,x)=0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a fixed positive integer k, a graph G, and a vertex x ∈ V(G), let 
    f_k(x) = |{y ∈ V(G) : d(x,y) ≤ k}|.
 Let 
    δ_k(G) = min_x ∈ V(G)f_k(x),
 the minimum k-distance degree of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: Given a graph G and a subset of its vertices S ⊆ V(G), we say that S k-distance dominates G if for each vertex x ∈ V(G), there exists some vertex y ∈ S such that d(x,y) ≤ k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a graph G, we call a partition of the vertices, 
    V(G) = S_1 ∪ S_2 ∪⋯∪ S_t,
 into t disjoint parts a k-distance domatic partition if each S_i is a k-distance dominating set of G. Such a partition is equivalent to an assignment of t colors to the vertices, 
    c:V(G) →{1,2,…,t},
 such that for each vertex x ∈ V(G) and for each color i ∈{1,…,t}, there exists a vertex y ∈ V(G) such that d(x,y) ≤ k and c(y) = i. We will call such a coloring a proper k-distance domatic coloring . For a given positive integer k, let d_k(G) denote the maximum t for which such an assignment exists, the k-distance domatic number of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O
plain_text_term: k-distance domatic partition;proper k-distance domatic coloring;k-distance domatic number

sentence:
Note that for any graph G, 
    d_k(G) ≤δ_k(G).
 Graphs that achieve this upper bound, that is any graph G for which 
    d_k(G) = δ_k(G),
 are called k-distance domatically-full .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Given positive integers s and t, let the s × t grid graph G_s,t be the graph with vertex set 
    V(G_s,t) = {(i,j) ∈ℤ^2: 1 ≤ i ≤ s, 1 ≤ j ≤ t}
 and edge set 
    E(G_s,t) ={(a,b)(c,d) : |a-c|+|b-d| =1}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let us define the stable matching polytope P(G)⊆^E for graph G as follows

    P(G):={χ(M)∈^E: M  is a stable matching in  G} .

By <cit.>, P(G) is a nonempty polytope because every
graph G has a stable matching.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A proper face of a polyhedral cone is a subset F⊂ Q
 such
that there is a supporting hyperplane H_a satisfying:

1) F=Q∩ H_a≠∅,

2) Q⊈ H_a and Q⊂ H^+_a.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cone C is  pointed if 0 is a face of C.  Equivalently
we can require that x∈ C  and -x∈ C  ⇒  x=0.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If a polyhedral cone Q is written as 
    Q=H^+_a_1∩…∩ H^+_a_r
 such that no  H^+_a_i can be
omitted, then we say that this is an irreducible representation
 of
Q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let Q be a polyhedral cone in ℝ^n  with Q=n
 and such that Q≠ℝ^n.  Let 

    Q=H^+_a_1∩…∩ H^+_a_r
 
be the irreducible representation of
Q.  If a_i=(a_i1,…,a_in),  then we call

    H_a_i(x):=a_i1x_1+… + a_inx_n=0,  i∈ [r],

the equations of the cone Q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The relative interior ri(Q) of a polyhedral cone is the 
interior of Q with respect to the embedding of Q into its affine
space aff(Q), in which Q is full-dimensional.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S be a finite set. A binary matroid M on S is represented by
a matrix with entries in GF(2), whose columns are indexed by the elements of
S. A subset of S is dependent in M if and only if the corresponding
columns of the matrix are linearly dependent.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If v and w are neighbors in G then the edge pivot
G^vw is the triple simple local complement:

    G^vw=((G_s^v)_s^w)_s^v=((G_s^w)_s^v)_s^w.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a looped simple graph. A partition P of W(G) into three-element
cells is a triangulation if each cell contains either a 3-element
circuit of M(IAS(G)) or a loop and a pair of non-loop parallels.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If G is a looped simple graph and P is a triangulation of W(G) then the
index of P is ‖ P‖ =|{non-canonical cells of P}|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If G is a looped simple graph then the sub-transversals of W(G) are
the elements of 𝒮(W(G))={S⊆ W(G)||
S∩{v_ϕ,v_χ,v_ψ}|≤1 ∀ v∈ V(G)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a looped simple graph. A transverse cycle of G
is an element of ℒ(G)=𝒮(W(G))∩ Z(M(IAS(G))).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: A connected bipartite graph G is called 4-perfect if E_1>0 , E_2>0 where E_1=n_2(A_11+1)-n_1A_12/n_2[A_12A_21-(A_11+1)(A_22+1)] and E_2=n_1(A_22+1)-n_2A_21/n_1[A_12A_21-(A_11+1)(A_22+1)].
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let E⊆ X× Y.  If I⊆ Y, we say {E_x}_x∈ X shatters I if for each J⊆ I, there is an x∈ X with E_x∩ I=J.

The VC dimension of a collection {E_x}_x∈ X is the supremum of |I| for those I⊆ Y such that {E_x}_x∈ X shatters I.  The dual VC dimension of {E_x}_x∈ X is the VC dimension of {E^y}_y∈ Y.

When E⊆ X× Y, the VC dimension of E is the larger of the VC dimension of {E_x}_x∈ X and the dual VC dimension of {E_x}_x∈ X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say Ŷ⊆ Y is an ϵ-net for differences if whenever E_x∩Ŷ=E_x'∩Ŷ, μ(E_x△ E_x')<ϵ.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence: We say 𝒫'=({X'_i},{Y'_j}) refines 𝒫=({X_i},{Y_j}) if for each X_i and each X'_i', either X'_i'⊆ X_i or X'_i'∩ X_i=∅, and if for each Y_j and each Y'_j', either Y'_j'⊆ Y_j or Y'_j'∩ Y_j=∅.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A pair (X_i,Y_j) is ϵ-regular if whenever X'⊆ X_i, Y'⊆ Y_j with μ(X')≥ϵμ(X_i) and μ(Y')≥ϵμ(Y_j), we have

    |d(X_i,Y_j)-d(X',Y')|<ϵ.


If 𝒫 is a partition, we write ℑ(ϵ,𝒫) for the set of (i,j) such that (X_i,Y_j) is not ϵ-regular.

We say 𝒫 is ϵ-regular if ∑_(i,j)∈ℑ(ϵ,𝒫)μ(X_i)μ(Y_j)<ϵ.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: The master graph satisfies the balancing condition .
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The master graph is a weighted graph in ^n+1
    parameterized by n distinct coprime numbers {i_1, …,
    i_n} with nodes:
    
    
  * D_i_j= e_j:=(0, …, 0,
      
      1, 0, …, 0)     (0≤ j≤ n),
    
  * E_i_j=(0, i_1, …, i_j-1,
      
      i_j, …, i_j) , h_i_j=(-i_j, …,
      
      -i_j, -i_j+1, …, -i_n)   (1≤ j≤ n-1),
    
  * F_a=∑_i_j∈a e_j  where a⊆{0, i_1, …, i_n} has size
      at least two and is obtained by intersecting an arithmetic
      progression of integers with the index set {0, i_1, …, i_n}.
    
Its edges agree with the edges of the abstract
tropical secant surface graph, and have weights:


  * m_D_i_0, h_i_1=1 , m_D_i_n,
    E_i_n-1=gcd(i_1, …, i_n-1) , m_D_i_n,
    h_i_n-1=i_n,

  * m_D_i_j,E_i_j=(i_1, …, i_j) , m_D_i_j,
    h_i_j = (i_j, …, i_n)     (1≤ j≤ n-1),
    
  * m_E_i_j, E_i_j+1 =(i_1, …, i_j) ,
m_h_i_j, h_i_j+1= (i_j+1, …, i_n)
        
(1≤ j ≤ n-2),

  * m_F_a, D_i_j=∑_r φ(r), where we sum
  over the common differences r of all arithmetic progressions
  containing i_j and giving the same subset a.  Here,
  φ denotes Euler's phi function.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (G,m)⊂^N be a weighted graph where each node has integer coordinates. Let w be a node in G
  and let {w_1, …, w_r} be the set of nodes adjacent to
  w. Consider the primitive lattices Λ_w = ⟨
  w⟩∩^N and Λ_w,w_i=⟨ w, w_i⟩∩^N. Then, Λ_w,w_i/Λ_w is a rank one
  lattice and it admits a unique generator which lifts to an element
  in the cone _≥ 0⟨ w, w_i⟩⊂^N. Let
  u_w_i|w be one such lifting. We say that the node w is
  balanced if ∑_i=1^r m_w_i,w u_w_i|w∈Λ_w.  If all nodes of G are balanced, then we say that the weighted
  graph (G,m) satisfies the balancing condition .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Given an affine variety X⊂^N with defining ideal
  I=I(X), we define the tropicalization of X to be the set

    X = I={w∈^N: _w(I)  does not contain a monomial}.

Here, _w(I)=⟨_w(f): f∈ I⟩, and if
f=∑_α c_α x^α

, then _w(f)=∑_α· w =W
c_α x^α, where W=min{α· w:
c_α≠ 0}.  If 
X⊂^N, then its tropicalization is defined as
X'⊂^N+1, where X' is the affine cone over X in
^N+1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X,Y⊂^N be subvarieties of tori.  The
  Hadamard product of X and Y equals

    X  Y = {(x_1y_1, …,
        x_Ny_N)   |  x∈ X, y∈ Y}⊂^N.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The tropical secant graph is a weighted subgraph of the
  master graph in ^n+1, with nodes:
  
  
  * D_i_j= e_j:=(0, …, 0,
1, 0, …,    0) 
        (0≤ j≤ n),

  * E_i_j= ∑_k<j i_k· e_k + i_j· (∑_k≥ j e_k)=(0, i_1, …, i_j-1,
  i_j, …, i_j)     (1≤ j≤
  n-1),



  * F_a=∑_i_j∈a e_j  where 
  a⊊{0, i_1, …, i_n} varies among all proper
  subsets containing at least two elements that are obtained from an arithmetic progression.

The edges have positive weights:


  * m_ E_i_j, E_i_j+1 = (i_1, …, i_j) 
_j<t<n (i_n-i_t)   (1≤ j ≤ n-2),



  * m_ D_i_j,E_i_j = ( (i_1, …, i_j-1) 

_j< l≤ n (i_l-i_j)  ;_0≤ k  <j (i_j-i_k)  
  (i_j+1, …, i_n)  )    (1≤ j≤
  n-1),






  * m_F_a,D_i_j =
  1/2∑_rφ(r) ·(_i_l,
    i_k∉a (| i_l-i_k|)  ;
  _i_l, i_k∈ a∖{i_j} (|
  i_l-i_k|))   where a = {i_l| i_l ≡ i_j  r},
             r∈ induces the subset  and 2≤ || ≤ n.

(By convention, a gcd over an empty set of indices is taken to be 0.)
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Gröbner tropical secant graph for a projective monomial
    curve C parameterized by n coprime distinct integers is a
    weighted graph in ^n+1 whose cone from C gives the
    weighted Gröbner fan structure on Sec^1(C).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A ribbon is a connected skew shape that does not contain a 2 by 2
square of cells.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Signed Sets]
A signed set is a set A together with a decomposition A=A^+∪
A^- where A^+∩ A^-=∅. 
The members of A^+ are positive elements, those of
A^- are negative .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A configuration is a 3-tuple (F,label,col)
 where F is a 𝒪-border, wich is well labeled by
 label, and col is a coloring of G_ℓ compatible with (F,label).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If p_j,m,n is defined as in Theorem <ref> and c_j,m,n represents the number of ways of choosing m disjoint bad components of K_N^-C_n where the number of vertices of the bad components is j, then C^k(K_N^-C_n) = j=0n∑m=0j∑(-1)^mc_j,m,n· S(N-j,k-m) and c_j,m,n = p_j,m,n-1 + 2 · p_j-2,m-1,n-2 + 3 · p_j-3,m-1,n-3 for j and n ≥ 3, and n ≠j for n ∈{3,4}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a compactification V of U, the variety of critical points of U is defined to be the closure 

    𝔛_V(U):=𝔛^∘(U)⊆ V ×ℙ(W).

We denote the variety of critical points by 𝔛(U) when there is no danger of confusion.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A triple of very affine varieties is a collection of the form (U,U_0,U_1).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The CSM class is the unique natural transformation

    c_SM : C ⟶ A_*

such that c_SM(1_X) = c(TX) ∩ [X] when X is smooth and complete.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that U is schön if the multiplication is smooth for some tropical compactification of U.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that an –set X_ is finitely generated in degree ≥ d if there is a finite subset of _i=0^d X_i which is not contained in any proper –subset of X_. 
We say that X_ is finitely generated if it is finitely generated in some degree.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For any –set X_, the linearization k X_ is the –module where (kX_)_n is the free k–vector space on the set X_n, with the obvious maps.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given an action τ of period n on a set of objects S and a statistic ξ :S→, where
 is any field, we call ξ birationally homomesic 
if the value of ∏_k=0^n-1ξ (τ^k(s)) is a constant c∈,
independent of s.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let d ≥ 1 be a dimension.  An algebraic set in ^d is any set of the form

    { x ∈^d: P_1(x) =…=P_m(x) = 0}

where P_1,…,P_m: ^d → are polynomials.  If one can take m=1, we call the algebraic set a hypersurface .  An algebraic set is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union of two strictly smaller algebraic sets.  An irreducible algebraic set will be referred to as an algebraic variety , or variety for short.

The intersection of any subset of ^d with ^d will be referred to as the real points of that subset.  A real algebraic variety is the real points V_ of a complex algebraic variety V.[Strictly speaking, because two different complex varieties may have the same real points, a real algebraic variety should really be viewed as a pair (V_,V) rather than just the set V_; however, we will abuse notation and identify a real algebraic variety with the set V_ of real points.]

sentence:
[Algebraic sets]  Let d ≥ 1 be a dimension.  An algebraic set in ^d is any set of the form

    { x ∈^d: P_1(x) =…=P_m(x) = 0}

where P_1,…,P_m: ^d → are polynomials.  If one can take m=1, we call the algebraic set a hypersurface .  An algebraic set is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union of two strictly smaller algebraic sets.  An irreducible algebraic set will be referred to as an algebraic variety , or variety for short.

The intersection of any subset of ^d with ^d will be referred to as the real points of that subset.  A real algebraic variety is the real points V_ of a complex algebraic variety V.[Strictly speaking, because two different complex varieties may have the same real points, a real algebraic variety should really be viewed as a pair (V_,V) rather than just the set V_; however, we will abuse notation and identify a real algebraic variety with the set V_ of real points.]

sentence:
Suppose (,) has the Null Tangle Property and let T be any tagged triangulation of (,).
Then  

  * The fan _(T) is the rational part of the mutation fan _B(T).  In particular:  

  * The support of _(T) contains ^n.  

  * Every rational cone in _B(T) 
is a cone in _(T).

  * The full-dimensional cones in _B(T) are exactly the full-dimensional cones in _(T).

  * Every codimension-1 cone in _(T) is a cone in _B(T). 

  * The -vector fan of the transpose B(T)^T is the set of all cones C_Λ such that Λ is a collection of pairwise compatible non-closed allowable curves.  (This statement must be modified if (,) is a marked surface without boundary having exactly one puncture, but we will not need that case here.)

  * The shear coordinates of allowable curves constitute universal geometric coefficients for B(T).

sentence:
Let Σ be a set (of “signs”). We say that π is a Σ-labeled partition of [[n]] if π is a partition of [[n]] labeled by Σ such that 
  
  
  * for every R ∈π, R∈π, and 
  
  * S=S if and only if S∈π is signed. 
  
  We will write this as follows:
  
    π = S_σ_1|⋯| S_σ_l| R_1 |R_1|⋯| R_k |R_k.

  Here the signed blocks are denoted by S, and carry the sign σ_i ∈Σ as an index. The unsigned blocks are denoted by R_i. We call Σ(π):={σ_1, …, σ_l } the sign of π.

sentence:
Let r≥ 0 be an integer.
  An increasing ordered tree is r-flourishing if the root has at least r children, and none of the first r children of the root is a leaf.
  See Figure <ref> for some examples.

sentence:
Let q≥ 0 be an integer. A q-blooming tree on n+1 nodes is an increasing ordered tree on n+1 nodes, with q extra indistinguishable unlabeled nodes (called blooms ) appended to the root.
  The only thing that matters about blooms is their position in the total order of the children of the root.
  See Figure <ref> for some examples.

sentence: Let λ= max(λ(0.3, 0.6, 2), e^2 ). A component shall be deemed small if it has diameter less than λ√(log n). Two small components shall be deemed close if they contain two points lying at a distance less than 8λ√(log n) from one another.

sentence:

Given x ∈Γ, let the local counting function Y(x)=Y_n,k(x) be the random variable taking the value 1 if there is a connected component H in V_n,k(x) such that H has diameter less than λ√(log n) and x is the (almost surely unique) member of ℤ^2 closest to the (almost surely unique) bottom-most vertex of H.

sentence:
We set 𝒟 to be a collection of bad events . Let 𝒟 be the event that any of the following occur:


  * S_n,k contains an edge of length at least λ√(log n)

  * there is some x ∈Γ for which V_n,k(x) contains an edge of length at least λ√(log n)

  * S_n,k contains at least two components of diameter at least λ√(log n)

  * S_n,k contains a small component H such that the point of ℤ^2 closest to the bottom-most vertex of H does not lie in Γ

  * S_n,k contains at least two components of diameter less than λ√(log n) lying within distance less than 8λ√(log n) of each other


  * S_n,k contains a small component H such that there is more than one element of ℤ^2 closest to a bottom-most vertex of H

  * there is some x∈Γ for which V_n,k(x) contains a small component H such that there is more than one element of ℤ^2 closest to a bottom-most vertex of H.

sentence:
Let D be a directed graph. Suppose that each vertex v is assigned with a list L(v) of four colors. Suppose further that each color x in L(v) is assigned with a real number r_v(x), the rank of color x in L(v). Assume that for every vertex v, the color ranks r_v(x) satisfy the following condition: 

    ∗∑_x∈ L(v)r_v(x) ≥ 2d^+(v).

Then there is a vertex coloring of D from lists L(v) satisfying the following constraint: If x is a color assigned to v, then the number of out-neighbors of v in color x is at most r_v(x).

sentence:
Let e ≠ g ∈ G.


  * We denote by F_g the smallest face of P(G) containing the identity e and g.

  * We denote by g = z_1 ∘⋯∘ z_r the unique disjoint cycle decomposition of g in S_n, i.e., z_1, …, z_r are cycles with pairwise 
disjoint support, and g = z_1 ⋯ z_r.

  * Let g = z_1 ∘⋯∘ z_r. For h ∈ S_n we say h is a subelement of g (we write h ≼ g), 
if there is a set I ⊆ [r] such that h = ∏_i ∈ I z_i.

  * g is called indecomposable in G, if e and g are the only subelements of g in G.
