sentence:
If real vector α∈ℝ^n and non-negative vector μ∈ℝ^n_+ are chosen such that weights μ are monotone in degrees d and
matrix (α)+μμ^⊤ - A is positive semidefinite, then for any tree
T∈𝒯(d)

    C_A(T)≥
    LB(α,μ):=n-1/2∑_i,j=1^nμ_ij-(n-1/2∑_i=1^n
    α_i+μ^⊤ P(H(μ))μ),

where H(μ)∈ℋ(μ,d) is a Huffman tree for weight sequence μ. In
other words, LB(α,μ) is the lower bound estimate for the problem
(<ref>).


Since matrices P(T) and (α)+μμ^⊤ - A are positive semidefinite
and diagonal elements of P(T) are equal to n-1/2,

    C_A(T)= D(T)A=n-1/2∑_i,j=1^nμ_ij- P(T)A ≥
    ≥n-1/2∑_i,j=1^nμ_ij-n-1/2∑_i=1^n α_i -μ^⊤
    P(T)μ =
    
    
    =n-1/2∑_i,j=1^n(μ_ij-μ_iμ_j)-n-1/2∑_i=1^n
    α_i+2WI_μ(T).


From Theorem <ref> we know that WI_μ(T)≥ WI_μ(H(μ)).
Hence,

    C_A(T)≥n-1/2∑_i,j=1^n(μ_ij-μ_iμ_j)-n-1/2∑_i=1^n α_i+2WI_μ(H(μ))=
    
    =n-1/2∑_i,j=1^nμ_ij-(n-1/2∑_i=1^n
    α_i+μ^⊤ P(H(μ))μ).

This completes the proof.

d_T(i)=2(n-1). The collection of trees over vertex set V is denoted with

d_i=2(n-1). Let 𝒯(d):={T∈𝒯(V): d_T=d} denote the
collection of trees with degree sequence d.

sentence: Let ℜ be a subset of F(𝒜). We say that 𝒜 is ℜ-generated if F(𝒜) is spanned by ℜ. If ℜ is the set of relations of length at most k+1 for some k≥ 2, then 𝒜 is called k-generated . 2-generated arrangements are also called 2-formal arrangements.

sentence: A  matrix A=(a_i,j)∈ M_m,n is stochastic if a_i,j≥ 0 for all i∈ [m], j∈ [n] and ∑_j=1^na_i,j=1 for all i∈ [m]. A  matrix A∈ M_n is doubly stochastic if a_i,j≥ 0 for all i, j∈ [n], ∑_j=1^na_i,j=1 for all i∈ [n], and  ∑_i=1^na_i,j=1 for all j∈ [n].

sentence:
Let c be a (k,d)-coloring of a signed graph (G,σ) in which colors x_0 and its inverse k-x_0 are missing.
Updating c at x_0 is defined as follows: if the color [x_0+d]_k appears in c, then recolor [x_0+d]_k by [x_0+d-1]_k; and meanwhile, if the color [k-x_0-d]_k appears in c, then recolor [k-x_0-d]_k by [k-x_0-d+1]_k. 
Let r be a positive integer.
Updating c at a sequence of colors x_0,[x_0+d]_k,…,[x_0+(r-1)d]_k is called updating c from x_0 by r steps . We also say that a function c' is obtained from c
by updating at x_0 (in r steps) if c' is the final function from V(G) to ℤ_k in this process.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: updating c from x_0 by r steps

sentence:
The function ϕ(s) is said to have a singularity of algebraic type
(λ,θ,ψ) at s_0 if a local expansion of the form
 
    ϕ(s) = (s-s_0)^-λψ((s-s_0)^θ)

holds in a slit neighborhood of s_0, where λ∈, (θ)>0, and

    ψ(s) = ∑_k≥0 p_k s^k

 is analytic at zero.

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph with n vertices and L_G its associated leaf function.
    The leaf word of G, denoted by Δ L_G, is the word on the alphabet ∪{} with i-th letter given by
    
    Δ L_G(i) = L_G(i+3) - L_G(i+2),

    for i = 1,2,…,n-3.
    We set L_G(i+3) - L_G(i+2) = whenever L_G(i+2) = -∞ or L_G(i+3) = -∞.

sentence:
[Leaf function, <cit.>]
    Given a finite graph G = (V,E), let 𝒯_G(i) be the family of all induced subtrees of G with exactly i vertices. The leaf function of G, denoted by L_G, is the function with domain {0,1,2,…,G} defined by
    
    L_G(i)=max{T : T∈𝒯_G(i)}.

    As is customary, we set max∅ = -∞.
    An induced subtree T of G with i vertices is called fully leafed when T = L_G(i).

sentence:
A caterpillar sequence S=(s_1,…,s_k) of length k is a sequence of k non negative integers such that s_1, s_k ≥ 1 and, if k = 1, then s_1 ≥ 2.
   
    The size S of S and its number of leaves S are respectively defined by
    
    S = k + ∑_i=1^k s_i  and S = ∑_i=1^k s_i.

   The reversal of S is the caterpillar sequence S = (s_k,…,s_1), that we also denote by Sab with the exponent notation for typographic reasons.
   We denote by  the set of all caterpillar sequences.

    lengths k and k' with 1≤ k'≤ k, we say that S' is a caterpillar subsequence of S, and we write S' ≼ S, if there exists an integer i∈{0,…,k-k'} such that
    
    (S')[j] ≤(S)[j+i],

sentence:
We define the reading caterpillar sequence (w) of a binary word w recursively on |w| as follows. The reading caterpillar sequence (ε) of the empty word is the sequence (2) corresponding to a simple chain on three vertices.
    Let ua be a binary word with u∈{0,1}^*,a∈{0,1} and let (u)=(r_1,…,r_k) be the reading caterpillar sequence of u. Then the reading caterpillar sequence of ua is
    
    (ua) = (u)♢ (1,1),    
    (u)♢ (3),

sentence:
[<cit.>]
    A binary word u on the alphabet {0,1} is called prefix normal if for any prefix p ∈(u) and any factor f ∈(u), the condition |p| = |f| implies |p|_1 ≥ |f|_1. We denote by  the set of prefix normal words.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A pure simplicial complex Δ 
is called vertex decomposable if


  * Δ is a simplex, or 

  * there is some vertex v ∈ V such that Δ∖ v and 
link_Δ(v) are vertex decomposable.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set V 
 with facets F_1, …, F_t. 
An s-colouring of Δ  is a partition of the vertices 
 V = V_1∪…∪ V_s (where the sets V_i are allowed to be empty) such that 
|F_i ∩ V_j| ≤ 1
for all 
1 ≤ i ≤ t, 1 ≤ j ≤ s.
We will sometimes write χ is an s-colouring of Δ
to mean χ is a specific partition of V that gives an s-colouring of Δ.
If there exists an s-colouring, we say that 
Δ is s-colourable .  
If Δ has dimension d-1, then we say that 
Δ is balanced if it is d-colourable.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
A pure d-dimensional simplicial complex Δ is shellable if there is an ordering F_1,…,F_s on the facets of Δ
such that for all 1 ≤ i <  j ≤ s there exists some v ∈ F_j ∖ F_i and some ℓ∈{1, …, j-1} with F_j ∖ F_ℓ = {v}.  Such an ordering on the facets is called a shelling order .
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Given a simplicial complex Δ on the vertex set
 {x_1, …, x_n}, the Stanley-Reisner ideal of Δ 
is the monomial ideal

    I_Δ = (x_i_1x_i_2⋯ x_i_s | {x_i_1, x_i_2, …, x_i_s}∉Δ)

in the ring S = k[x_1, …, x_n].  The quotient ring S/I_Δ is the Stanley-Reisner ring .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Suppose Δ = ⟨ F_1, …, F_s⟩ is a simplicial complex on the vertex set V.  We say that Δ has a facet restriction with respect to F if F is a facet of Δ such that 

    Δ |_V ∖ F = {F_1 ∖ F, …, F_s ∖ F}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: facet restriction with respect to F

sentence:
For any finite simple graph G = (V_G,E_G) the clique complex of G is the simplicial complex 

    Cl(G) = {C⊆ V  |  G |_C   }  .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex with vertex set V.  
We call v ∈ V a free vertex if v is contained in exactly one facet of Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be an abelian group with no elements of order 2. Then G ↛ (1)^⟨·⟩_2 (and a fortiori , G↛(κ)_2^⟨·⟩ for every nonzero cardinal κ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: Let R _2 be a Unique Factorization Domain (UFD)[That is, R is a commutative ring with unit, without zero divisors, where every element can be decomposed as a product of irreducible elements in a unique way (up to order and associates).]. Then for every free R-module M, we have that M ↛ (1)_2^ (and a fortiori , M↛(κ)_2^ for every positive κ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let the height h_J(p) of J at position p (0 ≤ p ≤ 2k + 1) be
the maximum value of 2k + 1 - a - b where (a, b) ∈ J and a - b = 2k + 2 - p.
This is well-defined for all proper, non-empty order ideals J of Q. Let the left height of J be the height of J at position 0, i.e., h_J(0). Let the right height of J be the height of J at position 2k + 1, i.e., h_J(2k+1). 

We say a proper, non-empty order ideal J of Q is balanced if the following holds.


  * h_J(0) < 0,

  * h_J(2k+1) ≥ 0,
 
  * |h_J(0)+h_J(2k+1)| = 1.

Note that h_J(0) is odd and h_J(2k+1) is even.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If D is a finite semifield, and 𝒟 is the set of all nonisomorphic semifields isotopic to D, then
	
    (|D|-1)^2=|At(D)|∑_E∈𝒟1/|Aut(E)|

	The sum of the right term will be called the Semifield/Automorphism (S/A) sum .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let H=(V,E) be a graph representing a Kotzig orbit. Let
S_(i,j) = ( s^(1)_(i,j),s^(2)_(i,j),…,s^(n)_(i,j)) be the event
at vertex (i,j)∈ V(H), where i = 1 … 2^n-1, j = 1 … 2^w_i - 1, and
s^(k)_(i,j)∈{I,x,x,y,
y,z,z}, for each k=1,2,…,n. Let |s^(k)_(i,j)⟩ be defined as follows:

    s^(k)_(i,j)   x   x   y   y   z   z   I
    |s^(k)_(i,j)⟩   |+⟩   |-⟩   |y_+⟩   |y_-⟩   |0⟩   |1⟩   |ψ⟩
    
    .

Here, |ψ⟩ is an arbitrary ray in ℂ^2 and |y_+⟩, |y_-⟩
are the eigenvectors of the Pauli matrix Y with eigenvalue +1 and -1, respectively.
The canonical orthogonal representation of H is the set of vectors
{|s_(i,j)⟩ :=|s^(1)_(i,j)⟩⊗ |s^(2)_(i,j)⟩⊗⋯⊗ |s^(n)_(i,j)⟩ :(i,j)∈ V(H)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Canonical orthogonal representation]
Let H=(V,E) be a graph representing a Kotzig orbit. Let
S_(i,j) = ( s^(1)_(i,j),s^(2)_(i,j),…,s^(n)_(i,j)) be the event
at vertex (i,j)∈ V(H), where i = 1 … 2^n-1, j = 1 … 2^w_i - 1, and
s^(k)_(i,j)∈{I,x,x,y,
y,z,z}, for each k=1,2,…,n. Let |s^(k)_(i,j)⟩ be defined as follows:

    s^(k)_(i,j)   x   x   y   y   z   z   I
    |s^(k)_(i,j)⟩   |+⟩   |-⟩   |y_+⟩   |y_-⟩   |0⟩   |1⟩   |ψ⟩
    
    .

Here, |ψ⟩ is an arbitrary ray in ℂ^2 and |y_+⟩, |y_-⟩
are the eigenvectors of the Pauli matrix Y with eigenvalue +1 and -1, respectively.
The canonical orthogonal representation of H is the set of vectors
{|s_(i,j)⟩ :=|s^(1)_(i,j)⟩⊗ |s^(2)_(i,j)⟩⊗⋯⊗ |s^(n)_(i,j)⟩ :(i,j)∈ V(H)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Schur polynomial s_λ(x_1,…,x_n) is given by
  
    s_λ(x_1,…,x_n) = ∑_T ∈_n(λ) x^(T),

  where x^a is the monomial x_1^a_1⋯ x_n^a_n.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  The fundamental quasisymmetric polynomial F_α(x_1,…,x_n) is given by
  
    F_α(x_1,…,x_n) = ∑_β refines α M_β(x_1,…,x_n) .
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A semistandard Young tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if for all i>1, the leftmost occurrence of i lies weakly left of some i-1. Let _n(λ) denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi tableaux with image in [n].
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Define the destandardization of T , denoted by (T), to be the tableau constructed as follows. If the leftmost i lies strictly right of the rightmost i-1, then decrement every i to i-1. Repeat until no i satisfies the condition.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  For w a permutation with no descents at or beyond n, the Schubert polynomial _w = _w(x_1,…,x_n) is given by
  
    _w = ∑_P ∈(w) x^(P),

  where x^a is the monomial x_1^a_1⋯ x_n^a_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a weak composition a of length n, define the monomial slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b) = (a) x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n,

  where the sum is over all compositions b obtained by shifting the entries of a to the left while preserving their relative order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a weak composition a of length n, define the fundamental slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b)  refines (a) x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n,

  where the sum is over all compositions b obtained by shifting or splitting the entries of a to the left while preserving their relative order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A pipe dream is quasi-Yamanouchi if, for every i, the westernmost  in row i is in the first column or lies weakly west of some  in the i+1st row. Let (w) denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi pipe dreams of shape w.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For P∈(w), the destandardization of P , denoted by (P), is the pipe dream constructed from P as follows. For each row, say i-1, with no  in the first column, if every  in row i-1 lies strictly east of every  in row i, then move every  in row i-1 northwest one position. Repeat until no such row exists.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  For w a permutation, the Stanley symmetric function of w , denoted by _w, is
  
    _w(X) = ∑_σ∈(w) F_(σ)(X),

  where (σ) is the descent composition of the reversed sequence of indices of σ, i.e. (s_i_ℓ⋯ s_i_1) = (i_1,…,i_ℓ).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For P ∈(w), the standardization of P , denoted by (P), is the decomposition obtained by reading the 's of P from left to right, top to bottom, and recording the cross in position (i,j) as s_i+j-1.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  The quasi-shuffle product of weak compositions α and β, denoted by αβ, is defined recursively by
  
    α∅    =    ∅α = α, 
    αβ    =    α_1 (α_2⋯α_ℓ(α)β) + β_1 (αβ_2⋯β_ℓ(β)) + [α_1,β_1] (α_2⋯α_ℓ(α)β_2⋯β_ℓ(β)),

  where ∅ is the empty composition, and [α_1,β_1] denotes the integer α_1+β_1.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let a,b be weak compositions of length n. Let α = (a) and β=(b). The quasi-shuffle set of a and b , denoted by (a,b), is given by
  
    (a,b) = { (γ_a, γ_b) |[ (γ_a)=(a),   γ_a ≥ a,; (γ_b)=(b),   γ_b ≥ b, ] (γ_a+γ_b)_i>0  i }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: quasi-shuffle set of a and b

sentence:
For weak compositions a and b of length n, define the quasi-slide product of a and b , denoted by a  b, to be the formal sum of weak compositions defined by
  
    a  b = ∑_(γ_a,γ_b) ∈(a,b)_(a,b)(γ_a,γ_b),

  where _(a,b)(γ_a,γ_b) is the unique composition c with (c)= γ_a+γ_b such that c_a ≥ a and c_b ≥ b and if (d) = γ_a+γ_b satisfies d_a ≥ a and d_b ≥ b, then d ≥ c.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: quasi-slide product of a and b

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  The shuffle product of words A and B, denoted by A  B, is defined recursively by
  
    A ∅    =    ∅ A = {A}, 
    
        A  B     =    {A_1 (A_2 ⋯ A_ℓ(A) B)}∪{B_1 (A  B_2 ⋯ B_ℓ(B))},

  where ∅ is the empty word.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let a,b be weak compositions of length n. Let A and B be the words defined by A = (2n-1)^a_1⋯ (3)^a_n-1 (1)^a_n and B = (2n)^b_1⋯ (4)^b_n-1 (2)^b_n. Define the shuffle set of a and b , denoted by (a,b), by
  
    (a,b) = { C ∈ A  B |_A(C) ≥ a _B(B) ≥ b },

  where _A(C)_i (respectively _B(C)_i) is the number of letters from A (respectively B) in the ith increasing run of C.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: shuffle set of a and b

sentence:
For weak compositions a,b of length n, define the slide product of a and b , denoted by a  b, to be the formal sum
  
    a  b =  ∑_C ∈(a,b)(_(a,b)(C))

  where _(a,b)(C) is the unique element of 0^n-ℓ((C)) C such that _A(_(a,b)(C)) ≥ a and _B(_(a,b)(C)) ≥ b and if D ∈ 0^n-ℓ C satisfies _A(D) ≥ a and _B(D) ≥ b, then (D) ≥(_(a,b)(C)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: slide product of a and b

sentence:
Let S be a closed surface and let G^+ and G^- be two graphs embedded in it. We say that (G^+,G^-) is a
normal pair of graphs if G^+ and G^- intersect only in the interior of edges,
each edge of one intersects each edge of the other at most once, and all the intersections are transversal.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that (G^+,G^-) form a strongly normal pair of graphs if they
are a normal pair of graphs and in addition the intersection of an edge
of G^+ with the interior of a face of G^- has at most one component (and
also with the roles of G^+ and G^- interchanged).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A path in H_0 is well-formed if when traversing C we always turn right when passing from a negative to a positive edge and turn left when passing from a positive to a negative edge. (The path is allowed to “go straight” at some of the vertices, meaning that it keeps walking along the same edge of G^+ or G^-). A well-formed loop is a cycle with the same property except 
(perhaps) at its base vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[PP]
    A parallelogram polyomino is a maximal set of cells of ℤ×ℤ, defined up translation, contained in between two paths
    with North and East steps that intersect only at their starting and ending
    points.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[PPP]


A periodic parallelogram polyomino is a PP with an admissible marked
cell in the first column. A cell is called admissible if its height is less or
equal to the size of the last column.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A degenerated periodic parallelogram polyomino is a PPP of rectangular
shape such that the marked cell is the topmost cell of the first column.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The rotation induces an action of the group G on the set of . The
    orbits of this action will be called strips . Since the
    semi-perimeter and the intrinsic thickness are invariant by rotation, we
    extend the two statistics to strips.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The mixing time τ(ε) of a Markov chain P with
stationary distribution U is given by


    τ(ε)
    = min{T∀ u,v∈Ω, (1-ε)U(v) ≤
    P^T(u,v) ≤(1+ε)U(v)} .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let us refer to the three types of moves that the Pollard Rho random
walk makes,
namely (u, u+1), (u,u+x) and (u, 2u) as moves of Type 1, Type 2 and
Type 3,
respectively. In general, let the random walk be denoted by Y_0, Y_1,
Y_2, …  with
Y_t indicating the position of the walk (modulo N) at time t≥
0. Let T_1 be the first
time that the walk makes a move of Type 3.
Let b_1 = Y_T_1 - 1 - Y_T_0 (i.e., the ground covered, modulo
N, only using
consecutive moves of Types 1 and 2). More generally, let T_i be the
first time, since T_i-1, that a move of Type 3 happens, and set
b_i = Y_T_i - 1 - Y_T_i-1. Then the block walk 𝖡 is
the walk X_s = Y_T_s = 2^s Y_T_0 + 2∑_i=1^s 2^s-ib_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A Dyck path of order n is a path in the n × n lattice from (0,0) to (n,n) that consists of n unit-length north steps and n unit-length east steps, which stays weakly above the line y=x.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A parking function of order n is a Dyck path of order n such that each north step has a label, called a car , written in the square to its immediate right. The cars are 1, 2, … , n, each occurring exactly once, and cars in the same column increase from bottom to top. We denote the set of all parking functions of order n by .

sentence:
Let X_n = {x_1, x_2, … ,x_n} and Y_n = {y_1, y_2, … ,y_n}. Then the space of diagonal harmonics , DH_n, is the vector space of polynomials in these variables, f(X_n, Y_n), which satisfy

    ∂ ^a _x_1∂ ^b _y_1 f(X_n, Y_n) + ∂ ^a _x_2∂ ^b _y_2 f(X_n, Y_n) + ⋯ + ∂ ^a _x_n∂ ^b _y_n f(X_n, Y_n) = 0
for all a,b≥ 0 and a+b>0. That is, 

    DH_n = { f(X_n, Y_n) ∈ℂ [X_n, Y_n] ∑ _i=1^n∂ ^a _x_i∂ ^b _y_i f(X_n, Y_n) = 0, ∀ a,b≥ 0, a+b>0}.

sentence: [Dyck path] A Dyck path of order n is a path in the n × n lattice from (0,0) to (n,n) that consists of n unit-length north steps and n unit-length east steps, which stays weakly above the line y=x.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [parking function] A parking function of order n is a Dyck path of order n such that each north step has a label, called a car , written in the square to its immediate right. The cars are 1, 2, … , n, each occurring exactly once, and cars in the same column increase from bottom to top. We denote the set of all parking functions of order n by .

sentence: [] If π is a parking function, then its area is the number of complete squares between the Dyck path of π and y=x, denoted by (π).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]  Consider a parking function π, and a pair of cars {c_1, c_2} in it.


  * If the cars c_1, c_2 are in the same diagonal (that is, their squares are the same distance from y=x) with the larger car occurring further right, then {c_1, c_2} is a primary diagonal inversion . Let ^pri(π) be the set of all such pairs.

  * If the cars c_1, c_2 are in adjacent diagonals with the larger car occurring in the higher diagonal (that is, its square is distance 1 further from y=x than that of the smaller car) and further left, then {c_1, c_2} is a secondary diagonal inversion . Let ^sec(π) be the set of all such pairs.

Then

    (π) = | ^pri(π) | + | ^sec(π) |.

sentence: [] If π is a parking function, then its word is the permutation in one-line notation obtained by reading cars from the diagonal furthest from y=x to the diagonal y=x, and within a diagonal reading from right to left. We denote this by (π).

[space of diagonal harmonics]
Let X_n = {x_1, x_2, … ,x_n} and Y_n = {y_1, y_2, … ,y_n}. Then the space of diagonal harmonics , DH_n, is the vector space of polynomials in these variables, f(X_n, Y_n), which satisfy

    ∂ ^a _x_1∂ ^b _y_1 f(X_n, Y_n) + ∂ ^a _x_2∂ ^b _y_2 f(X_n, Y_n) + ⋯ + ∂ ^a _x_n∂ ^b _y_n f(X_n, Y_n) = 0
for all a,b≥ 0 and a+b>0. That is, 

    DH_n = { f(X_n, Y_n) ∈ℂ [X_n, Y_n] ∑ _i=1^n∂ ^a _x_i∂ ^b _y_i f(X_n, Y_n) = 0, ∀ a,b≥ 0, a+b>0}.

    (π) = (i_2-i_1)(i_3-i_2)⋯(n+1-i_k).

sentence: The topograph is the graph whose set of vertices is all triples of pairwise -distinct points, with the stipulation that two such triples are connected by an edge whenever they have a pair of elements in common.

sentence:
[ Relative orientation ]
Given a planar embedding G̃_j 
of an ordinary tile G_j, we define the relative orientation 
rel(G̃_j, T^∘) 
of G̃_j with respect to T^∘ 
to be ± 1, based on whether its triangles agree or disagree in orientation with those of T^∘.

sentence:
[ Crossing Monomial ]
If  is an ordinary arc and  τ_i_1, τ_i_2,…, τ_i_d
is the sequence of arcs in T^∘ which  crosses, we define the crossing monomial of γ with respect to T^∘ to be

    cross(T^∘, γ) = ∏_j=1^d x_τ_i_j.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Perfect matchings and weights ]
A perfect matching of a graph G is a subset P of the 
edges of G such that
each vertex of G is incident to exactly one edge of P. 
If the edges of  a perfect matching P of  
G_T^∘, are labeled τ_j_1,…,τ_j_r, then 
we define the weight x(P) of P to be 
x_τ_j_1… x_τ_j_r.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Minimal and Maximal Matchings ]  
By induction on the number of tiles it is easy to see that 
G_T^∘,  
has  precisely two perfect matchings which we call
the minimal matching P_-=P_-(G_T^∘,) and 
the maximal matching P_+
=P_+(G_T^∘,), 
which contain only boundary edges.
To distinguish them, 
if  rel(G̃_1,T^∘)=1 (respectively, -1),
we define 
e_1 and e_2 to be the two edges of 
G_T^∘, which lie in the counterclockwise 
(respectively, clockwise) direction from 
the diagonal of G̃_1.  Then  P_- is defined as
the unique matching which contains only boundary 
edges and does not contain edges e_1 or e_2.  P_+
is the other matching with only boundary edges.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Height Monomial and Specialized Height Monomial ]  Let T^∘ = {τ_1,τ_2,…, τ_n} be an ideal triangulation of (S,M) and γ be an ordinary arc of (S,M).  By Lemma <ref>, for any perfect matching P
of G_T^∘,, P ⊖ P_- encloses the union of tiles ∪_j∈ J G_i_j.  
We  define the height monomial h(P) of P by

    h(P) = ∏_k=1^n h_τ_k^m_k,

where m_k is the number of tiles in ∪_j∈ J G_i_j whose
diagonal is labeled τ_k.


We  define the specialized height monomial y(P) of P to be
the specialization Φ(h(P)), where Φ is defined below. 

    Φ(h_τ_i)    =   {[      y_τ_i           ;           ; y_ry_r^(p)           ;           ;    y_r^(p)            ].

sentence:
[ Crossing monomials for tagged arcs with notches ]
If p is a puncture, and ^(p) is a tagged arc with a notch at p but tagged plain at its other end, we define the associated crossing monomial as 
    cross(T^∘,^(p)) =cross(T^∘,)/cross(T^∘,) = 
    cross(T^∘,γ) ∏_τ x_τ,

where the product is over all ends of arcs τ of  T^∘ that are incident to p.
If p and q are punctures and ^(pq) is a tagged arc with a notch at p and q, we define the associated crossing monomial as

    cross(T^∘,^(pq)) =cross(T^∘,)  cross(T^∘,) /cross(T^∘,)^3 = 
    cross(T^∘,γ) ∏_τ x_τ,
 where the 
product is
over all ends of arcs τ  that are incident to p or q.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Crossing monomials for tagged arcs with notches

sentence:
[ γ-symmetric matching ]
Having fixed an ideal triangulation T^∘ and an ordinary arc γ between p and q,
we call a perfect matching P of G_T^∘, -symmetric 
if the restrictions of P to the two ends satisfy P|_H_T^∘,γ_p,1≅ P|_H_T^∘,γ_p,2.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Weight and Height Monomials of a γ-symmetric matching ]
Fix a γ-symmetric matching P of G_T^∘,.  By Lemma <ref>, 
P restricts to a perfect matching of (without loss of generality) G_T^∘,γ_p,1.  
Therefore the following definitions of weight and (specialized) height monomials x(P) 
and y(P) are well-defined:


    x(P) = x(P)/x(P|_G_T^∘,,1),  y(P) = y(P)/y(P|_G_T^∘,,1).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Weight and Height Monomials of a γ-symmetric matching

sentence:
[ Symmetric completion ] Fix a perfect matching P of G_T^∘,ℓ_p, and by Lemma <ref>, assume without loss of generality that P restricts to a perfect matching on G_T^∘,γ_p,1.
Therefore P also restricts to a perfect matching on the complement, graph
G_ζ^(1).

We define the symmetric completion P=P|_G_ζ^(1) of P|_G_ζ^(1) to be the unique extension of P|_G_ζ^(1) to G_T^∘,ℓ_p such that P|_H_T^∘,γ_p,1≅P|_H_T^∘,γ_p,2.  
(Note that after adding edges to H_T^∘,γ_p,1, only vertex v_1 is not covered.  We 
add an edge incident to v_1 based on whether the edge incident to w_1 labeled τ_i_d-1
is included so far.)  
It follows from this construction that the restriction P|_G_T^∘,_p,1 is a perfect matching.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Augmentation ]
Fix a bordered surface (S,M), an ideal triangulation T^∘ of S,
a puncture p, and a loop ρ based at p with a choice of
orientation.
Let Δ be the first triangle of T^∘ which ρ crosses.
We assume that Δ is not self-folded, so we
can denote the arcs of Δ by a, b and c (in clockwise order),
with a and c incident to p, a and b incident to a marked
point u, and b and c incident to a marked point v.
We then define the
augmented bordered surface (S,M) by
adding a single puncture q to (S,M), placing it inside Δ.
And we construct the
augmented triangulation T^∘
from T^∘ by adding three new arcs inside
Δ: an arc â from q to u,
an arc ĉ from q to v, and an arc b̂ from u to v
(so that b̂ and b form a bigon with the puncture q
inside).    See Figure <ref>.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ The cluster algebra element corresponding to a singly-notched loop ]

Fix a bordered surface (S,M) and a tagged triangulation
T = ι(T^∘) corresponding to an ideal
triangulation T^∘, and
let  be the corresponding cluster algebra with
principal coefficients
with respect to T.
Let ρ be an ordinary loop based at p,
with a choice of orientation,
and let ρ^(p) denote the “tagged arc" obtained from ρ by
notching at the final end of ρ.
We represent this “tagged arc" by the curve (with a self-intersection) ℓ_p  obtained by
following the loop ρ along its orientation, but then looping around
the puncture p and doubling back, again following ρ.
See Figure <ref>.
Let G_T^∘, ℓ_p be the graph associated to ℓ_p
in Section <ref>.
Then we define x_ρ^(p)  to be

    1/cross(T^∘,ρ^(p))∑_P x(P) y(P),
 where the sum is over all
ρ-symmetric matchings P of G_T^∘,ℓ_p.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: The cluster algebra element corresponding to a singly-notched loop

sentence:
A function v→ satisfying v(∅)=0 is a (coalitional) game . A game v is called
   
   	
  * supermodular if 
   	v(A∪ B) + v(A∩ B) ≥ v(A) + v(B),
	
  * modular if v(A∪ B) + v(A∩ B) = v(A) + v(B),
	
  * monotone if v(A)≤ v(B) whenever A⊆ B,
	
  * nonnegative if v(A)≥ 0,
   
   for all A,B∈.

sentence:
A game v∈ G() is said to be 0-normalized if 
 
    v̂(A)=0,  for all A∈.

  Let G^⋆() be the set of all 0-normalized games on .

sentence:
<cit.> For a graph G with vertex set V={v_1, v_2, …, v_N} and edge set E, the chromatic symmetric function is defined to be

    X_G = ∑ _κ x_κ(v_1)x_κ(v_2)⋯ x_κ(v_N)

where the sum is over all proper colourings κ of G. If G=∅ then X_G=1.

word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let L be a (p, q)-leaper with p + q odd, C a cycle of L within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard, M the canonical second leaper associated with C, D the canonical second leaper cycle of M over the squares of C, and 4μ the length of both C and D.

Impose orientations on C and D. Given a square a of D, let the arc from a in C point to b and the D-displacement of a be the number of steps along D that lead from a to b.

Then the multiset of all D-displacements consists of all integers between μ and 3μ congruent to α modulo four, each occurring precisely eight times, where α = 1 or α = 3 depending on the orientations of C and D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
In the setting of Theorem <ref>, given a square c of C, let the arc from c in D point to d and the C-displacement of c be the number of steps along C that lead from c to d.

Then the multiset of all C-displacements coincides with the multiset of all D-displacements.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n be a positive integer and L a skew (p, q)-leaper with p < q. Then the leaper graph of L over W_n(L) is trivial and the direction graph extracted from it depends only on n. We refer to this direction graph as the pinwheel direction graph W_n of order n.

(The above continues to apply to non-skew leapers L in the sense that the leaper graph of L over W_n(L) is an instantiation of W_n.)

The pinwheel direction graph of order n is a dual direction graph of complement π_Pinwheel(W_n) when n is odd, where 
    π_Pinwheel = ([        ;         ])
 is the equivalence permutation induced by the unit 2 × 2 matrix and ( [  0  1; -1  0 ]), and π_Reflect∘π_Pinwheel(W_n) when n is even, and duality matrix A^Pinwheel_n.

sentence:
Let n and d be positive integers, L a (p, q)-leaper with p ≠ 0 and p < q, and M an (r, s)-leaper with 
    ([ r; s ]) = A^Pinwheel_n ([ p; q ]).


Then the expanded pinwheel board of order n and margin d for L is dual with respect to L and M.

Furthermore, the leaper graph of L over W_n, d(L) is trivial and the direction graph extracted from it depends only on n and d. We refer to this direction graph as the expanded pinwheel direction graph W_n, d of order n and margin d. It is a dual direction graph of complement π_Pinwheel(W_n, d) when n is odd and π_Reflect∘π_Pinwheel(W_n, d) when n is even, and duality matrix A^Pinwheel_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A regular chessboard is a rectangular grid of unit squares. A generalized chessboard is a set of unit squares in the plane, with sides parallel to the coordinate axes, obtained from each other by means of integer translations.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let p and q be nonnegative integers, at least one of them positive. A (p, q)-leaper L is a fairy chess piece that, from a square a, can move to any of the squares a + (± p, ± q) or a + (± q, ± p).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The leaper graph of a leaper L over a board B is the graph whose vertices are the squares of B and whose edges join the pairs of squares of B that are joined by a move of L.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A leaper L is free over a board B if the leaper graph of L over B is connected.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An open tour of a leaper L over a board B is a Hamiltonian path in the leaper graph of L over B. A closed tour of L over B is a Hamiltonian cycle in the leaper graph of L over B.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A (p, q)-leaper L is orthogonal if p = 0 or q = 0, diagonal if p = q, and skew if p ≠ 0, q ≠ 0, and p ≠ q.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A (p, q)-leaper L is basic if p + q is odd and p and q are relatively prime.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An (m, n)-frame F, m < n, is an (m + n) × (m + n) chessboard with an (n - m) × (n - m) hole in the center. The sections of F, F_, F_, …, F_ as in Figure <ref>, are the eight rectangular subboards that F is dissected into when the sides of the central hole are extended.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cycle D of a leaper M within a frame F is proper if D is the concatenation of eight disjoint nonempty paths, 
    D = a^a^… a^,
 such that, for all directions i, a^i lies within F_i and the L_F-translation that maps F_i ∪ F_i + 1 onto F_-(i + 1)∪ F_-i also maps a^ia^i + 1 onto -a^-(i + 1)-a^-i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be an (m, n)-frame, m < n, and H an (m, 2m + n)-frame. Place F and H so that their centers coincide. (Or, equivalently, so that the outer contour of F coincides with the inner contour of H.) We define the transformation f, lifting F to H, as follows.

An f-translation is any of the eight translations corresponding to a move of a (0, m + n)-leaper or an (m, m)-leaper. Given a direction i, we write v^f_i for the f-translation pointing in direction i. For instance, v^f_ = (m + n, 0) and v^f_ = (m, m).

Let S be a subset of the squares of F. Then f(S) is a subset of the squares of H, the disjoint union of 
    (S + v^f_i) ∩ H_i
 when i ranges over , , …, .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let m < n, 3m ≥ n, and F be an (m, n)-frame. The shell of F, F^-, is the union of eight equal, symmetrically placed square subboards of F defined as follows.

When 2m ≥ n, F^- is the union of eight subboards of F of size (n - m) × (n - m), one in each corner and four adjacent by side to the central hole, as in Figure <ref>.

When 2m ≤ n ≤ 3m, F^- is the union of eight subboards of F of size (3m - n) × (3m - n), one in the middle of each outer side and four adjacent by corner to the central hole, as in Figure <ref>.

In both cases, the core of F, F^+, is F ∖ F^-.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be an (m, n)-frame, m < n, and H an (n, 2n - m)-frame. Place F and H so that their centers coincide. (Or, equivalently, so that their inner contours coincide.) We define the transformation g, lifting F to H, as follows.

A g-translation is any of the eight translations corresponding to a move of a (0, n - m)-leaper or an (n, n)-leaper. Given a direction i, we write v^g_i for the g-translation pointing in direction i. For instance, v^g_ = (n - m, 0) and v^f_ = (n, n).

Let S be a subset of the squares of F. Then g(S) is a subset of the core of H, the disjoint union of 
    (S + v^g_i) ∩ H_i
 when i ranges over , , …, .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be an (m, n)-frame, m < n, and H an (n, m + 2n)-frame. Place F and H so that their centers coincide. (Or, equivalently, so that the outer contour of F coincides with the inner contour of H.) We define the transformation h, lifting F to H, as follows.

An h-translation is any of the eight translations corresponding to a move of a (0, m + n)-leaper or an (n, n)-leaper. Given a direction i, we write v^h_i for the h-translation pointing in direction i. For instance, v^h_ = (m + n, 0) and v^h_ = (n, n).

Let S be a subset of the squares of F. Then h(S) is a subset of the core of H, the disjoint union of 
    (S + v^h_i) ∩ H_i
 when i ranges over , , …, .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The descent of a skew basic (p, q)-leaper L is the unique string e_1e_2… e_l, composed of the characters , , and , such that successively applying lifting transformations of types e_l, e_l - 1, …, e_1 to a (1, 2)-frame lifts it to a (p, q)-frame.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An even continued fraction is an expression of the form 
    [c_1±, c_2±, …, c_k] = c_1 ±1c_2 ±1⋱±1/c_k,
 where c_i is an even integer for all i, c_1 is nonnegative, and c_2, c_3, …, c_k are all positive.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The direction matrix of a move of a skew (p, q)-leaper L, p < q, of direction i from a square a to a square b = a + v is the unique matrix A_i out of the following eight, 
    A_   = ([ 0 1; 1 0 ]),     A_   = ([ 1 0; 0 1 ]),
     A_   = ([ -1  0;  0  1 ]),     A_   = ([  0 -1;  1  0 ]),
     A_   = ([  0 -1; -1  0 ]),     A_   = ([ -1  0;  0 -1 ]),
     A_   = ([  1  0;  0 -1 ]),     A_   = ([  0  1; -1  0 ]),
 such that 
    v^T = A_i([ p; q ]).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A direction graph is a symmetric directed graph Φ whose arcs are labeled with skew directions in such a way that the sum of the associated direction matrices over every simple cycle in Φ is the zero matrix.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A labeled oriented graph Ψ represents a direction graph Φ if Ψ is obtained from Φ by removing exactly one arc out of each symmetric pair.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A direction graph Φ is extracted from a leaper graph G of a skew leaper L if there exists a one-to-one mapping σ between the vertices of G and the vertices of Φ such that an L-move of direction i leads from a vertex a to a vertex b in G if and only if an arc labeled i points from σ(a) to σ(b) in Φ.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A simple oriented cycle C of a skew leaper is trivial if the sum of the associated direction matrices over C is the zero matrix, and nontrivial otherwise. A simple cycle C of a skew leaper is trivial if any (or, equivalently, both) of its two orientations are, and nontrivial otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Φ be a direction graph and L a leaper. A graph G is an L-instantiation of Φ if the vertices of G are squares and there exists a mapping τ from the vertices of Φ to the vertices of G such that, for every arc in Φ pointing from x to y and labeled i, an L-move of direction i leads from τ(x) to τ(y).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Φ be a direction graph and x and y vertices in the same connected component of Φ. The distance from x to y in Φ is the sum of the associated direction matrices over any path from x to y in Φ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A direction graph Φ is coherent if, for every pair of vertices x and y in the same connected component of Φ, the distance from x to y in Φ equals the zero matrix if and only if x and y coincide, and a direction matrix if and only if x and y are joined by an arc.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A permutation π of the eight skew directions is an equivalence permutation if there exist two real-coefficient 2 × 2 matrices P and Q, inducing π, such that 
    A_π(i) = PA_iQ
 for all skew directions i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Two direction graphs Φ_1 and Φ_2 are equivalent if there exists an equivalence permutation π such that π(Φ_1) = Φ_2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let L be a skew basic (p, q)-leaper, C a cycle of L within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard, and e = e_1e_2… e_l a prefix  of the descent of L such that C is the product of successively applying lifting transformations of types e_l, e_l - 1, …, e_1 to a shell cycle. Then e is the descent of C.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: The fundamental direction cycle Φ(e) of descent e is the direction graph extracted from a cycle of descent e of a skew basic (p, q)-leaper within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard. Equivalently, the fundamental direction cycle Φ[c_1±, c_2±, …, c_k] of type [c_1±, c_2±,…, c_k] is the direction graph extracted from a cycle of type k of a skew basic (p, q)-leaper within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard, where [c_1±, c_2±, …, c_k] is the k-th convergent of the even continued fraction representation of q/p.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let L be a (p, q)-leaper with p + q odd and C a cycle of L within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard. Then the canonical second leaper associated with C and the canonical second leaper cycle over the squares of C are the ones constructed in the proof of Theorem <ref>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: canonical second leaper;canonical second leaper cycle

sentence: Let L be a skew basic (p, q)-leaper, D a canonical second leaper cycle of a skew basic canonical second leaper over the squares of a cycle of L within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard, and e = e_1e_2… e_l a prefix of the descent e_1e_2… e_m, l < m, of L such that D is the product of successively applying lifting transformations of types e_l, e_l - 1, …, e_1 to a shell canonical second leaper cycle. Then e is the descent of D and e_l + 1 is the origin of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let L be a skew basic (p, q)-leaper and D a canonical second leaper cycle of a skew basic canonical second leaper over the squares of a cycle of L within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard.

Impose an orientation on D and label every square a of D +_, +_, -_, or -_ as follows. Refer to the table 
    Label of a    Directions of moves to and from a
    +_   , , , 
    +_   , , , 
    -_   , , , 
    -_   , , ,
 if D is of origin , and to the table 
    Label of a    Directions of moves to and from a
    +_   , , , 
    +_   , , , 
    -_   , , , 
    -_   , , ,
 if D is of origin .

Then the cyclic string formed by the vertex labels of D is a signature of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: The second fundamental direction cycle Φ^II_o(e) of descent e and origin o is the direction graph extracted from a canonical second leaper cycle of descent e and origin o. Equivalently, the second fundamental direction cycle Φ^II_ϵ[c_1±, c_2±, …, c_k] of type [c_1±, c_2±,…, c_k] and sign ϵ is the direction graph extracted from a canonical second leaper cycle over the squares of a cycle of type k of a skew basic (p, q)-leaper within a (p + q) × (p + q) chessboard, where [c_1±, c_2±, …, c_k] is the k-th convergent of the even continued fraction representation of q/p and the sign following c_k in that representation is ϵ.

sentence: Let =, =, and =. The flip of a string e = e_1e_2… e_l composed of the characters , , and  is the string e_l e_l - 1…e_1.

sentence: A board B is dual with respect to two distinct leapers L and M if B contains more than one square and the leaper graphs of L and M over B are connected and isomorphic.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A direction graph Φ is dual if there exist a direction graph Φ', a complement of Φ, a one-to-one mapping η between the vertex sets of Φ and Φ', and a real-coefficient 2 × 2 duality matrix A_Dual, distinct from all direction matrices, such that the following conditions hold.

Both of Φ and Φ' are coherent and connected.

The unlabeled symmetric directed graphs obtained from Φ and Φ' by discarding all arc labels are isomorphic.

For every arc from η(a) to η(b) labeled i in Φ', the distance from a to b in Φ equals A_iA_Dual.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cycle D of a leaper M is (p, q)-perfect , p < q, if it admits a perfect partitioning into eight disjoint nonempty paths, 
    D = a^a^… a^,
 satisfying the following conditions.

Translation. 
    a^a^ + (-q, -p)    = -a^-a^
     a^a^ + (-p, -q)    = -a^-a^
     a^a^ + (p, -q)    = -a^-a^
     a^a^ + (q, -p)    = -a^-a^


Symmetry. For all directions i out of , , …, , a^i is of odd length, a^i_Mid lies on the ray α^i, and a^i is symmetric with respect to α^i. Furthermore, a 90^∘ rotation about O maps a^i onto a^i + 2.

Separation. For all directions i out of , , …, , the counterclockwise portion (a^i_Mid; a^i + 1_Mid) of D lies strictly inside the 45^∘ angle between the rays α^i and α^i + 1.

Simplicity. The broken line κ(D) is the contour of a simple polygon. In particular, D is a simple cycle.

Coherence. D is the leaper graph of M over the squares of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a (p, q)-perfect cycle of perfect partitioning D = a^a^… a^. Let 
    b^ = -a^-a^-a^ + (p + q, 0)
 and 
    b^ = a^ + (p, p),
 and define b^, b^, …, b^ symmetrically. Then the f-lift of D is the cycle f(D) = b^b^… b^ together with its partitioning into b^, b^, …, b^.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a (p, q)-perfect cycle of perfect partitioning D = a^a^… a^. Let 
    b^ = a^ + (q - p, 0)
 and 
    b^ = -a^-a^-a^ + (q, q),
 and define b^, b^, …, b^ symmetrically. Then the g-lift of D is the cycle g(D) = b^b^… b^ together with its partitioning into b^, b^, …, b^.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a (p, q)-perfect cycle of perfect partitioning D = a^a^… a^. Let 
    b^ = -a^-a^-a^-a^-a^ + (p + q, 0)
 and 
    b^ = a^a^a^ + (q, q),
 and define b^, b^, …, b^ symmetrically. Then the h-lift of D is the cycle h(D) = b^b^… b^ together with its partitioning into b^, b^, …, b^.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a (p, q)-perfect cycle of perfect partitioning D = a^a^… a^. Let 
    b^ = a^a^a^ + (p + q, 0)
 and 
    b^ = -a^-a^-a^-a^-a^ + (q, q),
 and define b^, b^, …, b^ symmetrically. Then the ħ-lift of D is the cycle ħ(D) = b^b^… b^ together with its partitioning into b^, b^, …, b^.

sentence:
Let M be an (r, s)-leaper, r ≤ s. Define the initial cycles of M as follows.

Provided that r ≠ 0, the initial cycle of M of type , D^M_, is the M-instantiation, centered at O, of the direction graph represented by the oriented cycle labeled . It contains the eight squares (r + s, 0), (r, r), (0, r + s), (-r, r), (-r - s, 0), (-r, -r), (0, -r - s), and (r, -r).

Provided that r ≠ s, the initial cycle of M of type , D^M_, is the M-instantiation, centered at O, of the direction graph represented by the oriented cycle labeled . It contains the eight squares (s - r, 0), (s, s), (0, s - r), (-s, s), (r - s, 0), (-s, -s), (0, r - s), and (s, -s).

The initial cycle of M of type , D^M_, is the M-instantiation, centered at O, of the direction graph represented by the oriented cycle labeled . It contains the eight squares (r + s, 0), (s, s), (0, r + s), (-s, s), (-r - s, 0), (-s, -s), (0, -r - s), and (s, -s).

sentence:
Let n be a positive integer and L a (p, q)-leaper with q ≠ 0.

Let N^I(L) be the net 
    N_2q(1/2(p + q), 1/2(p - q))
 and W^I_n(L) the board formed by all squares of N^I(L) whose centers lie on the boundary or in the interior of the rectangle R^I_n(L) bounded by 
    p ≤ x + y ≤ p + 2nq
 and 
    -(2n - 1)q ≤ y - x ≤ (2n - 1)q.


Let N^i(L), R^i_n(L), and W^i_n(L), for i = II, III, and IV, be the rotations of N^I(L), R^I_n(L), and W^I_n(L) by 90^∘, 180^∘, and 270^∘ counterclockwise about O.

Then the pinwheel board of order n for L, W_n(L), is the disjoint union of its four wings W^i_n(L), i = I, II, III, and IV.

sentence:
Let n be a positive integer, d a nonnegative integer, and L a (p, q)-leaper with q ≠ 0.

Let W^I_n, d(L) be the board formed by all squares of N^I(L) whose centers lie on the boundary or in the interior of the rectangle R^I_n, d(L) bounded by 
    p - 2dq ≤ x + y ≤ p + 2(n + d)q
 and 
    -(2n + 2d - 1)q ≤ y - x ≤ (2n + 2d - 1)q.


Let R^i_n, d(L) and W^i_n, d(L), for i = II, III, and IV, be the rotations of R^I_n, d(L) and W^I_n, d(L) by 90^∘, 180^∘, and 270^∘ counterclockwise about O.

Then the expanded pinwheel board of order n and margin d for L, W_n, d(L), is the (disjoint if p < q) union of its four wings W^i_n, d(L), i = I, II, III, and IV.

A graph G is called a generalized triangle factor if
		every connected component of G is a subgraph of a triangle, i.e.,
		a triangle, a path of length 2, an edge, or a vertex.

sentence:
Let X be a variety such that Pic(X)_Q is finite dimensional. Any k-algebra of the form

    Cox(X,(_1,_2,…,_s))=_def⊕_(m_1,m_2,…,m_s) ∈Z^s H^0(X,_1^⊗ m_1⊗_2^⊗ m_2⊗⋯⊗_s^⊗ m_s)

where _1,_2,…,_s are line bundles on X whose classes span Pic(X)_Q, will be called a Cox ring of X.

sentence:
Let  denote an ordered field with positive cone Π and suppose P_1,P_2∈Π[z] are monic, palindromic polynomials.  Denote by  the -subalgebra of  generated by the coefficients of P_1 and P_2.  Write (P_1,P_2) for the associated generalized cluster algebra over .
   
    
  * For each (a_1,a_2)∈^2 there exists a (unique) greedy element x[a_1,a_2]∈(P_1,P_2).
    
  * Each greedy element is an indecomposable positive element of (P_1,P_2).
    
  * The greedy elements x[a_1,a_2] for (a_1,a_2)∈^2 form a -basis of the generalized cluster algebra (P_1,P_2), which we call the greedy basis .
    
  * The greedy basis is independent of the choice of initial cluster.
    
  * The greedy basis contains all cluster monomials.

sentence:
A prepostive cone Π⊂∖{-1} satisfies the following closure properties:
  
   
  * For any a,b∈Π, we have a+b,ab∈Π;
   
  * For any a∈, we have a^2∈Π.
  
  A prepositive cone is called positive if =Π∪-Π.  A field  together with a positive cone Π is called an ordered field .  We define a total order ≤ on  by declaring for a,b∈ that a≤ b if b-a∈Π.

sentence: An nonzero element x∈(P_1,P_2) is called universally positive if its expression as a Laurent polynomial in any cluster {x_k,x_k+1} only contains nonnegative coefficients, i.e. x∈⋂_k∈_k^≥0.  A positive element is called indecomposable if it cannot be written as a sum of two nonzero positive elements.

Consider functions S_1:D_1→_≥0 and S_2:D_2→_≥0 which we call horizontal (resp. vertical ) gradings .  We call the pair (S_1,S_2) (graded) compatible if for every h∈ D_1 and v∈ D_2 there exists an edge e∈ D so that at least one of the following conditions on the gradings is satisfied:
  
    HGC   he is a proper subpath of hv   and   |(he)_2|=∑_h'∈(he)_1S_1(h');
    VGC   ev is a proper subpath of hv   and   |(ev)_1|=∑_v'∈(ev)_2S_2(v').

Write D(h;S_1)=he for this minimal path.  If there is no such subpath then we set (h;S_1)=D_2 and D(h;S_1)=D.  We define the shadow of S_1 as the union of local shadows: (S_1)=⋃_h∈ D_1(h;S_1).

Write D(v;S_2) for this minimal path ev.  If there is no such subpath then we set (v;S_2)=D_1 and D(v;S_2)=D.  We define the shadow of S_2 as the union of local shadows: (S_2)=⋃_v∈ D_2(v;S_2).

By considering the definition of compatibility one may alternatively described (S_1)⊂(S_1) as the subset consisting of all vertical edges v for which there exists a vertical grading S_2∈(S_1) with S_2(v)0.

sentence:
Let { x_1, x_2, …, x_n } be a set of Boolean variables. A 2-Xor expression is a finite
conjunction of clauses l ⊕ l', where l and l' are literals, i.e. they are elements of
{x_1, x_2, …, x_n, x̅_1, x̅_2,…, x̅_n}. 

The clauses as well as the literals within each clause are ordered (i.e. for instance that the
clauses x⊕ y and y ⊕ x are distinct). 
From a combinatorial point of view, an expression can be regarded as a
sequence of clauses where each clause is a pair of two literals. 
Neither the literals of a clause nor the clauses themselves need to be distinct. 

The set of all such expressions is denoted by ℰ_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Two Boolean functions f and g on n variables are equivalent , denoted as f≡ g, 
if g can be obtained from f by permuting the variables and flipping some of the literals.
We denote by (f) the equivalence class of a function f.

sentence:

only if f|_x=1≠ f|_x=0. 
We set e(f) as the number of the essential variables of f.

sentence:
Let G⃗ be a bipartite directed graph with vertex classes A and B,
	and  such that the degree
	of each vertex in A is divisible by 5. We say that G⃗
	admits a fractional factorization (M,F,H) for A if A(G⃗)
	can be decomposed into three edge-sets M, F and H such
	that the following holds.

 
  * Every edge in M is directed from B to A;
 
  * For every v∈ A, we have d^-_F(v)=d^+_F(v)=d^-_H(v)=d^+_H(v)=d^-_M(v)=d(v)/5;
 
  * For every v∈ B, we have d^-_F(v)=d^+_F(v) and d^-_H(v)=d^+_H(v).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given G=(V,E) and a threshold r, a set A_0⊆ V is called contagious if ⟨ A_0 ⟩=V. That is, activating A_0 results with the entire graph being activated.
The minimal cardinality of a contagious set in G is denoted in G by m(G,r).
The number of generations of a (not necessarily contagious) set A_0 which we denote by τ:=τ(A_0) is the minimal integer such that
⋃_i ≤τA_i=⟨ A_0 ⟩.

sentence: Let G be a split graph. We say G is balanced if it has a unique KS-partition, and unbalanced otherwise. A given KS-partition of G is S-max if S is as large as possible, and K-max if K is as large as possible. Furthermore, a vertex x as in case (ii) or (iii) of Proposition <ref> is called a swing vertex of G.

sentence: A colored split graph is a split graph with a chosen S-max partition. Equivalently, it is a split graph with vertices colored green (Kelly green) and red (Scarlet) such that the green set and the red set are respectively K and S in an S-max partition.

sentence:
For any p ∈ P, the toggle t_p: J(P) → J(P) is defined as follows:

    t_p(I)=
        
          I ∪{ p }       if  p ∉ I  and  I ∪{ p }∈ J(P) 
    
          I ∖{ p }   if  p ∈ I  and  I ∖{ p }∈ J(P) 
    
          I    otherwise.

The toggle group of P is the group generated by the t_p for all p∈ P.

sentence: An increasing tableau of shape λ is a filling of boxes of partition shape λ with positive integers such that the entries strictly increase from left to right across rows and strictly increase from top to bottom along columns. We will use qλ to indicate the set of increasing tableaux of shape λ with entries at most q.

sentence:

Let P be a poset with an n-dimensional lattice projection π, and let v = (v_1,v_2,…,v_n) where v_j ∈{± 1}.  Let T_π, v^i be the product of toggles t_x for all elements x of P that lie on the affine hyperplane ⟨π(x),v ⟩=i.  If there is no such x, then this is the empty product, considered to be the identity.  Define (hyperplane) promotion with respect to π and v as the toggle product Pro_π,v=… T_π,v^-2 T_π,v^-1 T_π,v^0 T_π,v^1 T_π,v^2…

sentence:
We say that a function f:P→ℤ is an increasing labeling if p_1< p_2 in P implies that f(p_1)< f(p_2) (with the usual total ordering on the integers). We will be interested in sets of increasing labelings on P given a restriction function
R:P↦𝒫(ℤ) indicating which labels each poset element is allowed to attain. 
We require R(p) to be nonempty and finite for each p∈ P. Call the set of such increasing labelings RP.

sentence:
Let p∈ P and f∈RP. 
For each i∈ℤ,
define the ith generalized Bender-Knuth involution ρ_i:RP→RP  as follows:


    ρ_i(f)(p)=
    R(p)_>i     f(p)=i RP
    
    i      f(p)=R(p)_>iRP
    
    f(p)

where R(p)_>i denotes the smallest label in R(p) that is larger than i.
That is, ρ_i changes i to R(p)_>i and/or R(p)_>i to i wherever possible. 

Define increasing labeling promotion as (f)=⋯∘ρ_3∘ρ_2∘ρ_1∘⋯(f).

sentence:

    t_p(I)=
        
          I ∪{ p }       if  p ∉ I  and  I ∪{ p }∈ J(P) 
    
          I ∖{ p }   if  p ∈ I  and  I ∖{ p }∈ J(P) 
    
          I    otherwise.

The toggle group of P is the group generated by the t_p for all p∈ P.

sentence:
Let T ∈qλ. Delete all labels 1
from T. Consider the set of boxes that are either empty or contain 2. We simultaneously delete
each label 2 that is adjacent to an empty box and place a 2 in each empty box that is adjacent to a 2. Now consider
the set of boxes that are either empty or contain 3, and repeat the above
process. Continue until all empty boxes are located at outer corners of λ.
Finally, label those boxes q + 1 and then subtract 1 from each entry. The
result is the K-promotion of T , which we denote (T). Note that (T) ∈qλ.

sentence: Suppose G=⟨ g ⟩ is a cyclic group acting on a set X, 𝒞_ω=⟨ c ⟩ a cyclic group of order ω acting nontrivially on a set Y, and f:X → Y a surjection. We say the triple (X,G,f) exhibits resonance with frequency ω if, for all x ∈ X, c · f(x)=f(g · x).

sentence: We say that a labeling function R:P↦𝒫(ℤ) is consistent if for every covering relation x⋖ y in P, we have min(R(x)) < min(R(y)) and max(R(x))< max(R(y)).

sentence: Say that an element p∈ P in an increasing labeling f∈RP is raisable if there exists another increasing labeling g∈RP where f(p)<g(p), and f(p')=g(p') for all p'∈ P, p'≠ p.

sentence:
Let ℤ_(P) denote the set of labelings g:P→(ℤ∪).
Define the ith jeu de taquin slide σ_i:ℤ_(P)→ℤ_(P) 
as follows: 


    σ_i(g)(x)=
    i      g(x)= g(y)=i  y⋗ x 
         g(x)=i  g(z)= z⋖ x
    
    g(x)

In words, σ_i(g)(x) replaces a label  with i if i is the label of a cover of x, replaces a label i by  if x covers an element labeled by , and leaves all other labels unchanged.

Let σ_i→ j:ℤ_(P)→ℤ_(P) be defined as 
    σ_i→ j(g)(x)= j     g(x)=i
      g(x)    .

In words, σ_i→ j(g)(x) replaces all labels i by j. 

For f∈qP, let jdt(f)=σ_→ (q+1)σ_q∘σ_q-1∘⋯∘σ_3∘σ_2∘σ_1→(f). That is, first replace all 1 labels by . Then perform the ith jeu de taquin slide σ_i for all 2≤ i≤ q. Next, replace all labels  by q+1. 
Define jeu de taquin promotion on f as (f)(x)=jdt(f)(x)-1.

We say that a function H:P→ℤ is a toggle order if p_1⋖ p_2 implies H(p_1)≠ H(p_2). 
Given a toggle order H, define T_H^i to be the toggle group action that is the product of all t_p for p∈ P such that H(p)=i.

sentence: [Definition 7, <cit.>] Let V=v_1,v_2,…, v_n. A multi-hypergraph  is a pair (V, ), where =E_1,…, E_N a set of multisets of V. The elements of V are called the vertices and the elements of  are called the edges . Moreover, a multi-hypergraph  is called an n× N multi-hypergraph if V=n, =N.

sentence: [Definition 8, <cit.>]  A multi-hypergraph =(V,) is called m-uniform (m≥ 2) if for all E ∈, the cardinal number of the multiset of E is m (including repeated memberships).

a_i_1…i_m =0,   ∀i_1∈I, ∀i_2, …,i_m ∉I.
 is called irreducible if it is not reducible.

An mth order n-dimensional tensor =(a_i_1⋯ i_m) is said to possess the zero-entry dominance property if for any (i_1,⋯, i_m)∈ S(m,n), a_i_1⋯ i_m=0 implies that a_j_1⋯ j_m=0 for all {j_1,⋯, j_m} satisfying B({j_1,⋯, j_m}) ⊇ B({i_1,⋯, i_m}).

    H_μ(x;q,t)=∑_λK_λμ(q,t)s_λ

sentence: Given a word w=w_1⋯ w_n where the letters w_i are taken from some totally ordered alphabet A, a descent of w is an index i for which w_i>w_i+1.  The major index of w, denoted (w), is the sum of the descents of w.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An attacking pair in a filling σ of a Young diagram is a pair of entries u and v with u>v satisfying one of the following conditions:
  
  
  * u and v are in the same row, with u to the left of v, or
  
  * u is in the row above v and strictly to its right.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let σ be any filling of a Young diagram with letters from a totally ordered alphabet A, allowing repeated letters.  A relative inversion of a filling σ of a Young diagram is a pair of entries u and v in the same row, with u to the left of v, such that if b is the entry directly below u, one of the following conditions is satisfied:
   
     
  * u<v and b is between u and v in size, in particular u≤ b<v.
     
  * u>v and b is not between u and v in size, in particular either b<v<u or v<u≤ b,
   
   If u and v are on the bottom row, we treat b as any value less than min(u,v), usually 0 in the case A=_+.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The content of a filling σ, denoted |σ|, is the sequence α=(α_1,⋯,α_k) where α_i is the number of i's used in the filling.  We also define the symbols:
  
  
  * F - set of all fillings of Young diagrams with positive integers
  
  * F_μ^α - set of fillings of shape μ and content α
  
  * F_μ^α|_=a,=b - set of fillings σ∈F_μ^α  for which (σ)=a and (σ)=b.
  
  We also define a weighted set to be a set S equipped with a number of statistics _1,_2,…, and a morphism of weighted sets to be a map that preserves their statistics.  We write 
    (S;_1,_2,…)
 to denote the weighted set if the statistics are not understood.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A Carlitz code of length n is a word w=w_1⋯ w_n consisting of nonnegative integers such that w_n-i<i for all i.  Let C_n denote the set of all Carlitz codes of length n, equipped with the combinatorial statistic Σ taking a word to the sum of its entries.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The inversion code of a permutation π, denoted (π), is the sequence c_1,c_2,…,c_n where c_i is the number of inversions of the form (j,i) in π, i.e. where i<j and i is to the right of j.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Carlitz bijection is the isomorphism 
    ^-1∘:(S_n;)→ (S_n;).

sentence:
Let A=(a_1^α_1, a_2^α_2,…, a_k^α_k) be any finite multiset of size n, with an ordering “<” such that a_1<a_2<⋯<a_k, and let μ be a partition of n.  We say that a word c of length n is A-weakly increasing if every subword of the form 
    c_α_1+⋯ +α_i,c_α_1+⋯α_i+1,… c_α_1+⋯+α_i+α_i+1-1
 is weakly increasing.

sentence:
The reverse of the content α=(α_1,…,α_M) is the tuple 
    r(α)=(α_M,α_M-1,…,α_1).
  In terms of alphabets, let A be a finite multiset of positive integers with maximum element M.  The content of A is α if α_i is the multiplicity of i in A. The complement of A, denoted A, is the multiset consisting of the elements M+1-a for all a∈ A.  Notice that the content of A is r(α).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let w be a word consisting of the letters in the ordered alphabet A=a_1≤⋯≤ a_n (corresponding to a filling of a horizontal shape), with ties among the letters broken in the order they appear in w.  The inversion code of w is the code (w)=c_1⋯ c_n where c_i is the number of inversions having a_i as the smaller entry of the inversion.

sentence:
We say that a sequence of numbers a_1,…, a_n are in cyclic order if there exists an index i∈ [n] for which 
    a_i+1≤ a_i+2≤⋯≤ a_n≤ a_1≤ a_2 ≤⋯≤ a_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let σ be a filling of a hook shape μ.  We define the hook codes of σ to be the pair of codes consisting of the  of its bottom row and the  of its leftmost column, along with the data of which entries occur in the row and which occur in the column.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A word having letters in {0,1,2,…} is Yamanouchi if every suffix contains at least as many i's as i+1's for all i≥ 0.

    A word w has content α=(α_1,…,α_k) if exactly α_i of the entries of w are equal to i-1 for each i.  We also sometimes say it has content A where A is the multiset of letters of w.

    Finally, a word w=w_1⋯ w_n is μ-sub-Yamanouchi , or μ-Carlitz , if there exists a Yamanouchi word v=v_1⋯ v_n of content μ such that w_i<v_i for all i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We define C_μ,A to be the collection of all μ-sub-Yamanouchi codes which are A-weakly increasing (see Definition <ref>).  We call such codes generalized Carlitz codes , and we equip this collection with the statistic Σ:C_μ,A→ by Σ(c)=∑ c_i, forming a weighted set (C_μ,A;Σ).
