sentence:
Fix variables x_1,x_2,….   For any finite code c of length n, define its monomial to be 
    x^c=x_n^c_1x_n-1^c_2⋯ x_1^c_n.
  Also let C_A(μ) be the set of all monomials x^c of μ-sub-Yamanouchi words c that are A-weakly increasing.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The sets B(μ) are defined by B((1))={1} and the recursion
     
    B(μ)=_i-1^μ_1^∗x_n^i-1·B(μ^(i)).
  We refer to these sets as the Garsia-Procesi module bases .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let ρ be a filling of μ^∗ having (ρ)=0.  Order its entries by size with ties broken in reading order to form a totally ordered alphabet A={a_1,…,a_n}. Then its inversion code , denoted (ρ), is the sequence c_1⋯ c_n whose ith entry c_i is the number of attacking pairs having a_i as its smaller entry.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let σ be a filling of a rectangle shape μ having height h, with distinct entries 1,2,…,n.  The bumping sequence of σ is the collection of entries a_1,a_2,…,a_h-1 defined as in Theorem <ref> above.  If n is in the ith row of σ, then a_1,…,a_i-1 are in rows 1 through i-1 respectively, and a_i,…,a_h-1 are in rows i+1 through h.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a word w=w_1⋯ w_n of positive integers, a Knuth move consists of either:
    
    
  * A transposition of the form xyz→ xzy where x,y,z are consecutive letters and y<x≤ z or z<x≤ y
    
  * A transposition of the form xyz→ yxz where x,y,z are consecutive letters and x≤ z<y or y≤ z<x.
     
    Two words w,w are said to be Knuth equivalent , written w w, if one can be reached from the other via a sequence of Knuth moves.  Knuth equivalence is an equivalence relation on words.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a word w=w_1,⋯, w_n with partition content μ, the cocharge of w, denoted (w) is the unique statistic satisfying the following properties:
    
      
  * It is constant on Knuth equivalence classes, that is, if w is Knuth equivalent to w then w=w. 
      
  * If w=w_1w_2⋯ w_n and w≠ 1, let (w)=w_2w_3⋯ w_nw_1 be the word formed by moving the first letter to the end.  Then 
    ((w))=(w)-1.

      
  * If the letters of w are weakly increasing then (w)=0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The cocharge word of a filling σ:μ→_+ is the word (σ)=i_1 i_2⋯ i_n consisting of the row indices of the cells u_k=(i_k,j_k), where u_1,u_2,…,u_n is the ordering of the cells of μ such that σ(u_1)≥σ(u_2)≥⋯≥σ(u_n), and for each constant segment σ(u_j)=⋯ =σ(u_k), the cells u_j,⋯,u_k are in reverse reading order.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let ρ be a filling of shape μ having =0.  We define the inversion word of ρ as follows.  Starting with the smallest value that appears in the filling, write the column numbers of the entries with that value as they appear in reading order, and then proceed with the second largest entry and so on.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Fix a linearly ordered finite multiset A, with elements a_1≤ a_2≤⋯≤ a_n.  The diagram a function f:A→_+ is the plot of the function with respect to the ordering on A.  We say that the diagram has shape μ if |f^-1(i)|=μ_i for each i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence: A consecutive subsequence is in inversion-friendly order if, when each row is labeled from right to left as above, all dots of label i+1 in the subsequence occur before the dots of label i for all i, and the dots of any given label appear in increasing order from bottom to top.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A diagram is of inversion word type if every subsequence determined by a fixed letter of A is in inversion-friendly order.
     
     We let _μ,A the set of all diagrams of shape μ of inversion word type over A.  We equip _μ,A with its  statistic to make it into a weighted set.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The inversion code of a diagram w, denoted (w) is the sequence {c_i} whose ith entry c_i is the number of inversion pairs of the form (w(i),b).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The cocharge contribution _(i,j)(σ) of an entry σ(i,j) of a filling σ is the number of descents that occur weakly below the entry (i,j) in its column, j.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let w be any sequence consisting of k 0's and k 1's, and let a_1,a_2,…,a_k be any ordering of the 0's.  We define the crossing number of w with respect to this ordering as follows.  Starting with a_1, let b_1 be the first 1 to the right of a_1 in the sequence, possibly wrapping around cyclically if there are no 1's to the right of a_1.  Then let b_2 be the first 1 cyclically to the right of a_2 other than b_1, and so on.  Then the crossing number is the number of indices i for which b_i is to the left of a_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A plane permutation on [n] is a pair 𝔭=(s,π) where s=(s_i)_i=0^n-1
	is an n-cycle and π is an arbitrary permutation on [n].
	Given s=(s_0 s_1 ⋯ s_n-1),
a plane permutation 𝔭=(s,π) is represented by a two-row array:

    𝔭=([      s_0      s_1        ⋯    s_n-2    s_n-1;   π(s_0)   π(s_1)        ⋯ π(s_n-2) π(s_n-1) ]).

The permutation D_𝔭 induced by the diagonal-pairs (cyclically), i.e., D_𝔭(π(s_i-1))=s_i for 0<i< n, and
D_𝔭(π(s_n-1))=s_0, is called the diagonal of 𝔭.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
For a plane permutation 𝔭=(s,π), an element s_i is called an
	exceedance of 𝔭 if s_i<_s π(s_i), and an anti-exceedance if s_i≥_s π(s_i).

_v,1=arc( c_v-a_v) and ϕ _v,2=arc(

sentence:
[<cit.>]
An unbounded vertex v∈ V_U is 
inevitable if replacing T_v by H_convex(T_v,T
_v) creates a new edge uv in G; then u is a hovering vertex
of v and the set H(v) of all hovering vertices of v is the 
hovering set of v. A trapezoepiped representation of a multitolerance
graph G is called canonical if every unbounded vertex is inevitable.

sentence:
[shadow representation]
Let G=(V,E) be a multitolerance graph, R
be a trapezoepiped representation of G, and V_B,V_U be the sets of
bounded and unbounded vertices of G in R, respectively. We associate the
vertices of G with points and line segments in the plane as follows:



  * for every v∈ V_B, the points p_v,1=(a_v,Δ -ϕ
_v,1) and p_v,2=(d_v,Δ -ϕ _v,2) and the line segment 
L_v=(p_v,1,p_v,2),


  * for every v∈ V_U, the point p_v=(a_v,Δ -ϕ_v)
.


The tuple (𝒫,ℒ), where ℒ={L_v:v∈
V_B} and 𝒫={p_v:v∈ V_U}, is the shadow
representation of G. If ϕ _v,1=ϕ _v,2 for every v∈ V_B,
then (𝒫,ℒ) is the horizontal shadow
representation of the tolerance graph G. Furthermore, the representation (𝒫,ℒ) is canonical if the initial trapezoepiped
representation R is also canonical.

sentence:
Let L_i,L_i^',∈ℒ and let L_j,L_j^'∈ℒ, where possibly i^'=i and possibly j^'=j. The pair (j,j^') is
a left-crossing pair if l_j∈ S_l_j^'. Furthermore
the pair (i,i^') is a right-crossing pair if r_i^'∈ S_r_i. For every left-crossing pair (j,j^') we define

    ℒ_j,j^'^right={x∈𝒫∪ℒ
    :x⊆ A_t, where t=Γ _l_j^vert∩Γ
    _l_j^'^diag}

and for every right-crossing pair (i,i^') we define

    ℒ_i,i^'^left={x∈𝒫∪ℒ
    :x⊆ B_t, where t=Γ _r_i^vert∩Γ
    _r_i^'^diag}.

Finally, for every line segment L_q∈ℒ we define

    ℒ_q^right={x∈𝒫∪ℒ:x⊆ℝ_right^2(Γ _l_q^diag)}.

Let S⊆𝒫∪ℒ be an arbitrary set. Let (i,i^') be a right-crossing
pair and (j,j^') be a left-crossing pair. If L_i,L_i^'∈ S and S⊆ℒ_i,i^'^left, then (i,i^') is the end-pair of the set S. If L_j,L_j^'∈ S and S⊆ℒ_j,j^'^
right, then (j,j^') is the start-pair of the set S.

sentence:
Let (a,b)∈𝒜×ℬ be a pair of
points such that b∈ℝ_right^2(Γ _a^diag
). Let (i,i^') be a right-crossing pair and L_q be a line
segment such that L_q∈ℒ_i,i^'^left and L_i,L_i^'∈ℒ_q^right.
Furthermore let b∈ℝ_left^2(Γ _r_i^
vert). Then BD_(𝒫,ℒ)(a,b,q,i,i^') is a
dominating set Z⊆ℒ of X(a,b) with the smallest
size, such that:



  * (i,i^') is the end-pair of Z and


  * L_q is the diagonally leftmost line segment of Z.


If such a dominating set Z⊆ℒ of X(a,b) does not
exist, we define BD_(𝒫,ℒ)(a,b,q,i,i^')=
and |BD_(𝒫,ℒ)(a,b,q,i,i^')|=∞.

sentence:
Let ℐ=(𝒫,ℒ
,j,j^',i,i^') be an instance of Restricted Bounded
Dominating Set on tolerance graphs. Let l=Γ _l_j^vert
∩Γ _l_j^'^diag and r=Γ _r_i^
vert∩Γ _r_i^'^diag. A point p∈𝒫 is a bad point if p∈ℝ_left^2(Γ _l^
diag) or p∈ℝ_right^2(Γ _r^vert
). A point p∈𝒫 is an irrelevant point if p∈
S_l∪ S_r. A line segment L_t∈ℒ is a bad line
segment if L_t⊆ B_l or L_t⊆ A_r. Finally a line
segment L_t∈ℒ is an irrelevant line segment if
either L_t⊆B_l∩A_r and L_t∉ℒ_j,j^'^right∩ℒ
_i,i^'^left, or L_t has an endpoint in B_l∪
A_r and another point in B_l∩A_r.

sentence:
Let G be an even graph. A decomposition of G into cycles is called a cycle decomposition .
	We call
	
    c(G) = min{|𝒞| |𝒞 is a cycle decomposition of  G}

	the cycle number of G.

sentence:
Let G be a graph containing a path P = v_1 ⋯ v_r such that ∀ i = 1, …, r: _G(v_i) = 2.
	We add a double ear to P by the following construction:
	
		
  *  Connect the first and the last vertex of P by a new edge.
		
  *  Duplicate each edge of P.
	
	Also the path v_1 without edges is allowed as a choice of P. In this case, a loop is added to v_1.
	Observe that all edges added in the above two steps build a cycle. In particular: If G is an Eulerian graph, also the graph obtained by adding a double ear is an Eulerian graph.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
[Cycle Decomposition]
	Let G be an even graph. A decomposition of G into cycles is called a cycle decomposition .
	We call
	
    c(G) = min{|𝒞| |𝒞 is a cycle decomposition of  G}

	the cycle number of G.

sentence:
[Subdivision, Resolving a Node of Degree 2]
	A graph G' that is obtained by replacing an edge with endnodes u and w of a graph G by a new path uvw is called a simple subdivision of G.
	We say that G is obtained from G' by resolving the node v.
	Moreover, G” is called a subdivision of G if there is a finite sequence (G_0 = G, G_1, G_2, …, G_k = G”) such that G_i is a simple subdivision of G_i-1 for each i = 1, …, k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Adding a Double Ear]
	
	Let G be a graph containing a path P = v_1 ⋯ v_r such that ∀ i = 1, …, r: _G(v_i) = 2.
	We add a double ear to P by the following construction:
	
		
  *  Connect the first and the last vertex of P by a new edge.
		
  *  Duplicate each edge of P.
	
	Also the path v_1 without edges is allowed as a choice of P. In this case, a loop is added to v_1.
	Observe that all edges added in the above two steps build a cycle. In particular: If G is an Eulerian graph, also the graph obtained by adding a double ear is an Eulerian graph.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (G_0, G_1, …, G_k) be a finite sequence of graphs such that for each i = 1, …, k: either
	
		
  * double ear step: G_i is either built by adding a double ear to G_i-1 or
		
  * subdivision step: G_i is a simple subdivision of G_i-1.
	
	Then, we call (G_0, G_1, …, G_k) a double ear decomposition of G_k starting with G_0.
	If G_0 is a cycle, we call G_k a double ear decomposable graph .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: double ear step:;subdivision step:;double ear decomposable graph

sentence:
[Tree Decomposition, Treewidth, Bags, <cit.>]
	A tree decomposition of a graph G = (V, E) is a pair ({X_i i ∈ I}, T=(I,F)) with {X_i i ∈ I} a family of subsets of V, one for each node of T, and T a tree such that
	
		
  * ⋃_i ∈ I X_i = V.
		
  * For all edges vw ∈ E, there exists an i ∈ I with v ∈ X_i and w ∈ X_i.
		
  * For all i,j,k ∈ I: If j is on the path from i to k in T, then X_i ∩ X_k ⊆ X_j.
	
	For i ∈ I, X_i is called a bag of the tree decomposition.
	The width of a tree decomposition ({X_i i ∈ I}, T=(I,F)) is max_i ∈ I |X_i|-1.
	The treewidth of a graph G is the minimum width over all possible tree decompositions of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A tree decomposition as in Lemma <ref> is called a smooth tree decomposition.

sentence: A pendant path attached to vertex v in graph G=(V,E) is a set P⊂ V such that G[P] is a connected component of G-v which is a path, one of whose ends is adjacent to v in G. The neighbor of v in P will be called the base of the path, and p(v) will denote the number of pendant paths attached to v∈ V.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph G=(V,E) is a graph of two parallel paths specified by V_1 and V_2 if G≄P_n, and if V can be partitioned into nonempty sets V_1 and V_2 such that P_1:=G[V_1] and P_2:=G[V_2] are paths, and such that G can be drawn in the plane in such a way that P_1 and P_2 are parallel line segments, and the edges between P_1 and P_2 (drawn as straight line segments) do not cross; such a drawing of G is called a standard drawing . In a standard drawing of G, fix an ordering of the vertices of P_1 and P_2 that is increasing in the same direction for both paths. In this ordering, let first(P_i) and last(P_i) respectively denote the first and last vertices of P_i for i=1,2. The sets {first(P_1),first(P_2)} and {last(P_1),last(P_2)} will be referred to as ends of G.

sentence:
An _q-labeled lattice path is a lattice path with a rule assigning to each step (i,j) in the path a sequence of labels (x_1,…,x_j) ∈ (_q^×)^j.
Thus, the number of nonzero labels assigned to a step is the step's height, and we consider steps of the form (i,0) to be unlabeled.

sentence: Let w be a finite word over an alphabet Σ. We say that w is closed if it is empty or it has a factor (different from the word itself) occurring exactly twice in w, as a prefix and as a suffix, that is, with no internal occurrences. A word which is not closed is called open .

sentence:
A non-empty word w is trapezoidal if 


 
  * f_w(i)=i+1   for   0≤ i ≤ m_w,
 
  * f_w(i+1)=f_w(i)   for    m_w≤ i ≤ M_w-1,
 
  * f_w(i+1)=f_w(i)-1   for    M_w≤ i ≤|w|.

sentence: Let w be a trapezoidal word. We say that w is semicentral if h_w=k_w=r_w=l_w.

sentence: A poset P is a set with a binary relation, denoted ≤, that is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. Given e,f ∈ P, f covers e if e<f and there is no element x∈ P such that e<x<f. A subset I of P is called an order ideal if for any t ∈ I and s ≤ t in P, then s ∈ I. Let J(P) denote the set of order ideals of P.

sentence:
Let P be a poset. For any e ∈ P, the toggle t_e: J(P) → J(P) is defined as follows:

    t_e(I)=
        
          I ∪{ e }       if  e ∉ I  and  I ∪{ e }∈ J(P) 
    
          I ∖{ e }   if  e ∈ I  and  I ∖{ e }∈ J(P) 
    
          I    otherwise.

sentence:
[<cit.>]

Let P=[a_1] ×…× [a_n] be the product of n chains poset where we consider the elements in the standard n-dimensional embedding as vectors in ℕ^n, and let v = (v_1,v_2,…,v_n) where v_j ∈{± 1}.  Let T_v^i be the product of toggles t_x for all elements x of P that lie on the affine hyperplane ⟨ x,v ⟩=i.  If there is no such x, then this is the empty product, considered to be the identity.  Define promotion with respect to v as the toggle product Pro_v=… T_v^-2 T_v^-1 T_v^0 T_v^1 T_v^2…

sentence:
Given a finite set S, an action τ:S → S, and a statistic f:S → k where k is a field of characteristic zero, then (S, τ, f) exhibits homomesy if there exists c ∈ k such that for every τ-orbit  


1/#∑_x ∈ f(x) = c


where # denotes the number of elements in . If such a c exists, we will say the triple is c-mesic.

sentence: An increasing tableau of shape λ is a filling of boxes of partition shape λ with positive integers such that the entries strictly increase from left to right across rows and strictly increase from top to bottom along columns. We will use Inc^q(λ) to indicate the set of increasing tableaux of shape λ with entries at most q.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
The frame of a partition λ is the set Frame(λ) of all boxes in the first or last row, or in the first or last column.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let P be a poset with an n-dimensional lattice projection π, and let v = (v_1,v_2,…,v_n) where v_j ∈{± 1}.  Let T_π, v^i be the product of toggles t_x for all elements x of P that lie on the affine hyperplane ⟨π(x),v ⟩=i.  If there is no such x, then this is the empty product, considered to be the identity.  Define promotion with respect to π and v as the toggle product Pro_π,v=… T_π,v^-2 T_π,v^-1 T_π,v^0 T_π,v^1 T_π,v^2…

sentence:
Let H and G be graphs.
	G is H-saturated
		if G contains no copy of H
		and for every edge e ∈ E(G) 
		there is at least one copy of H in G+e.
	G is uniquely H-saturated
		if G contains no copy of H
		and for every edge e ∈ E(G),
		there is a unique copy of H in G + e.

sentence:
Given a SSYT, T, of shape λ /μ we perform a forward-(jdt)-slide as follows:


  * Choose an inner corner of μ, C=(i,j).

  * Let c=min{T(i+1, j), T(i, j+1)} or c=T(i+1, j) if T(i+1, j) = T(i, j+1)  or if only one of T(i+1, j), T(i, j+1) exists then that is taken to be the minimum value. Let C' be the position c is in.

  * Form T' by setting T(i,j)=c and letting C' be empty.

  * Set C:=C' and return to the second step until T' is a SSYT.


Given a SSYT, T, of shape λ /μ we perform a backward-(jdt)-slide as follows:


  * Choose an outer corner of λ, D=(i,j).

  * Let d=max{T(i-1, j), T(i, j-1)} or d=T(i-1, j) if T(i-1, j) = T(i, j-1)  or if only one of T(i-1, j), T(i, j-1) exists then that is taken to be the maximum value. Let D' be the position d is in.

  * Form T” by setting T(i,j)=d and letting D' be empty.

  * Set D:=D' and return to the second step until T” is a SSYT.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider any simple labeled graph G on k vertices.  The encoded form of G is a listing of k-1 integers a_0 a_1 … a_k-2 chosen as follows:




For each 0≤ i≤ k-2, set the base 2 representation of a_i to b_k-1 b_k-2… b_i+1, where b_m = 1 if and only if the vertex with label i is adjacent to the vertex m in G.




The a_i are the entries of G's encoded form.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence: Given two strings of k integers, A = a_0 a_1 … a_k-1 and B = b_0 b_1 … b_k-1, we say that A and B are encoding equivalent if a_i ≡ b_i 2^k-i-1 for each integer 0≤ i≤ k-1.  Clearly encoding equivalence is an equivalence relation.  Let the canonical representative of each equivalence class be the member C = c_0 c_1 … c_k-1 with 0 ≤ c_i< 2^k-i-1.  Notice that C is the only member of [C] which is itself the encoding of a graph.  If A is a string, we let C(A) denote the graph encoded by the canonical representative from A's equivalence class.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a string of integers A = a_0 a_1 … a_n-1 and a positive integer k ≤ n-1, define a k-window of A to be a length-k substring of the form n_i n_i+1… n_i+k-1, where subscripts are reduced modulo k as appropriate.  A U-cycle of encodings of length k is a string of positive integers such that the sequence of k-windows of the string contains exactly one member from each equivalence class of encodings of length k.

sentence:
Suppose that n is a natural number.
	
		
  * A disjoint type of length n is a function t : 2n → 2
		such that
		
    |{i < 2n | t(i) = 0}| = |{i < 2n | t(i) = 1}| = n.

		
  * If a and b are disjoint elements of [Ord]^n, then
		(a,b) is the unique disjoint type t :2n → 2 such that,
		letting a ∪ b = {α_0, α_1, …, α_2n-1},
		enumerated in increasing order, we have a = {α_i | i < 2n  and  t(n) = 0}
		and b = {α_i | i < 2n  and  t(n) = 1}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that κ < λ are regular cardinals and S ⊆ S^λ_κ
	is stationary. A club-guessing sequence on S is a sequence
	C⃗ = ⟨ C_α|α∈ S ⟩ such that
	
		
  * for every α∈ S, C_α is a club in α of order type κ;
		
  * for every club D in λ, there are stationarily many
		α∈ S such that C_α⊆ D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A symmetric hyperplane arrangement or a SH–arrangement is a hyperplane arrangement 𝒜 in ℂ^n such that, for every permutation σ in 𝔖_n, we have σ·𝒜 = 𝒜.

sentence: A colored symmetric hyperplane arrangement or a CSH–arrangement is a hyperplane arrangement 𝒜 in ℂ^n such that, for every colored permutation π of 𝕌_m ≀𝔖_n, we have π·𝒜 = 𝒜.

    u(x) := ∑_n ∈ℕ u_n x^n/n!.

sentence:
[The Cathedral Construction] 
Let G_0 be a saturated elementary graph 
and let {G_S}_S∈G_0 be a family of saturated graphs, 
some of which might be empty. 
For each S∈𝒫(G_0), 
join every vertex in S and every vertex of G_S.
We call this operation the cathedral construction . 
Here G_0 and {G_S}_S∈G_0 
are respectively called  
the foundation and the family of towers . 

0
Let G_0 be a saturated elementary graph.
For each class S∈𝒫(G_0), assign an saturated graph G_S, which might be empty,
and join every vertex in S and every vertex of G_S.
We call this operation cathedral construction .

sentence: A set S⊆^d is said to be in stair-general position if p_i≠ q_i for every two distinct points p,q∈ S and every 1≤ i≤ d.

with derangement connection set S as the digraph (X,S) = (X, A) with vertex set X and 
arc set A= { (x,x^s) | x∈ X, s∈ S}⊆ X^(2).

Let X be a non-empty set. A non-empty subset S⊆(X)
is said to be  closed if  both of the following conditions hold.


(1) x^S=x^S^-1 for each x∈ X;   and   (2) SS^-1⊆(X)∪{1}.

sentence:
Let =(X,A) and Δ=(Y,B) be simple digraphs, and let Z=X× Y, and  z_i=(x_i,y_i) for i=1,2.

(a) The cartesian product Σ = □Δ = (Z,C_□), where (z_1,z_2)∈ C_□ if and only if  either (x_1, x_2)∈ A and y_1=y_2, or (y_1,y_2)∈ B and x_1=x_2.

(b) The tensor product ×Δ=(Z,C_×), where (z_1,z_2)∈ C_× if and only if  both (x_1, x_2)∈ A and (y_1,y_2)∈ B.

(c) The strong product ⊠Δ=(Z,C_⊠), where C_⊠ = C_□∪ C_×. 

(d)  The  lexicographic product [Δ]=(Z,C_[ ]), where  (z_1,z_2)∈ C_[ ] if and only if  either (x_1, x_2)∈ A, 
or x_1=x_2 and (y_1,y_2)∈ B.

sentence: Let G and H be graphs. Then H is a retract of G if and only if there exist homomorphisms ρ : G⟶ H and γ:H⟶ G such that ρ∘γ=id_H. The homomorphic ρ is called a retraction and γ a co-retraction .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let X be a nonempty set. A derangement connection set S of Sym(X) is called complete if |S|=|X|-1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let H be a graph and v a looped vertex of H. The local complement of H at v, denoted by H*v, is the graph obtained from H by complementing the subgraph induced by N_H(v).

In other words, for all p ⊆ V(H) = V(H*v) with |p| ∈{1,2}, we have p ∈ E(H*v) if and only if either (1) p ∉ E(H) and p ⊆ N_H(v) or (2) p ∈ E(H) and p ⊈N_H(v).

sentence: A monet ( monadic net ) is a consistent linked mograph with no induced bimatching.

sentence:
A homogeneous combinatorial proof of a mograph  is a skew bifibration  from a monet .
A homogeneous combinatorial proof of a closed monadic formula  is a homogeneous combinatorial proof of its mograph .[Although, for technical convenience, throughout this paper we have assumed (without loss of generality) that every formula is rectified, this definition of homogeneous combinatorial proof also works directly for non-rectified closed monadic formulas, without the need to first transform to rectified form.

This is because  is agnostic to the choice of bound variables, since mographs do not contain any variables.

For example,
(∀ x1mu px)
∨
(∀ x1mu qx)

=

(∀ x1mu px)
∨
(∀ y1mu qy)

=
  x pxxxqxnodesepA=1pt,nodesepB=.5pt[angleA=30,angleB=155]xpx[angleA=30,angleB=155]xxqx
and
∀ x2mu∃ x2mu px
=
∀ x2mu∃ y2mu py
=
  x xxpxxxpxnodesepA=1.5pt,nodesepB=1pt[angleA=35,angleB=150]xxpx.]

sentence:
Let S_1, … , S_m be finite sets and for every assignment s_1, …, s_m∈ S_1×…× S_m
  let f_s_1, … , s_m (x) be a real-rooted degree n polynomial with positive leading coefficient.
For a partial assignment s_1, …, s_k ∈ S_1 ×…× S_k with k < m, define

    f_s_1,… , s_k∑_s_k+1∈ S_k+1, … , s_m∈ S_m
      f_s_1, … ,s_k, s_k+1, … , s_m,

as well as

    f_∅∑_s_1∈ S_1, … , s_m∈ S_m
      f_s_1, … , s_m.


We say that the polynomials {f_s_1, … , s_m}_s_1, … , s_m
  form an interlacing family if for all k=0,…, m-1, and all
  s_1, …, s_k∈ S_1×…× S_k,
  the polynomials

    {f_s_1, … , s_k,t}_t∈ S_k+1

have a common interlacing.

sentence:
We say that a polynomial g(x) = ∏_i=1^n-1 (x - α_i) interlaces a polynomial 
  f(x) = ∏_i=1^n (x - β_i) if

    β_1≤α_1≤β_2≤α_2≤…≤α_n-1≤β_n

We say that polynomials f_1, … , f_k have a common interlacing
  if there is a polynomial g so that g interlaces f_i for each i.

sentence:
Let G be a graph.  Assign to each edge e={i,j} an interaction energy  J_e=J_i,j, and assign to each vertex v_i a  field vector M_i :=(  M_i,1, M_i,2, … , M_i,q  ). 
Then the  Hamiltonian of  the Potts model with variable edge interaction energy and variable  field is 

    h(σ) =  -∑_{ i,j }∈ E   J_i,jδ(σ_i, σ_j)  - ∑_v_i∈ V(G)∑_α =1^q M_i,αδ(α,  σ_i).

sentence:
<cit.>
Let G(V,E) be a graph and v∈ V(G). The clique substitution at v is the graph obtain from G by replacing v with a clique of size |N_G(v)| and matching vertices in N_G(v) with the vertices of that clique. The clique substitution of G, denoted K(G), is the graph obtained from G by performing clique substitutions at all vertices of G. We refer to a clique substituted for a vertex of G as a knot (of K(G)).

sentence: A parking function of length n is a sequence (α_1,…,α_n) ∈ℕ^n whose weakly increasing rearrangement α_i_1≤α_i_2≤⋯≤α_i_n satisfies α_i_j≤ j -1 for all 1 ≤ j ≤ n. We denote the set of parking functions of length n by PF(n).

sentence:
For n ≥ 1, a rooted plane tree on n+1 vertices is a rooted tree T with vertex set V(T) := {0,1,…,n} and root 0 satisfying the following conditions:


  * i ≤_T j implies i ≤ j for all 1 ≤ i,j ≤ n;

  * i ≤_T k implies i ≤_T j for all 1 ≤ i < j < k ≤ n. 

We denote the set of rooted plane trees on n+1 vertices by RPT(n+1).

sentence: A G-parking function is a formal sum α = ∑_i ∈V(G)α_i [i] ∈ℕV(G) of non-root vertices such that for any ∅≠ U ⊆V(G) there is i ∈ U with  where deg^G_U(i) := ∑_j ∈ V(G) - Uω_G({i,j}). We identify the formal sum α = ∑_i ∈V(G)α_i [i] with the sequence α = (α_1,…,α_n) ∈ℕ^n when V(G) = {1,…,n}. We denote the set of G-parking functions by PF(G). The sum of α∈PF(G) is sum(α) := ∑_i=1^nα_i and the reversed sum is rsum(α) := #E(G) - n - sum(α).

sentence:
Let q>1 be a prime power. A set ℱ_q
  of 3-dimensional subspaces of _q^7/_q (or any other
  7-dimensional vector space V over _q) is said to be a
  q-analogue of the Fano plane if every 2-dimensional
  subspace of _q^7 (respectively, V) is contained in a unique
  member of ℱ_q.

sentence:

  α(S)=(α_0(S),α_1(S),α_2(S),α_3(S)),
  α_i(S)=#{E∈𝒞;(E∩ S)=i}, of

sentence:
The toroidal expanse of a graph G, denoted by (G), is the largest value of p· q
over all integers p,q≥3 such that G contains a toroidal p × q-grid
 as a minor.
If G does not contain C_3 C_3 as a minor, then let (G)=0.

sentence:
Let G be a graph embedded in an orientable surface Σ.
The stretch (G) of G 
is the minimum value of (A)·(B) over all pairs of cycles
A,B⊆ G that are in a one-leap position in Σ.

sentence:
Let G be a graph embedded in the orientable surface Σ_g.
A sequence (G_1,C_1),(G_2,C_2), …, (G_g,C_g) 
is called a good planarizing sequence for G if the following holds
for i=1,…,g, letting G_0=G:


  * G_i is a graph embedded in Σ_g-i,

  * C_i is a nonseparating cycle in G_i-1 of length (G_i-1), and

  * G_i results by cutting the embedding G_i-1 through C_i.

We implicitly associate such a planarizing sequence with the values
{k_i,ℓ_i}_i=1,…,g, where
k_i=(C_i) and ℓ_i is the length of a shortest C_i-switching
ear in G_i-1, for i=1,…,g.

    _X∩_Y=_Z.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
 A Grassmann necklace is a sequence 
 
    =(I_1,I_2,…,I_n,I_n+1=I_1)
 
 of k-element subsets of [n] such that for each i∈[n], there exists an integer j_i such that 
 
    I_i+1=(I_i-{i})∪{j_i}.

 In this case, we call k the rank of .

sentence: Let H be a 3-graph. A pair ab of vertices of H is called light in H if it is contained in less than 2l-2 edges of H. It is called heavy in H otherwise. We let (H) be the set of all the pairs which are light in H and (H) the set of all the pairs which are heavy in H.

sentence: Let H be a 3-graph. An edge e of H is called heavy if it contains a pair which is heavy in H. Otherwise, it is called light . We let (H) be the set of heavy edges of H and (H) the set of light ones.

sentence: Let H be a 3-graph. The reduced hypergraph of H, denoted by , is the hypergraph with vertex set V(H) and set of edges (H)∪(H).

sentence:
A pair (X,Y) of disjoint subsets of V(H) is called an extender if 


  * For any u,v ∈ X with u≠ v and any set S⊆ V(H)\ ({u,v }∪ Y) of size at most 2l-5 there exists a simple path of length two in H joining u to v and which contains no element of S;

  * |Y| ≤ 2|X|.

The size of the extender (X,Y) is defined to be |X|.

sentence:
A family of polytopes P 
 is affinely reduced to a family Q
 if there exists r∈ such that
 for every polytope p∈ P there is q∈ Q with p  q 
 and  q = O (( p)^r).
Designation: P ∝_A Q.

sentence:
The double covering polytope is the convex hull of the set 
  
    _d = {x∈{0,1}^d | B x = 2},

  where B∈^m× d is a 0-1 matrix, 
  2 is the m-dimensional all 2 vector,
  and each row of B contains exactly four 1's.

    x + δ(x)m  ∈ [c,c+m[.

We call δ(x) the depth of x.

sentence: Let b ∈ S^*. A summand of b is any a ∈ S^* such that b ∈ a+S^*, i.e. such that there exists s ∈ S^* with b=a+s.

sentence: A loopy graph is a finite graph with no isolated vertices, no multiple edges but possibly with loops.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
In a loopy graph, an edge with equal endvertices is a loop , otherwise it is a true edge . A vertex is loopy if it supports a loop, or nonloopy otherwise. The loopy-complete graph on n vertices, denoted LK_n, is the graph obtained from the complete graph K_n
by attaching a loop to every vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The vertex-maximal matching number of G is the maximum number of vertices touched by a matching M in G. We denote this number by (G). In formula:

    (G) = max_M ⊆ G |V(M)|

where M runs over all matchings of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A vertex-maximal matching of G is a matching touching (G) vertices. An edge in G is active if it is contained in a vertex-maximal matching of G, and passive otherwise. We denote by E^+ ⊆ E the set of active edges.

sentence: Let e={x,y}∈ E(G). The weight of e is defined as (e)=x+y.

sentence: An edge {x,y} in G is weak if δ(x)+δ(y) = q-1, and normal otherwise, i.e. if δ(x)+δ(y) ≥ q.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
The normality number of the graph G=G(S) is defined as

    ν=ν(G) = max_M ⊆ G #{endvertices of all normal edges in  M},

where M runs over all vertex-maximal matchings in G. Thus 0 ≤ν≤(G).

sentence: Let u ∈ S^*. A proper factor of u is an element v ∈ S^* such that v ≠u and v divides u, i.e. such that there exists v' ∈ S^* satisfying u=vv'.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A downset in S^* is a subset I ⊆ S^* which is stable under taking proper factors. That is, if u ∈ I and if v ∈ S^* is a proper factor of u, then v ∈ I.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let z ∈ S^*. We define the length of z to be the largest integer t ≥ 1 such that z=x_1… x_t with x_1,…,x_t ∈ S^*. We then write t = (z).

sentence: Let S,S' be two numerical semigroups. We say that S,S' are graph-equivalent if their associated graphs G(S), G(S') are isomorphic.

sentence:
Let G be a graph with (G)≤ r and T V(G) a tight clique in G. Set S = S_T. Then we define
	
    R_T = ∁G[S],

i.e., the graph on S whose edges are those not in G.  If R is any graph and I V(R) we define
	
    _̣I = mind_R(x)x∈ I.

	We define the fixed loss of a graph R to be
	
    (R) = ∑_I∈(R)
    I≠ (2^_̣I - 1).

sentence: A cluster is a maximal tight clique.  If T is a cluster in a graph G and C is a c-clique with T∩ C=c-1, then we say that C is associated with T .

sentence:
The Bell polynomials are defined recursively by

    B_0    = 𝕀
    
    	B_n    = (d_1 + ∂) B_n-1,    n > 0.

sentence:
The Lie derivative of a function ψ: M →ℝ along a vector field F ∈𝒳(M) is

    F[ψ](x) := 𝐝ψ(x) · F(x),

where 𝐝ψ: M → T^*M is the differential of ψ.

sentence:
Let F,G ∈𝒳(M) be two vector fields, and write Φ_t,F for the flow of F. The Lie derivative of G with respect to F is defined by

    F[G] := d/dt|_t=0Φ_t,F^* G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A (commutative or noncommutative) uniform family is a hereditary family 𝒫 of graded posets together with a reduced order-compatible relation ∼ such that

	
  (1) If P∈𝒫_0, y ∈ P and y < 1_P, then [y,1_P] ∈𝒫_0.
	
  (2) For all n ≥ 1 there exists exactly one type in 𝒫_0 having rank n.

sentence: Let 𝒢 = (G_n)_n ∈ be a sequence of graphs, where G_n is a (n,δ_n,Δ_n,λ_n)-graph for each n ∈. We say that 𝒢 is an expander sequence if Δ_n/δ_n=1+o(1) and λ_n=o(Δ_n).

    d_G(X,Y)=e_G(X,Y)/|X||Y|.

sentence:
[(ε,k_0,K_0)-Szemerédi partition]
Let G=(V,E) and k∈ℕ. We call  Π={V_i}_i∈[k] an (ε,k_0,K_0)-Szemerdédi partition of G if the following conditions are fulfilled.

0em 

  * V_1∪̇…∪̇V_k=V,

  * k_0≤ k≤ K_0,

  * |V_1| ≤…≤ |V_k| ≤ |V_1|+1,

  * for all but at most ε k^2 pairs (V_i,V_j) of Π with i<j we have that for all subsets U_i⊆ V_i and U_j⊆ V_j with |U_i| ≥ε|V_i| and |U_j| ≥ε|V_j|

    |d(U_i,U_j)-d(V_i,V_j)| ≤ε.


A pair (V_i,V_j) satisfying the last condition is called ε-regular . For pairs (V_i,V_j) in Π we will abbreviate d(V_i,V_j) with d_ij.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>, (ε,p,k_0,K_0)-Szemerédi partition]
Let G=(V,E) and k∈ℕ. We call  Π={V_i}_i∈[k] an (ε,k_0,K_0)-Szemerdédi partition of G if the following conditions are fulfilled.

0em 

  * V_1∪̇…∪̇V_k=V,

  * k_0≤ k≤ K_0,

  * |V_1| ≤…≤ |V_k| ≤ |V_1|+1,

  * for all but at most ε k^2 pairs (V_i,V_j) of Π with i<j we have that for all subsets U_i⊆ V_i and U_j⊆ V_j with |U_i| ≥ε|V_i| and |U_j| ≥ε|V_j|

    |d(U_i,U_j)-d(V_i,V_j)| ≤ε p.


A pair (V_i,V_j) satisfying the last condition is called (ε,p)-regular . For pairs (V_i,V_j) in Π we will abbreviate d(V_i,V_j) with d_ij.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A set Q⊂ Z, where Z is an abelian torsion-free group, is a GAP of rank r if it can be expressed in the form

    Q= {_0+ k_1_1 + … +k_r _r : K_i ≤ k_i ≤ K_i', k_i∈ for all  1 ≤ i ≤ r}
 for some _0,…, _r∈ Z, and some integers K_1,…,K_r,K'_1,…,K'_r.

The elements _i∈ Z are the generators of Q, the numbers K_i' and K_i are the dimensions of Q.  We say that Q is proper if |Q| = ∏ (K_i'-K_i+1).  If g_0=0 and -K_i=K_i' for all i≥ 1, we say that Q is symmetric.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Stirling Polynomial Analogs] 

For x,n,x-n ≥ 1, we suggest the next two variants of the 
generalized Stirling convolution polynomials , denoted by 
σ_f(t),n(x) and σ_f(t),n(x), respectively, 
as the right-hand-side coefficient definitions in the following equations: 

    σ_f(t),n(x) := f(t)xx-n(x-n-1)!/x!_f       f(t)n+1k = (n+1)!_f/(k-1)! σ_f(t),n+1-k(n+1) 
    σ_f(t),n(x) := f(t)xx-n(x-n-1)!/x!       f(t)n+1k = (n+1)!/(k-1)! σ_f(t),n+1-k(n+1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Spanners]
A k-spanner of a graph G = (V, E, w) is a subgraph H = (V, E' ⊆ E, w) for which
_H(s, t) ≤ k ·_G(s, t) for all s, t ∈ V.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Fault Tolerant Spanners]
Given a graph G, a subgraph H is an f Vertex Fault Tolerant (VFT), resp. Edge Fault Tolerant (EFT), k-spanner of G if for any set of F vertices (resp. edges) in G of size |F| ≤ f, H ∖ F is a k-spanner of G ∖ F.

plain_text_term: f Vertex Fault Tolerant (VFT), resp. Edge Fault Tolerant (EFT),

sentence: [Blocking Set] Given a graph G = (V, E), a k-blocking set for G is a set B ⊆ V × E such that (1) every (v,e) ∈ B has v ∉e, and (2) for every cycle C in G on ≤ k edges, there exists (v,e) ∈ B such that v,e ∈ C.

sentence: Let A be an n × n matrix. We say that A is generalised irreducible if for every pair (i,j), i,j=1,2,…,n, there exists a positive integer k such that (A^k)_ij≠ 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a colored sequence f=(f_1^c_1,…,f_n^c_n) ∈, we construct the colored permutation π(f) as follows. For ν∈, we first define the sets 

    A_ν:={i^c_i| f_i =ν  and c_i=c_i(f)},

and arrange the entries in each nonempty “bloc” A_ν in increasing order (cf. (<ref>)), obtaining ↑ A_ν. Then 

    π(f):=[↑ A_ν_1, ↑A_ν_2, …,  ↑ A_ν_k]
 
is obtained by juxtaposing the entries of the nonempty blocs  ↑ A_ν_1, ↑ A_ν_2, …, where
ν_1<ν_2<⋯.

sentence:
For a graph G = (V, E), a set S ⊂ V is a β-packing set of a graph G if S is a proper, maximal set having the property (which we call the β-packing property ) that for all vertices v ∈ V-S, 
    |N(v) ∩ S|≤β |N(v)|

     for some 0 < β≤ 1. The β-packing number of G, β-pack(G), equals the maximum cardinality of a β-packing set in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a graph G = (V, E), a set S ⊂ V is a β-packing set of a graph G if S is a proper, maximal set having the property (which we call the β-packing property ) that for all vertices v ∈ V-S, 
    |N(v) ∩ S|≤β |N(v)|

     for some 0 < β≤ 1. The β-packing number of G, β-pack(G), equals the maximum cardinality of a β-packing set in G.

sentence:
Let λ be a partition and let μ be a strict partition.
The Schur function of λ, the Schur S-function 
of λ, and the Schur Q-function of μ are then the respective sums

    s_λ = ∑_T x^T,      S_λ = ∑_U x^U,
     
    Q_μ = ∑_V x^V

where T runs over all semistandard tableaux of shape λ,
U runs over all semistandard marked tableaux of shape λ,
and V runs over all marked semistandard shifted tableaux of shape μ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The type A Stanley symmetric function associated to w ∈ A_n = S_n+1 is  

    _w  = ∑_∈(w)∑_(i_1 ≤ i_2 ≤⋯≤ i_l) ∈() x_i_1x_i_2⋯ x_i_l

where for a reduced word = (s_a_1, s_a_2,⋯, s_a_l), the set () consists of all weakly
increasing sequences of positive integers i_1≤ i_2 ≤…≤ i_l
such that if a_j > a_j+1 then i_j < i_j+1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The type C Stanley symmetric function associated to w ∈ C_n is

    _w  = ∑_∈(w)∑_(i_1 ≤ i_2 ≤⋯≤ i_l) ∈() 2^| { i_1,i_2,…,i_l}| x_i_1x_i_2⋯ x_i_l

where for a reduced word = (t_a_1,t_a_2,⋯ ,t_a_l), the set () consists of all weakly
increasing sequences of positive integers i_1≤ i_2 ≤…≤ i_l
such that if a_j-1 < a_j > a_j+1 for some j ∈ [l-1] then either i_j-1 < i_j ≤ i_j+1
or i_j-1≤ i_j < i_j+1.

For each y ∈(W) = { z ∈ W : z=z^-1} let 
 (y) be the set of elements w ∈ W with minimal length such that w^-1∘ w = y.
 The elements of this set are the atoms of y.

sentence:
The type A and type C involution Stanley symmetric functions 
associated to y ∈(A_n) and z ∈(C_n) are 
_y  = ∑_w ∈(y)_w and _z  = ∑_w ∈(z)_w, respectively.

sentence:
An element w ∈ C_n is a quasi-atom if
the following conditions hold:


  (a) One has w_1>0 and _±(w_2w_3⋯ w_n) ∈_n-1, so (w) is defined.

  (b) At most one 
block {a,b}∈(w) has 0<a<w_1<b.


  (c) No symmetric
block {± c }∈(w) has 0<w_1<c.


A quasi-atom w is  odd  if no block
{a,b}∈(w)
exists with 0<a<w_1<b;
otherwise, w is even .
We write _n^+ and _n^- for the sets of even and odd quasi-atoms in C_n,
and define _n  = _n^+ ⊔_n^-.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let E be a set of n elements
and ℬ a family of r-element subsets of E. 

A combinatorial representation of (E,ℬ) over a set X
is defined to be an n-tuple of functions f_i:X^r→ X such that,
for any r distinct indices i_1,…,i_r∈ E, the map from
X^r to X^r given by

    (x_1,x_2,…,x_r)↦ (f_i_1(x_1,…,x_r),…, f_i_r(x_1,…,x_r))

is bijective if and only if {i_1,…,i_r}∈ℬ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
* l is a loop if no basis contains l, that is, ℬ(l)=∅.

    
  * l_1 and l_2 are parallel if each can be replaced by the other in a basis, that is, ℬ(l_1)=ℬ(l_2).

    
  * The subset I of E is dependent if no basis contains I.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph and M be a maximum matching of G. If X⊂ V(G) is a set of vertices of G,
then the M-even-reachable set of X, R_e(X,M), is the set of vertices that can be reached from
X through an M-alternating path of even length. Similarly, the M-odd-reachable set of X, 
R_o(X,M), is the set of vertices that can be reached from X through an M-alternating 
path of odd length.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A k-uniform hypergraph H=(V,E) is k-partite if there exists a partition of V into k disjoint subsets, V_1, …, V_k, such that each edge in E contains exactly one vertex from each V_i.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A site-island is a triangulation with simple boundary

together with a site-percolation configuration such that 


  (i) all the outer vertices are black,

  (ii) all the inner edges incident to an outer vertex are also incident to a white inner vertex.

Examples are given in Figure <ref> below and Figure <ref> (left).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A bond-island is a triangulation with simple boundary, together with a bond-percolation configuration such that 


  (i) all the outer edges are black,

  (ii) all the inner edges incident to an outer vertex are white.

See Figure <ref> for an example.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The restricted nonnegative rank of a nonnegative matrix M is the minimum value of k such that there exists U ∈ℝ^m × k_+ and V ∈ℝ^k × n_+ with M = UV and (U) = (M), i.e., (U) = (M). It is denoted _+^*(M).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let f_1,…,f_s,g ∈ℝ[x_1,…,x_n].

A subset of ℝ^n is basic semialgebraic if it is on the form { f_1 ≥ 0, …, f_s ≥ 0, g ≠ 0 } and semialgebraic if it is a finite union of basic semialgebraic sets.

A subset of ℝ^n is basic closed semialgebraic if it is on the form { f_1 ≥ 0, …, f_s ≥ 0}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given polynomials g_1,…,g_m ∈ℝ[x_1,…,x_n], the quadratic module generated by g_1,…,g_m is defined by:

    QM(g_1,…,g_m) = {σ_0 + ∑_i=1^m σ_ig_i | σ_0,…,σ_m  are sums of squares} .
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A quadratic module QM(g_1,…,g_m) is Archimedean if

    N - ∑_i=1^n x_i^2 ∈QM(g_1,…,g_m)

for some N ∈ℕ.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A matrix ∗-algebra is a collection of matrices closed under addition, scalar and matrix multiplication, and transposition.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒢 be a permutation representation graph of Γ.
A fracture graph ℱ of Γ is a subgraph of 𝒢 containing all vertices of 𝒢 and  one edge of each label, chosen in such a way that each i-edge joins two vertices a_i and b_i that are in distinct Γ_i-orbits.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A crystal of dimension r+1 is a nonempty set  not containing 0 together with crystal operators e_i, f_i  :  →∪{0} for i=1,2,…,r and a weight map : →Λ satisfying the conditions
  
  
  * for b,b^'∈, e_i(b)=b^' if and only if f_i(b^') = b, and in this case we have (b^') = (b) + α_i;
  
  * for b∈ and i=1,…,r, we have _i(b) = ((b)_i - (b)_i+1) + _i(b), where _i, _i : →ℤ are
    
    _i(b)     =    max{k ∈ℤ_≥ 0| e_i^k(b) ≠ 0 }, 
    _i(b)     =    max{k ∈ℤ_≥ 0| f_i^k(b) ≠ 0 }.

  
  We call _i(b), _i(b) the string lengths through b, with _i(b) the i-tail and _i(b) the i-head.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The character of a crystal  is the polynomial
  
    ch() = ∑_b ∈ B x_1^(b)_1 x_2^(b)_2⋯ x_r+1^(b)_r+1.

sentence:
Given two crystals _1 and _2, the tensor product _1 ⊗_2 is the set _1 ⊗_2 together with crystal operators e_i, f_i defined on the tensor product _1 ⊗_2 by
  
    f_i(b_1 ⊗ b_2) = {[     f_i(b_1) ⊗ b_2 _i(b_2) < _i(b_1),;     b_1 ⊗ f_i(b_2)  _i(b_2) ≥_i(b_1), ].

  and weight function (b_1 ⊗ b_2) = (b_1) + (b_2), where addition is taken coordinate-wise.

sentence:
The Schur polynomial indexed by the partition λ is given by
  
    s_λ (x_1,…,x_n) = ∑_T ∈_n(λ) x_1^(T)_1⋯ x_n^(T)_n,

  where _n(λ) denotes the set of all semistandard Young tableaux of shape λ with largest entry at most n, and (T) is the composition whose ith part is the multiplicity with which i occurs in T.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a positive integer i, define lowering operators , denoted by f_i, on semistandard Young tableaux as follows: if m_i(w(T)) = 0, then f_i(T)=0; otherwise, let p be the smallest index such that m_i(w(T),p) = m_i(w(T)), and set f_i(T) to change the entry in T corresponding to w_p to i+1.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a positive integer i, define raising operators , denoted by e_i, on semistandard Young tableaux as follows: let q be the largest index such that m_i(w(T),q) = max_r(m_i(w(T),r)). If q=k, then e_i(T)=0; otherwise, set e_i(T) to change the entry in T corresponding to w_q+1 to i.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For T a shifted tableau, the hook reading word of T , denoted by w(T), is the word obtained by reading the marked entries of T up the ith column, then the unmarked entries of T along the ith row, left to right, for i from max(γ_1,ℓ(γ)) to 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let i ≥ 1 be an index and T a semistandard shifted tableau.  A pair of entries y,x of T, with y ∈{i+1,i+1} and x ∈{i,i} are i-paired if y occurs before x in the hook reading word of T and every entry i, i, i+1, i+1 that lies between them in the hook reading word is i-blocked. The i-paired entries become i-blocked, and we continue the operation recursively till there are no more possible i-pairs. An entry i,i,i+1,i+1 of T is i-free if it is not part of an i-pair.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

    f_0(b_1 ⊗ b_2) = {[         f_0(b_1) ⊗ b_2 (b_2)_1 = (b_2)_2 = 0,;         b_1 ⊗ f_0(b_2)                      . ].

sentence: The queer lowering operator , denoted by f_0, acts on semistandard shifted tableaux by: if T has no cell labeled 1 or if T has a cell labeled 2, then f_0(T)=0; otherwise f_0(T) changes the rightmost 1 in the first row of T to 2 if it is on the main diagonal and to 2 otherwise.

sentence: The queer raising operator , denoted by e_0, acts on semistandard shifted tableaux by: if T has no cell labeled 2 and the leftmost entry of the first row is not 2, then e_0(T)=0; otherwise e_0(T) changes the leftmost 2 in the first row of T, if it exists, or the leftmost entry in the first row, otherwise, to 1.

sentence: Let A be a strictly increasing one-line array of positive integers, and let x be a positive integer not occurring in A. Define the insertion of x into A , denoted by A x←, as follows: if x > z for all z∈ A, place x at the end of A and set y = ∅; otherwise, let y denote the smallest element of A such that y>x (we say that x bumps y), replace y by x in A.

sentence:
Let T be an injective Young tableau, and let x be a positive integer not occurring in T. Let T_i be the ith lowest row of T. Define the insertion of x into T , denoted by T x←, as follows. Set x_0=x and for i≥ 0, insert x_i into T_i+1, set x_i+1 to be the bumped letter, and
  
  
  * if x_i+1 is nonempty, continue;
  
  * otherwise, if no letter is bumped, stop.
  
  The insertion tableau of a permutation w, denoted by P(w), is the standard Young tableau obtained by beginning with the empty tableau and successively inserting the letters of w.
  
  The recording tableau of w, denoted by Q(w), is the standard Young tableau with entry i in the unique cell of P_i / P_i-1, where (∅ = P_0,P_1,…,P_n = P(w)) is the sequence of tableaux created when inserting w.

sentence: A lie restriction R is a condition on binary strings.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Renyi-Ulam game with lie restriction R is played as follows.

There are two players: the Seeker and the Obscurer. The Obscurer thinks of a number between 1 and n. The Seeker wishes to identify that number.

On each turn, the Seeker asks the Obscurer whether her number belongs to a specific subset of the numbers from 1 to n. The Obscurer answers either yes or no, and her answer is either true or false. On every turn, the series of truths and lies given by the Obscurer thus far must belong to R.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Renyi-Ulam game with lie restriction R

sentence:
A lie restriction graph G for a lie restriction R is a directed graph G such that:



  * One vertex in G is called a start vertex .

  * Every arc in G is labeled either 0 or 1.

  * Every vertex in G originates at least one and at most two outward arcs. Of those, at most one arc is labeled 0 and at most one arc is labeled 1.

  * A binary string s satisfies R if and only if there is a path l in G such that l starts from the start vertex and the arc labels along l trace out s.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A position is a mapping from the vertices of G to the nonnegative integers.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The support of a position P is the number of vertices v of G such that P(v) is nonzero.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The weight of a position P is the sum of P(v) over all vertices v of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P, P_1, and P_2 be three positions. We say that (P_1, P_2) is a split of P if there exist two positions Q_0 and Q_1 such that



  * For all vertices v of G, P(v) = Q_0(v) + Q_1(v).

  * For all vertices v of G, P_1(v) is the sum of Q_0(u) over all vertices u of G such that a 0-arc in G points from u to v.

  * For all vertices v of G, P_2(v) is the sum of Q_1(u) over all vertices u of G such that a 1-arc in G points from u to v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A strategy-like tree is a binary tree such that its vertices are positions and every non-leaf vertex P has two children that form a split of P. A strategy-like tree for a position P is a strategy-like tree rooted at P.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A strategy tree is a strategy-like tree whose every leaf has weight either zero or one. A strategy tree for a position P is a strategy tree rooted at P.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A lie restriction R is regular if the set of all strings that satisfy R is a regular language.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The two-string game for a lie restriction R is played between two players as follows. The starting position is given by two binary strings u_1 and u_2. On each turn, the Obscurer extends one of u_1 and u_2 (that is, appends a character to it) and the Seeker replies by extending the other. The Seeker's goal is that one of the two strings ceases to satisfy R (it does not matter whether this happens following a move by the Seeker or the Obscurer) and the Obscurer's goal is to prevent this.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that S_1 is expanded by S_2 if S_1 contains a substring of every string in S_2.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The risk of a string p is the length of the longest suffix of p that is a prefix of an element of S. When p is of risk l and the l-suffix of p is an l-prefix of q ∈ S, we say that p is of risk l via q. The risk of a position P in the two-string game for R is the maximum of the risks of the two strings that comprise P.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The l-flip of a string p = a_1a_2 … a_m of length m ≥ l + 1 is the string a_1a_2 … a_la_l + 1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G = (𝒱,E) be a subset partition graph of 𝒜 on the symbol set S, and let F ⊆ S be a collection of symbols. We define a new subset partition graph G_F = (𝒱_F, E_F) of 𝒜_F on the symbol set S' := S. 

We define 𝒜_F := {A ∈𝒜 : F ⊆ A}. That is to say, 𝒜_F is obtained by deleting from 𝒜 (and the containing 𝒱_i) any d-set A which does not contain F. This deletion from the vertices in 𝒱 may make some of them empty. The vertex set 𝒱_F consists of those vertices in 𝒱 which are still non-empty, and two vertices in 𝒱_F are connected by an edge in E_F exactly when the associated vertices were connected in E. The subset partition graph G_F is called the restriction of G with respect to F.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Fix a finite set S of cardinality n and a set 𝒜⊆Sd of subsets. Let G = (𝒱,E) be a connected graph with vertex set 𝒱 = {𝒱_0,…,𝒱_t}. If 𝒱 is a partition of 𝒜 in the sense that:


  * 𝒜 = 𝒱_0 ∪⋯∪𝒱_t,

  * 𝒱_i ∩𝒱_j = ∅ if i ≠ j, and

  * 𝒱_i ≠∅ for all i,

then we say that G is a d-dimensional subset partition graph of 𝒜 on the symbol set S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Restriction]
Let G = (𝒱,E) be a subset partition graph of 𝒜 on the symbol set S, and let F ⊆ S be a collection of symbols. We define a new subset partition graph G_F = (𝒱_F, E_F) of 𝒜_F on the symbol set S' := S. 

We define 𝒜_F := {A ∈𝒜 : F ⊆ A}. That is to say, 𝒜_F is obtained by deleting from 𝒜 (and the containing 𝒱_i) any d-set A which does not contain F. This deletion from the vertices in 𝒱 may make some of them empty. The vertex set 𝒱_F consists of those vertices in 𝒱 which are still non-empty, and two vertices in 𝒱_F are connected by an edge in E_F exactly when the associated vertices were connected in E. The subset partition graph G_F is called the restriction of G with respect to F.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be a maximal spanning forest of G, f ∈  F, and e ∈ E ∖ F.   The fundamental cut associated with F and e cutcycle is
 
    U_F(e) =    {the edges of the unique cut in (E ∖ F) ∪ e}.


Similarly, the fundamental cycle associated with F and e is 

    Z_F(e) ={the edges of the unique cycle in F∪ e}.

sentence:
Let G = (V,E) be a graph with a total order on E, and F be a maximal spanning forest of G.  We say that an edge e ∈ E is spanning forest


  * internally active (e ∈I(F)) with respect to F if e∈ F and it is the smallest edge in U_F(e),

  * externally active (e ∈E(F)) with respect to F if e∉F and it is the smallest edge in Z_F(e).




We note that all bridges are internally active and all loops are externally active.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let ℱ⊂ E. If there exists no e ∈ E ∖ℱ such that e is contained in a non loop cycle in e ∪ℱ, we say that ℱ is a flat of G. A flat is cyclic if it is a union of cycles. forest
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G = (V,E) be a graph with a total order on E, and S ⊂ E, then we say that an edge e is


  * internally active present with respect to S (e ∈ I(S)∩ S) if e∈ S and e is the smallest edge in some cut in S^c ∪ e,

  * internally active absent  with respect to S (e ∈ I(S)∩ S^c)  if e∉ S and e is the smallest edge in some cut in S^c,

  * externally active present  with respect to S (e ∈  L(S)∩ S) if e∈ S and e is the smallest edge in some cycle in S,

  * externally active absent  with respect to S (e ∈L(S)∩ S^c) if e∉ S and e is the smallest edge in some cycle in S ∪ e.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Gessel-Sagan <cit.>]
  Let < be a total order on the vertices of G, and F be a spanning tree of G rooted at the smallest vertex q.  Let e = (u,v) be an edge of G ∖ F.  We say that e is depth-first search externally active (DFS externally active), and write e∈ E_DFS(F), if either u=v, or (u,w) is an oriented edge in F belonging to the unique cycle in F ∪ (u,v), and w>v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: depth-first search externally active (DFS externally active)

sentence:
[Bernardi <cit.>]  Let (G,σ, h) be a rooted combinatorial map, T a spanning tree of G, and e an edge of G.




  * The edge e is embedding-internally active (e ∈ I_B(T)) if e ∈ T and e is the minimum edge with respect to <_T in its associated fundamental cut.


  * The edge e is embedding-externally active (e ∈ E_B(T)) if e ∉ T and e is the minimum edge with respect to <_T in its associated fundamental cycle.

sentence:
activity
A decision tree D for G consists of a perfect binary tree, i.e., a rooted tree such that all non-leaf nodes have two descendants, and a labeling of each node of the tree by elements of E such that the labels along any particular branch give a permutation of E.

sentence: Let Ø be an orientation of the edges of G.  Let Z be a cycle in G, and U = (X,X^c) be a cut in G.  We say that Z is a directed cycle if we can walk around the cycle traveling in the direction of the edge orientations.  We similarly define U to be a directed cut if all of its edges are, without loss of generality, oriented from X to X^c.

sentence:
[Las Vergnas <cit.>] activityorientationactivity!orientationorientation!reference
 Let G = (V,E) be a graph with a total order on E, and  Ø_ref a reference orientation of the edges of G.  If Ø is an orientation of G and e ∈ E, then we say e is


  * positive cut active (e ∈ I(Ø)^+)  if e is the smallest edge in some directed cut and is oriented in agreement with Ø_ref,

  * negative cut active (e ∈ I(Ø)^-) if e is the smallest edge in some directed cut and is oriented in disagreement with Ø_ref,

  * positive cycle active (e ∈ E(Ø)^+) if e is the smallest edge in some directed cycle and is oriented in agreement with Ø_ref,

  * negative cycle active (e ∈ E(Ø)^-) if e is the smallest edge in some directed cycle and is oriented in disagreement with Ø_ref.

sentence:
Let A⊆ℤ^d as before. Let f=⊕_i∈ A p_i ⊙ w^i
∈[w_1,…, w_d] be a tropical polynomial. Let q be a point in the
tropical hypersurface 𝒯(f). Then, q is a singular point of
𝒯(f) if there is a polynomial F=∑_i∈ A a_i x^i ∈[x_1^±1, …, x_d^± 1] and a point b∈ (𝕂^*)^d such
that val(a_i)=p_i, val(b)=q and b is a singular point of the algebraic
hypersurface V(F) defined by F. If 𝒯(f) has a singular point, we
call it a singular tropical hypersurface .

sentence:

an integral affine function. The Euler derivative offwith respect toLis the tropical polynomial

    ∂ f/∂ L= ⊕_i∈ A, L(i) ≠0 p_i ⊙
    w^i.

sentence:
Let F=∑_i∈ A a_i x^i ∈𝕂[x_1^±1, …, x_d^± 1]
and L=j_1 w_1+…+ j_d w_d +$̱ be an integral affine function. We associate
toLthe Euler vector fieldL_Θ= j_1 Θ_1 + …+ j_d Θ_d +
$̱, where Θ_j = x_j ∂/∂ x_j for all j=1, …,
d. The Euler derivative of F with respect to L is the polynomial

    ∂ F/∂ L:= L_Θ(F) = j_1 x_1∂
    F/∂ x_1+… + j_dx_d∂ F/∂ x_d +F̱.

sentence:
Let q be in the interior of a cell σ^* ⊆𝒯(f). We
define the flag of f with respect to q as the flag of subsets
ℱ(q) of A defined inductively by: F_0(q)=σ⊊
F_1(q)⊊…⊊ F_r(q), dim ⟨  F_r(q) ⟩ =d,
and for any ℓ:
F_ℓ+1(q) - F_ℓ(q) is the subset of A- ⟨ F_ℓ(q)⟩ where
the tropical polynomial ⊕_i∈ A - ⟨ F_ℓ(q)⟩  p_i
⊙ w^i attains its minimum at q. The weight class of the flag
ℱ(q) are all the points q'∈𝒯(f) for which
ℱ(q) =ℱ(q')

sentence:
Let f=⊕_i∈ A_1 p^1_i ⊙ w^i, g= ⊕_i∈ A_2 p^2_i
⊙ w^i be two tropical polynomials in [w_1, w_2]. Let q be a point in
the intersection of the tropical curves 𝒯(f)∩𝒯(g).
Then q is a non-transversal (or non-smooth) intersection point of
𝒯(f) and 𝒯(g) if there exists two Laurent polynomials
F =∑_i∈ A_1 a^1_i x^i, G = ∑_i∈ A_2 a^2_i x^i in
𝕂[x_1,x_2], with respective supports A_1, A_2 and a point b∈
(𝕂^*)^2 which is a non-transversal intersection of {F=0} and
{G=0} such that Trop(F)=f (that is, val(a^1_i)=p^1_i for all i ∈
A_1), Trop(G) = g and val(b) =q.

sentence:
Let k, r and ℓ be integers.
A graph F on n vertices is called (k,r,ℓ)-decomposable if there exist k graphs F_i with the following properties. Every edge of F appears in exactly r of the F_i 
and there are maps g_i F_i → [n], which are injective homomoprhisms from F_i into P_n^ℓ. 
Then we denote by _k,r,ℓ(n) the family of (k,r,ℓ)-decomposable graphs on n vertices.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
[(k,r,ℓ)-decomposable graphs]
Let k, r and ℓ be integers.
A graph F on n vertices is called (k,r,ℓ)-decomposable if there exist k graphs F_i with the following properties. Every edge of F appears in exactly r of the F_i 
and there are maps g_i F_i → [n], which are injective homomoprhisms from F_i into P_n^ℓ. 
Then we denote by _k,r,ℓ(n) the family of (k,r,ℓ)-decomposable graphs on n vertices.

sentence:
Given any (multi-)graph Γ and a parameter Δ∈_0,
        we define an augmented multigraph Γ^Δ as follows.
        We add a new, special, vertex v_∞ to the vertex
        set of Γ.
        Furthermore we add Δ many edges v v_∞
        for every v ∈ V(Γ).
        If Δ = 0 then we add one additional edge s
        v_∞ for every sink s of Γ; this way we ensure that
        v_∞ is the only sink of Γ^Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[(good phases)]
     Let k ∈ [m].
     We say that k is a good phase of the augmented process if,
     using the notation from Lemma <ref>,
     
         
  * k is visited, so that k = ϕ_j for some j,
         
  * the pivot at time σ_j has color r, and
         
  * the position S_σ_j does not contain any point from the
             layer _r-1.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and let X ⊂ V(G) satisfy |X| =k ≥ 2. We say G[X] is a chain of sausages of order k in G if 

G. (V(G)∖ X ) is a doubled cycle (of length k+1).  
If G[X] is a chain of sausages of order at least 3 and x,x' ∈ X are adjacent, then the operation of identifying x and x' to a new vertex is called a sausage shortening .  If G' is obtained from G by repeatedly performing sausage shortenings until this operation is no longer possible, we call G' a sausage reduction of G.  We say that G is sausage reduced if it has no sausage of order at least 3 (so no sausage reduction is possible).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If G is a graph and X,Y ⊆ V(G) are disjoint, a segmentation of G relative to (X,Y) is a family of nested sets X_1 ⊂ X_2 ⊂ X_3 …⊂ X_k satisfying:


  * X_1 = X and V(G) ∖ X_k = Y

  * |X_i+1∖ X_i| = 1 for 1 ≤ i ≤ k-1

We say that the segmentation has width k if d(X_i) = k holds for every 1 ≤ i ≤ k and we call it an (a,b)-segmentation if |X| ≤ a and |Y| ≤ b.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph, let X ⊆ V(G), let e ∈δ(X), and let x be the endpoint of e in X.  We say that X is almost cubic relative to e if d(x) ∈{3,4} and d(u) = 3 for every u ∈ X ∖{x}.

sentence:
Given a finite 3-free set A⊂_0, let S(A) be the Stanley sequence generated by A and S(A,x)=|{ s∈ S(A): s≤ x}| be its counting function. Then, for any ϵ>0 and x≥ x_0(ϵ, A),

    S(A,x)≥( √(2)-ϵ) √(x).

sentence:
Let X = { x_1, …, x_m } and Y = { y_1,…, y_m}
be subsets of the natural numbers, written so that x_1 < x_2 < …
< x_m and y_1 < y_2 < … < y_m. We say that Y majorizes X,
and write X ≼ Y, if x_i ≤ y_i for each i.

sentence:
A set family of shape 
(m^n) is a 
collection of n distinct m-subsets of the natural
numbers. A set family 𝒫 is
closed if whenever Y ∈𝒫 and X ≺ Y, then
X ∈𝒫.

sentence:
Let 𝒫 be a
set family of shape (m^n) and type λ.
We say that 𝒫 is minimal if 
there 
is no 
set family 𝒬
of shape (m^n) and type μ with μλ.

sentence:
An indexed set partition of shape (m^n) and type λ
is a set partition of A(λ) into n sets each of size m.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒫 be a set family of shape (m^n) and type λ.
Order the sets making up 𝒫 lexicographically,
so that 𝒫 = {X_1, …, X_n} where X_1 < X_2 < ⋯ < X_n.
The indexed set partition associated to 𝒫
is 
the indexed set partition of type λ
obtained
by appending indices to the elements of the sets X_1, …, X_n 
so that the elements of X_1 all get the index 1, and
an element i ∈ X_r is given the smallest index not appended to
any i appearing in X_1, …, X_r-1.

sentence:
Let A be a subset of the natural numbers. The downset
of A, denoted A^≼, is the set family consisting
of all subsets X such that X ≼ A.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[R. Rado, <cit.>] We say that a graph P is a path iff there is a well ordering ≺ on V(P) such that 
    {w∈ N_P(v):w≺ v} is ≺-cofinal below  v
 for all v∈ V(P).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a path P and x≺_P y∈ P let P [x,y) denote the segment of P from x to y (excluding y) i.e. the graph spanned by {z∈ V(P):x≤_P z≺_P y}. For a set A and path P we say that P is concentrated on A iff 
    N(y)∩ A ∩ V(P[x,y))≠∅
 for every ≺_P-limit y∈ P and x≺_P y in P.

sentence:
We call a graph G=(V,E) κ-complete iff |V|≥κ and 
    |V N_G(x)|<κ
 for all x∈ V.
