sentence:
A k-ordering of a graph H assigns distinct order-labels from the set 
{1,…,|H|} to k vertices in H.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a graph H and a vertex v ∈ H, the (v, l)-ordering of H for some l between 1 and |H|, inclusive, is the 1-ordering of H in which v is assigned order-label l.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A 2-coloring on n vertices is a set of n vertices between every two of which is either a red or a blue edge. Additionally, the 2-coloring is said to be ordered if every vertex has a unique integer from 1 to n assigned to it, indicating the order-label of the vertex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given an ordered 2-coloring G and a k-ordering H, we say that G contains H if there exists a copy of H in G that satisfies the following properties:


  * The edges in the copy of H are all the same color. (monochromatic)


  * The ith smallest-labeled vertex in the copy of H either has order-label i in H or no order-label in H. (order-preserving)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given an ordered 2-coloring G and a k-coloring H, we say that G avoids H if G does not contain H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: The ordered Ramsey number R_<(H_1,H_2) of a k-ordering H_1 and a j-ordering H_2 is the smallest number n such that any ordered 2-coloring on n vertices must contain a red copy of H_1 or a blue copy of H_2. As a shorthand, R_<(H, H) is denoted by R_<(H).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let H be a k-ordered graph for any k ≥ 0. Define H^+ as the (k+1)-ordered graph with vertex set H ∪v, where v has order-label 1 and all order-labels in H are increased 1, and with edge set H ∪{(v,u):u∈ H}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph G=(V,E) with loops is called an anti-regular graph with loops if all vertices of G have distinct degrees.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a graph G=(V,E), an ordering < of V(G) is said to be a proper vertex ordering if for u,v,w∈ V(G)  such that u<v<w, uw∈ E(G)⇒ uv,vw∈ E(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a graph G=(V,E), an ordering < of V(G) is said to be a transitive vertex ordering if for u,v,w∈ V(G) such that u<v<w,


  * uv,vw∈ E(G)⇒ uw∈ E(G), and

  * uw∈ E(G)⇒ uv∈ E(G) or vw∈ E(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An ordered graph G_< is called a semi-comparability graph , if it has no 4 vertices a,b,c,d∈ V(G_<) such that a<b<c<d and ab,bc,cd∈ E(G_<), but ac,bd∉E(G_<).

An unordered graph G is said to be a semi-comparability graph, if its vertex set has a total ordering < such that G_< is a semi-comparability graph.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A double-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2 is called magical if for any three distinct vertices a,b,c∈ V(G) with a<_1b<_1c, if ab,bc∈ E(G) and ac∉E(G), then b<_2a and b<_2c.

A graph G is said to be magical, if there exist two total orders <_1,<_2 on V(G) such that G_<_1,<_2 is magical. In this case, we say that the pair (<_1,<_2) witnesses G.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is called double-magical , if there exist two magical graphs G^1_<_1,<_2 and G^2_<_1,<_3 on V(G)  such that  E(G_<_1,<_2,<_3)=E(G^1_<_1,<_2)∩ E(G^2_<_1,<_3). An unordered graph G is said to be double-magical, if there exist three total orders <_1,<_2,<_3 on V(G) such that the triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is double-magical. We say that G is witnessed by (<_1,<_2,<_3).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The dual graph Γ_(k,n) of Sturmfels' triangulation of Δ_k,n is the graph whose
vertices are the maximal simplices, and two maximal simplices are adjacent by an edge if they share a common facet.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An oriented Young graph is the graph that is obtained from a Young diagram after rotating it in 180 degrees and orienting each horizontal edge from left to right and each vertical edge from bottom to top.
We call the vertex that is in the lower right corner the origin vertex , and denote the upper right
(lower left) vertex by v_1 (v_0). There are two paths that start at v_0, continue along the border and end at
v_1. The path that passes through the origin vertex is called inner path , and the second path is called
outer path . From now on, we denote the set of the vertices appear in the outer path by V.
See Figure <ref> for an example.


    < g r a p h i c s >

An oriented Young graph. Its inner boundary path is formed by the edges labeled from 1' through 7'.
Its outer boundary path is formed by the edges labeled from 1 through 7, and all the vertices that appear along the latter path form the collection V.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: oriented Young graph;origin vertex;inner path;outer path

sentence:
Let H be an oriented Young subgraph of G_k,n, and let u be the origin vertex.
The swapping distance between u and V is max{i+j-1 | (i,j) ∈ H}.

sentence:
Let r be an integer, 1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n, and denote by H_i,j,r the affine hyperplane {x_i+x_i+1⋯ + x_j =r}⊂^n. Fix a point x ∈^n. For y ∈^n, we say that H_i,j,r separates y from x if one of the following holds:

  
  * x and y lie in the two disjoint halfspaces formed by H_i,j,r.
  
  * y lies on H_i,j,r and x does not.

Define  d_ij(x,y)=|{r| the hyperplane  H_i,j,r separates  y  from  x}|.

Finally, let   B_r(x)={y|d_ij(x,y) ≤ r  for all  1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n }.

sentence: A partial element of G_n is a triple (C,(x;k),C'), where k is an integer between 1 and n, C (resp. C') is a left (resp. right) class of K_n^k in K_n and x∈ G_k.

sentence:
A pair of partitions (λ,δ) is proper if the partition λ is proper. For a proper pair (λ,δ) of partitions and for any integer n≥ |λ|+|δ|, we define (λ,δ)^↑^n to be the following pair of partitions with size n (that means the sum of sizes of both partitions is equal to n) :

    (λ,δ)^↑^n:=(λ∪ (1^n-|λ|-|δ|),δ).

This defines a bijection between the set of proper pairs of partitions with size less or equal to n and the set of pairs of partitions with size n.

sentence:
[n-cube antichains]

Let n be  a positive integer. A subset S of the unit n-cube [0, 1]^n is called an n-cube antichain if S does not contain two elements 𝐱=(x_1, x_2,…, x_n) and 𝐲=(y_1, y_2,…, y_n) satisfying 
x_i≤ y_i for all i∈ [n].

sentence:
[(n,k,t)-sets] Fix positive integers n,k,t such that n≥ k>t. A 
subset A of the unit n-cube [0,1]^n is called an (n,k,t)-set if every (x_1,…,x_n)∈ A has exactly k coordinates that are strictly positive and for every two elements (x_1,…,x_n), (y_1,…,y_n)∈ A, there exists t distinct indices i_1,…,i_t ∈ [n] 
such that x_i_j=y_i_j>0 for j ∈ [t].

by the following algorithm.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let T be a genomic tableau with entries i_j. We call i the gene family and j the gene . First, we say T is semistandard if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the genes is semistandard (that is, each gene family forms a horizontal strip);

  * Within each gene family, the genes form a Pieri strip.

We say the K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, …, c_r) if c_i is the max-content of the Pieri strip of genes in the i-th gene family. Finally, we say T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every repeated gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot.

sentence:
Let z be a non-contractible closed curve in C_p,q. Consider the homeomorphism of C_p,q obtained by cutting C_p,q along z and gluing it back after rotating the inner boundary by 2π. This homeomorphism is called a Dehn twist .
We have chosen a counter-clockwise orientation of our surface, so when applying a positive Dehn twist, we rotate the inner boundary ∂' of the annulus clockwise by 2π (Fig. <ref>). A negative Dehn twist would be a rotation of ∂' by 2π in the counter-clockwise direction.

The path algebra of Q is the ℂ-vector space 
    R⟨ Q ⟩ = ⊕_l = 0^∞ A^l.

sentence:
The complete path algebra of Q is the ℂ-vector space R⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩ consisting of all possibly infinite linear combinations of paths in Q, that is: 
    R⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩ = ∏_l = 0^∞ A^l.

sentence: Let Q be a quiver. An element W of R ⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩ is called a potential if it is a possibly infinite linear combination of cycles of Q such that no two cycles appearing in W with non-zero coefficients can be obtain from each other by rotation. If W is a potential on Q, we say that the pair (Q,W) is a quiver with potential, or a QP.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Q, Q' be quivers with the same vertex set Q_0 = Q_0'. 


  * Two potentials W and W' on Q are cyclically equivalent if W-W' lies in the closure of the vector subspace of R ⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩ spanned by all the elements of the form α_1 …α_l - α_2 …α_l α_1 with α_1 …α_l a cycle of positive length.


  * We say that two QPs (Q,W) and (Q',W') are right-equivalent if there exists a ℂ-algebra isomorphism ϕ : R ⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩→ R ⟨⟨ Q' ⟩⟩ satisfying ϕ(e_i) = e_i ∀ i ∈ Q_0 = Q_0' and such that ϕ(W) is cyclically-equivalent to W'.


  * For each arrow α∈ Q_1 and each cycle α_1 …α_l in Q we define the cyclic derivative 
    ∂_α(α_1 …α_l) = ∑_k=1^lδ_α,α_kα_k+1⋯α_l  α_1 ⋯α_k-1
 and extend ∂_α by linearity and continuity so that ∂_α(W) is defined for every potential W.


  * The Jacobian ideal J(W) is the topological closure of the two-sided ideal of R ⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩ generated by {∂_α(W) | α∈ Q_1 }, and the Jacobian algebra P(Q,W) is the quotient algebra R ⟨⟨ Q ⟩⟩ / J(W).


  * A QP is trivial if W ∈ A^2 and {∂_α(W) | α∈ Q_1 } spans A as a ℂ-vector space.


  * A QP is reduced if the degree-2 component of W is 0, that is, if the expression of W involves no 2-cycles.


  * The direct sum Q ⊕ Q' is the quiver whose vertex set is Q_0 = Q_0' and whose arrow set is the disjoint union Q_1 ⊔ Q_1'.


  * The direct sum of two QPs (Q,W) and (Q',W') is the QP (Q,W) ⊕ (Q',W') = (Q ⊕ Q', W+W').

sentence:
[Duffin <cit.>, Dirac <cit.>]
  Series-parallel graphs are graphs that arise from a forest by
  repeatedly applying the following operations:

  
  
  * add a parallel edge to an existing edge and subdivide this new edge
    (this is the parallel extension );
  
  * subdivide an edge (this is the series extension ).

sentence:
* A finite graded lattice is Eulerian if
		any non-trivial interval has the same number of elements of odd and of even rank;
		it is interval-connected if the proper part of any interval of length at least 3 is connected.
		
  * A CW-sphere is regular if the attaching maps of the cells are homeomorphisms also
		on the boundary. The sphere has the intersection property if 
		the intersection of any two cells is a single cell (which may be empty).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Components of type T_3,T_4 or T_5,1 that are contained in a white face, and components of type T_3,T_4,T_5,2, as well as pairs of triangles of type T_3,1 contained in a black face, are called exceptional components .
Consider G∈ P_m, and let f_1,f_2 be two faces of the same color, such that f_1 has at least two boundary components.
By choosing f_1 to be the outer face, we may think of G as a planar graph.


 
    < g r a p h i c s >

 These are the 7 types of exceptional components. They are the components that contribute to the automorphism terms, and that receive special treatment in the flattening process



If f_2 does not belong to an exceptional component, we define a flattening from f_2 to f_1 as the operation of taking all of the connected components of G surrounded by f_2, and moving them, together with the parts of G in the planar region they bound, to the interior of f_1. If f_2 is exceptional, all of the connected components of G surrounded by f_2, except for one component, are moved to f_1, together with the parts of G in the planar region they bound. If f_2 surrounds several components, not all of whom are triangles, then one of the non-triangular components remains in f_2. In particular, if f_2 is a white triangle that surrounds a black triangle as well as a non-triangular component, then we leave a non-triangular component in f_2.

If f_2 is a white triangle and also a connected component of size three that surrounds more than one component, all of whom are triangles, then we view f_2 together with one of the triangles it surrounds as a component of type T_3,1. In this case, we move all but two of the triangles f_2 surrounds to f_1.




We say that a graph G ∈ P_m is flat if G has a white face f_w and a black face f_b such that


  * The faces of G surround at most two components, except possibly f_w and f_b.

  * If f ∉{f_b,f_w} is a face of G that surrounds two components, then f is a white triangle surrounding two black triangles.

  * The remaining faces that surround a component belong to exceptional components.

sentence:
Given a graph H with a cut vertex v, let H'_1,…,H'_κ be the connected components of H-{v}.
The split of H at v is the set of graphs {H_1,…,H_κ}, where H_j=H[V(H'_j)∪{v}].

sentence:
Let (G) denote the set of independent sets of a graph G.
The Parity Generalised Independent Set problem 
(λ,μ)
is defined as follows, where the parameters λ and μ are natural numbers.

Name: (λ,μ).

Input: A graph G.

Output: 
Z_λ,μ(G) = ∑_J∈(G)λ^|J|μ^|V(G)∖ J| 2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
A hardness gadget in a graph H
is a tuple (β,s,t,O,i,K,k,w) 
where β is a positive integer,
s, t and i are vertices of H,
(O,{i},K) is a partition of Γ_H(s), and
k K → and w K → V(H)
are functions.
The following conditions must be satisfied.


  *  |O| is odd.

  *  For any o∈ O and y∈ O∪{i}, s is the
  unique vertex that is adjacent to o and y and has an odd number
  of β-walks to t.

  *  There are an even number of (1+β)-walks from
  i to t.

  *  For all u∈ K, w(u) has an even number of k(u)-walks to u 
and an odd number of k(u)-walks to every vertex in O∪{i}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a hardness gadget (β,s,t,O,i,K,k,w) in H and a vertex v∈ V(H).
The primary distance requirement of the gadget with respect to v
is

    _H(v,O∪{i}) + _H(v,t) > β-1.

The secondary distance requirement of the gadget with respect to v
is that, for each u∈ K,

    _H(v,w(u))+_H(v,O∪{i,u}) >k(u)-2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A partial hardness gadget in a rooted graph (H,x)  
is a tuple (s,i,O,P)
where  
s is a vertex of H,
({i},O) is a partition of Γ_H(s), and P is a path in H 
satisfying the following conditions.


  * |O| is odd.

  * P is the unique shortest path from x to i in H.

  * Ps is the unique shortest path from x to s in H.

  * For each o∈ O, Pso
is the unique shortest path from x to o in H.

sentence:
A mosaic is a rooted graph  defined as follows.  


  * An unbristled mosaic is the one-vertex rooted graph or a rooted cactus graph that is a union of 4-cycles.

  * A mosaic
is a rooted graph (H,x) 
for which there is a 
partition (V',V”) of V(H) such that x is in V',
(H[V'],x) is an unbristled mosaic,
and  E(H)-E(H[V']) is a perfect matching between
V” and a subset of V'.
The edges of the matching are called bristles .

  * A proper mosaic is a
mosaic that contains at least one cycle.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A 2,3-path in a rooted graph (H,x) is a tuple
    (P,v_2,v_3) such that v_2 and v_3 are in the same cycle
    of H and that, for j∈{2,3}, _H(v_j)=j and
    Pv_j is the unique shortest x–v_j path in H.

sentence:
Let P=x_1… x_ℓ+1 be a path in a graph H.  We define the
following three sets of (ℓ+2)-walks from x_1 to x_ℓ+1.



  * T_1(P) is the set of walks that differ from P by going the
  long way around a (2r+2)-cycle from which P uses r consecutive
  edges, as shown in Figure <ref>.  Formally, these
  are the walks x_1… x_aP'x_b… x_ℓ+1, where 1≤
  a<b≤ℓ+1 and x_aP'x_b is a (b-a+2)-path in H-{x_a+1,
  …, x_b-1}.

  * T_2(P) is the set of walks that differ from P by going the
  long way around cycles of length 2r+1 and 2r'+1, from which
  P uses r and r' consecutive edges, respectively, as shown in
  Figure <ref>.  Formally, these are the x_1…
  x_aP'x_b… x_a'P”x_b'… x_ℓ+1 where 1≤ a<b≤
  a'<b'≤ℓ+1, x_aP'x_b is a (b-a+1)-path in H-{x_a+1,
  …, x_b-1} and x_a'P”x_b' is a (b'-a'+1)-path in
  H-{x_a'+1, …, x_b'-1}.

  * T_3(P) is the set of walks x_1… x_azx_a… x_ℓ+1,
  where 1≤ a≤{ℓ+1} and z∈Γ_H(x_a) (we allow the
  case z=x_a± 1).


We refer to the cycles appearing in the definition of T_1 and T_2
as detour cycles .

sentence:
A shortcut in a mosaic (H,x)  
is a pair of odd-degree vertices v_1,v_2, with degree at least 3, that
have a unique shortest path P between them, and this path does not
contain x.
A shortcut mosaic is a mosaic that contains a
shortcut.

sentence:
Say that a homomorphism π from H to H (an endomorphism of H)
is orbit-preserving if π(v)∈_H(v) for every v∈
V(H).
Let ^⋆(H,H) be the set of orbit preserving endomorphisms
of H.

sentence:
Let Γ=(β,s,t,O,i,K,k,w) be a hardness gadget in a graph H and let G be any graph.  We
construct the graph G_Γ as follows.  
Let V”={v_e | e ∈ E(G)} and
begin with the graph G'=(V',E')
where
 V' = V(G) ∪ V(H) ∪ V” (these three sets are assumed to be
disjoint) and E'=E(H).
To G', add the following:


  * for every vertex x∈ V(G), the edge (x,s);

  * for every edge e=(x,y)∈ E(G), the edges (x,v_e) and (y,v_e);

  * for every edge e∈ E(G), a new β-path P_t,e from t to v_e; and

  * for every vertex x∈ V(G) and every u∈ K, a new k(u)-path P_x,u from x to w(u).

In G_Γ,
we refer to vertices that are in V(G) as G-vertices and
those in V(H) as H-vertices . 
Figure <ref>
illustrates the construction.

sentence:
Given a matrix A∈ℳ_∞(𝒜) the
  shifted matrix s(A) of A is
the diagonal blocked matrix formed by the identity
matrix of size 1× 1 and A, that is

    s(A)=
      [ 1  ;   A ].

sentence:
Given  a lower triangular matrix T_0∈ℳ_∞(𝒜)
  the left iterated matrix
  T_0^L corresponding to T_0 is the infinite (from right to left) product

    T_0^L=⋯  s^3(T_0) s^2(T_0) s(T_0) T_0.

It is clear that this product converges to a lower triangular matrix.
Similarly, the right iterated matrix
  T_0^R corresponding to T_0 is the lower triangular matrix
given by the infinite (from left to right) product

    T_0^R=T_0 s(T_0) s^2(T_0) s^3(T_0)⋯.

We say that a matrix A∈ℳ_∞(𝒜)
admits a periodic Gaussian elimination process if there exist
a lower triangular matrix T_0∈ℳ_∞(𝒜) such that
T_0^LA is upper triangular.
In this case T_0 is called a fundamental sequence
of the Gaussian elimination process of A.

sentence:
Let A, A' be matrices with entries in a partial field .
  
    
  * If A' can be obtained from A by repeatedly scaling rows and columns by elements of , then we say that A and A' are scaling-equivalent .
    
  * If A' can be obtained from A by repeatedly scaling rows or columns, permuting rows, permuting columns, or pivoting, then we say that A and A' are geometrically equivalent .
    
  * If ϕ(A') is geometrically equivalent to A for some partial-field automorphism ϕ, then we say that A' and A are algebraically equivalent .

Let  be a partial field, M a matroid, X a basis of M, Y := E(M)∖ X, S⊆ X, T⊆ Y, and N := M S  T.
	If, for all X× Y -matrices A_1, A_2 such that
	
		
  * M = M[I  A_1] = M[I  A_2]
		
  * A_1[X∖ S,Y∖ T] is scaling-equivalent to A_2[X∖ S,Y∖ T],
	
	we have that A_1 is scaling-equivalent to A_2, then we say that N stabilizes M.

sentence: Let M be a matroid and let (X_1,X_2) and (Y_1,Y_2) be 2-separations of M. If X_i ∩ Y_j≠∅ for all i,j ∈{1,2}, then we say that (X_1,Y_1) and (X_2,Y_2) cross .

sentence: Let 𝒩 be a set of matroids. A matroid M is 𝒩-fragile if, for all e ∈ E(M), at least one of M e and M e has no minor isomorphic to a member of 𝒩. Moreover, an 𝒩-fragile matroid M is strictly 𝒩-fragile if some minor of M is isomorphic to a member of 𝒩.

sentence:
Let R be a d-representation on a vertex set V, and consider the edge set E of Σ(R) defined by E = { X ∈Σ(R) : |X| = 2}.
    	We define the matrix A_R of _ E ×1d , V ×1d-1()
    	where the coefficients, a_(e,i),(v,j) of A_R are indexed by an edge e∈ E, a vertex v∈ V, and two indices i ∈1d and j ∈1d-1.
    
    a_(e={x,y},i),(v,j) = 
        
        +1     if i=j, v ∈ e and v = max_≤_j (x,y)
    
        -1     if i=j, v ∈ e and  v = min_≤_j (x,y)
    
        +1     if i = d, v ∈ e and  v = min_≤_d (x,y)
    
        -1     if i = d, v ∈ e and  v = max_≤_d (x,y)
    
        0     otherwise

    The TD-Delaunay system of the representation R is the following linear system of inequalities :
	
    A_R X > 0

	for some vector X ∈^V ×1d-1.

	A multi-flow is a collection of d flows φ_1, …, φ_d respectively on each digraph G^1(R), … , G^d(R) such that _φ_i(v) = _φ_d(v), for every v∈ V and every i ∈1d.

sentence:
The Dushnik-Miller dimension of a poset (≤,V) is the minimum number d such that (≤,V) is the intersection of d linear extensions of (≤,V). This means that there exists d extensions (≤_1,V), … , (≤_d,V) of (≤,V) such that for every x,y ∈ V, x ≤ y if and only if x ≤_i y for every i ∈1d.
     In particular if x and y are incomparable with respect to ≤, then there exists i and j such that x ≤_i y and y ≤_j x.

sentence:

	A straight line embedding of Δ in ^d is a mapping f : V →^d such that

sentence:
[Kostochka et al. <cit.>]

Consider an n-vertex (d+1)-uniform hypergraph H such that every d-tuple of vertices is contained in at most t=O(1) edges,
and apply the following procedure:


  * let X be the subset of vertices obtained by choosing each vertex independently at random with probability p, such that
pn = ( n/(t logloglog n) )^3/(3d-1),

  * remove the minimum number of vertices of X so that the resulting subset Y induces a triangle-free linear[A hypergraph is linear if it has no pair of distinct edges sharing two or more vertices.] hypergraph H[Y].

Then with high probability H[Y] has an independent set of size at least ( n/tlogn/t)^1/d.

Let ρ G_[k]→𝔽 and β_i  G_I_i→𝔽, i ∈ [m] be multilinear forms. Write ℐ = {i ∈ [m]  I_i = [k]}. Let B = {x_[k]∈ G_[k] (∀ i ∈ [m]) β_i(x_I_i) = 0} and let B^0 = {x_[k]∈ B ρ(x_[k]) = 0}. Let H be another 𝔽-vector space and let ϕ B^0 → H be a multilinear map , i.e., a map such that whenever x_[k], y_[k]∈ B^0 differ in a single coordinate then ϕ(x⊖ y) = ϕ(x) - ϕ(y). Suppose that for each λ∈𝔽^ℐ

    _x_[k]χ(ρ(x_[k]) + ∑_i ∈ℐλ_i β_i(x_[k])) < 1/2k^2𝐟^-(2k^2 + k + 1) (m + 1)2^2k+3.

Then, for each z_[k]∈ B ∖ B^0 and h_0 ∈ H, there is a unique multilinear map ϕ^ext B → H such that ϕ^extB^0 = ϕ and ϕ^ext(z_[k]) = h_0.

Let the set Cov be

    Cov:= { (α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2)∈ S_d×⋯× S_d | β^-1α^-1βα = γ_1⋯γ_2g-2,


    γ_i ⟨α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2⟩ } .
 
There is an equivalence relation ∼ among elements in Cov: 

    (α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2) ∼ (α', β', γ'_1, …, γ'_2g-2 )
 if and only if there exists τ∈ S_d
such that τ (α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2) τ^-1 = (α', β', γ'_1, …, γ'_2g-2).
Moreover, let N = |Cov/∼| denote the cardinality of the set Cov modulo the equivalence relation.

sentence:
A run r of a (linear or circular) permutation σ is an interval [i  j] such that σ(i) ≷σ(i+1) ≷…≷σ(j) is a monotone sequence, either increasing or decreasing, and so that it cannot be extended in either direction; its length is defined to be j-i.
  If σ is a permutation of an n-element set, the collection of the lengths of all runs gives a partition p of n-1 (linear permutations) or n (circular permutations).
  The partition p is called the run structure of σ.

sentence:
Let H be an arbitrary fixed hypergraph. Let = (p_r)_r ≥ 1 be any sequence
such that 0 ≤ p_r = p_r(n) ≤ 1 for each r ≥ 1. Let  denote the family of all strong subgraphs of H.


  (a) If for some H' ∈ we have μ_s(H') → 0 (as n →∞), then a.a.s. (n,) does not contain H as a strong subgraph.

  (b) If for all H' ∈  we have μ_s(H') →∞ (as n →∞), then a.a.s. (n,) contains H as a strong subgraph.

Moreover, if there exists >0 such that p_r ≤ 1-, for all r, then the conditions above determine whether or not H appears as an induced strong subgraph.

sentence:
A simple diagram is parametrized by two parameters, a word  with entries in {r,c},
and a natural number n. 

The family of simple diagrams are constructed recursively as follows:

 
  * If = ∅, then (,n) is the n× n-square.
 
  * The diagram (c,n) is obtained from (,n) by adding 
 an additional column of size n on the left, such that the bottom-most 
 square of the new column is in the bottommost row of (,n).
 
  
  * The diagram (r,n) is obtained from (,n) by adding 
 an additional row of size n on the bottom, such that the left-most 
 square of the new row is in the leftmost column of (,n).

sentence:
In a fixed border-strip decomposition, a border-strip B_a is above a border-strip B_b if there is 
a path from B_a to B_b going only down or right. In this case B_b is below B_a.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A border-strip B_a is inner to a border-strip B_b if there exists a sequence B_a=B_1,B_2,…,B_k=B_b such that for all i B_i is above B_i+1. This means the relation inner is the transitive closure of the relation above .

If B_a is inner to B_b, B_b is outer to B_a.

Two border strips B_a and B_b are comparable , if B_a is inner or outer to B_b.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Two border strips B_1 and B_2 in a decomposition 
form an inversion if the following three conditions are fulfilled:

 
  * The content-sequences of B_1 and B_2 have a non-empty intersection,
 
  * B_1 is inner to B_2, and
 
  * B_1>B_2.

sentence:
Given a border-strip decomposition of a simple diagram,
the unique strip with head in diagonal i is referred to as strip i .

sentence:
A bipartite graph G is called a Salem graph if the largest eigenvalue 
λ_1 is greater than 2, and the remaining n-1 eigenvalues are no greater than 2. Then λ_n=-λ_1<-2.  A bipartite Salem graph is called trivial if λ_1^2∈ℤ.  The associated number τ(G) is the larger root of √(z)+1/√(z)=λ_1; this is a Salem number unless G is trivial.

A non-bipartite graph G is called a Salem graph if the largest eigenvalue  λ_1 > 2 and the remaining n-1 eigenvalues are in the interval [-2,2]. A non-bipartite Salem graph is called trivial if λ_1∈ℤ.  The associated number τ(G) is the larger root of z+1/z=λ_1; this is a Salem number unless G is trivial.

A subset Δ = {α_1, α_2, …, α_r }⊂Φ is a set of simple roots if every root in β∈Φ can be written uniquely as
 
    β = c_1 α_1 + c_2 α_2 + ⋯ + c_r α_r

sentence:
A partition of the highest root α̃ in Φ^+ is a multiset {β_1, β_2, …, β_k} = Γ such that β_i∈Φ^+ for all 1≤ i≤ k and α̃ = β_1+β_2 + ⋯ + β_k.  
The elements β∈Γ are called the parts of the partition Γ.

sentence:
[The Rule of Three for sums vs. products]

Let R be a ring, and let
v_1, …, v_N ∈ R and g_1, …, g_N∈R,
with g_1,…,g_N potentially invertible.
Then the following are equivalent:


  * [∑_i ∈ Sv_i, g_S] = 0 for all subsets
  S⊂{1,…,N};

  * [∑_i ∈ Sv_i, g_S] = 0 for all subsets
S of cardinality ≤ 3.

sentence:
[The Rule of Three for products vs. products
    and sums]

Let R be a ring, [3]
and let g_1,…, g_N, h_1,…, h_N∈ R be potentially invertible. 

Then the following are equivalent:
 

  * [g_S, h_S]=[g_S, ∑_i ∈ Sh_i]=0 for all subsets S⊂{1,…,N};

  * [g_S, h_S]=[g_S, ∑_i ∈ Sh_i]=0 for all subsets S of cardinality ≤ 3.

sentence:
[The Rule of Three for products vs. sums and quadratic forms]

Let R be a ring.
Let v_1, …, v_N ∈ R and g_1, …, g_N∈ R,
with g_1,…,g_N potentially invertible.
Then the following are equivalent:


  * g_S  e_ℓ(𝐯_S) = e_ℓ(𝐯_S)  g_S for all subsets
  S⊂{1,…,N} and ℓ≤ 2;

  * g_S  e_ℓ(𝐯_S) = e_ℓ(𝐯_S)  g_S for all subsets
S of cardinality ≤ 3 and ℓ≤ 2.

sentence:
[The Rule of Three for products vs. elementary symmetric functions]

Let R be a ring.
Let v_1, …, v_N ∈ R and g_1, …, g_N∈ R,
with g_1,…,g_N potentially invertible.
Then the following are equivalent:


  * g_S  e_ℓ(𝐯_S) = e_ℓ(𝐯_S)  g_S for all subsets
  S⊂{1,…,N} and all ℓ;

  * g_S  e_ℓ(𝐯_S) = e_ℓ(𝐯_S)  g_S for all subsets
S of cardinality ≤ 3 and all ℓ.

sentence:
Let 𝒜=⟨ u_1, …, u_M, v_1, …, v_M⟩
be the free associative -algebra with generators u_1,…, u_M, v_1,…, v_M.
Let g_1, …, g_N, h_1, …, h_N be elements of 𝒜[[x,y]],
i.e., some formal power series in x and y with coefficients in 𝒜.
We say that the Multiplicative Rule of Three holds for 
  g_1,…,g_N,h_1,…,h_N if for any quotient ring
R=𝒜/I, the following are equivalent:


  * g_S h_S ≡ h_S g_S  I  for all subsets S⊂{1,…,N};

  * g_S h_S ≡ h_S g_S  I  for all subsets S of cardinality ≤ 3.

sentence:
Let M be a monoid.
A subset M'⊂ M is called potentially invertible
if M can be embedded into a larger monoid in which all elements of M'
have left and right inverses (necessarily equal to each other);
see <cit.>.
Similarly, a subset R' of a ring R is potentially invertible
if R can be embedded into a larger ring in which all elements of R' are invertible.

By abuse of terminology, we say
that elements g_1,…,g_N
of a monoid (or ring) are potentially
invertible if {g_1,…,g_N} is a potentially invertible subset.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Fix an integer w≥ 0 and j∈{ 1,…,w } and let the diagonals through (0,0) and (w+2,0)
be referred to as the left and the right diagonal, respectively.

Let L_j(n,w,ℓ) be the q-enumeration of north-east paths L from

    (w+1-j,0)  to  (n+w+1-j,n-1)

with the property that there are ℓ points on the path L, p_1,p_2,…,p_ℓ, appearing in this order from the start,
such that the odd-indexed p_i lie on the left diagonal, and the even-indexed p_i are points on the right diagonal.

Similarly, define R_j(n,w,ℓ) be the be the q-enumeration of north-east paths in (<ref>),
such that there are ℓ points p_1,p_2,…,p_ℓ on the path
with the even-indexed p_i being on the left diagonal,
and the odd-indexed p_i being points on the right diagonal.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Y ⊆ X be a set of combinatorial objects and C_n = ⟨ g ⟩
be a cyclic group acting on X.
Let f(q) ∈[q] with non-negative coefficients, such that f(1)=|Y|.
Then (Y ⊂ X ,C_n,f(q)) is a subset cyclic sieving phenomenon if
for every k∈ [n] we have

    f(ω_n^k) = |{ y∈ Y : g^k · y = y }|.

sentence:
Throughout the paper by an infinite surface  we mean a connected oriented surface  


  - of a finite genus,

  - with finitely many interior marked points (punctures),

  - with finitely many boundary components, 

  - with infinitely many boundary marked points, located in such a way that they have only finitely many accumulation points of boundary marked points.  
 
 Accumulation points themselves are also considered as boundary marked points.

By an admissible hyperbolic structure on an infinite surface  
we mean a locally hyperbolic metric such that
 

  - all boundary arcs are complete (i.e. bi-infinite) geodesics, and

  - all interior marked points are  cusps.


A surface with admissible hyperbolic structure will be called an admissible hyperbolic surface.

sentence:
[Infinite mutation, infinite sequence of infinite mutations] 

Consider a triangulation T={γ_i| i∈}  of an infinite surface .


  * An elementary mutation μ is a flip of an arc in T, see Fig. <ref>.

  * A finite mutation μ_n∘…∘μ_1 is a composition of finitely many flips for some n∈. We will use the notation μ^(0) to refer to  a finite mutation.

  * An infinite mutation is the following two step procedure:


  -  apply an admissible infinite sequence of elementary mutations …∘μ_2∘μ_1,  where a sequence is admissible if for every γ∈ T there exists n=n(γ)∈ such that ∀ i>n, we have μ_i∘…∘μ_2∘μ_1(γ)=μ_n∘…∘μ_2∘μ_1(γ);

  - complete the resulting collection of arcs by  all limit arcs (if there are any).

We will use the notation μ^(1) to specify an infinite mutation.

  * A finite sequence of infinite mutations μ^(1)_n∘…∘μ^(1)_1 is a composition of finitely many admissible infinite mutations μ^(1)_i for i=1,…,n for some n ∈. We will use the notation  to specify a sequence of n infinite mutations.

  * An infinite sequence of infinite mutations is the following two step procedure:


  -  apply an admissible infinite composition of infinite mutations …∘_2∘_1,  where a composition is admissible  if the orbit of every individual arc converges, i.e.
the sequence of arcs {_i+j∘…∘_i+2∘_i+1(γ) }, for j ≥ 1, converges for every arc 

γ∈⋃_i=0^∞[_i∘…∘_2∘_1(T)], for i ≥ 0;

  -  complete the resulting collection of arcs by  all limit arcs (if there are any).

We will use the notation  to specify an infinite sequence of infinite mutations.

sentence:
[Bad arcs for a given triangulation] 
For an arc γ∈ and a triangulation T of , we say γ is a bad arc for T if |γ∩ T|=∞. We denote by _T T' the set of all arcs of T' which are bad for the triangulation T.
We also denote by |_T T'| the cardinality of this set (which may be infinite).

sentence: Let p be a left (resp. right) accumulation point of boundary marked points of a surface  and T be a triangulation of . A p-domain (resp. p-domain ) of T is an almost elementary domain of T containing infinitely many marked points accumulating to p from the left (resp. right). We will denote a p-domain (resp. p-domain) of T by ^T_p or simply by _p (resp. ^T_p or _p). When there is no need to specify which side the accumulation point p is approached from, we will use the simplified notation _p.

[Fan triangulations, incoming/outgoing fan triangulations]

T is a finite union of almost elementary fan domains;

  * an incoming (resp. outgoing) fan triangulation if all almost elementary domains are incoming (resp. outgoing) fans.

sentence:
A perfect matching P of an infinite staircase snake graph  is a set of edges of  such that each vertex in  is incident to precisely one edge in P and an edge of a limit tile is in the perfect matching if one of the following applies:


  - a limit tile G_lim is followed by a regular tile G_∗ and the edge between G_lim and G_∗ is in the matching of G_∗;

  - limit edge condition: if G_lim is a limit tile of the tiles G_i, for i∈,  and there exists k∈ such that an edge
of G_i at the position Y∈{I,II,III,IV} is in P for all i>k, then the edge of G_lim at the position Y is also in P, see Example <ref>.

sentence:
The intersection graph G_ associated to an arrangement
={B_1, …, B_n} of d-boxes is the graph with vertices
V={1, …, n} and such that {i,j} is an edge if and only if B_i
∩ B_j ≠∅.

Conversely, given a simple undirected graph G, we can define its
boxicity (G): it is the smallest integer d such that
there exists an arrangement of d-boxes  whose intersection graph
is G.

sentence:
We say that the box Q∈ is exposed by the hyperplane H
for the arrangement  if 
=0pt

  * H is a supporting hyperplane of Q which is parallel to some
coordinate hyperplane. 

  * For any P∈ such that P∩ H=∅, P and Q
do not lie in the same half-space defined by H. 

We call H an exposing hyperplane for Q.

Let a>0 and assume that each round a newly sampled Erdős-Rényi random graph G(n,a/n) is the underlying graph. Then for the rumor spreading time of Pull , T_n, we have
 
    E[T_n]=log_2-e^-a(n) + 1/aln(n) + 𝒪(1)
 
and there are constants A,α>0 such that for all r,n ∈ 
    P[|T_n-E[T_n]| ≥ r ] ≤ A exp(- α r).

sentence:
Let a>0 and let γ:=2(1-e^-a)-(1-e^-a)^2/a. Assume that each round a newly sampled Erdős-Rényi random graph G(n,a/n) is the underlying graph. Then for the rumor spreading time of Push&Pull , T_n, we have
 
    E[T_n]=log_1+γ(n) + 1/aln(n) + 𝒪(1)
  
and there are constants A,α>0 such that for all r,n ∈

sentence: Let Γ be a connected G-vertex-transitive graph, let v be a vertex of Γ and let L be a permutation group which is permutation isomorphic to G_v^Γ(v). Then (Γ,G) is said to be locally-L . More generally, if  is a  permutation group property, then (Γ,G) will be called locally- provided that G_v^Γ(v) possesses the property .

sentence:
A transitive permutation group L is graph-restrictive if there exists a constant
c(L) such that, for every locally-L pair (Γ,G) and an arc (u,v) of Γ, the
inequality |G_uv|≤ c(L) holds.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p be a prime. A transitive permutation group L is p-graph-restrictive if there exists a constant
c(p,L) such that, for every locally-L pair (Γ,G), the largest p-th power dividing the order of an arc-stabiliser is bounded above by c(p,L).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For S,T ∈𝒮(G) we use S∼ T to denote

    S ∖ (Î(S) ∪L̂(S)) ⊆ T ⊆ S ∪Î(S) ∪L̂(S).

Lemma <ref> guarantees that ∼ is an equivalence relation on 𝒮(G). Observe that the equivalence class to which S ∈𝒮(G) belongs is [ S ∖ (Î(S) ∪L̂(S)), S ∪Î(S) ∪L̂(S)], an interval in the poset of spanning subgraphs 𝒮(G) ordered by containment. This partition of 𝒮(G) into intervals was first demonstrated by Crapo <cit.>, so we refer to the equivalence classes of subgraphs under ∼ as Crapo intervals .

sentence:
(<cit.>)
Let O ∈𝒪^4(G). We say a directed cut Cu of G is a potential cut of O if for δ∈{+,-},  e^δ∈𝔼(Cu) ⇒ e^-δ∉ O. Similarly, a directed cycle Cy of G is a potential cycle of O if for δ∈{+,-}, e^δ∈𝔼(Cy) ⇒ e^δ∈ O. In other words, a potential cut of a fourientation is the same as a directed cut of an orientation except that some edges of the cut are allowed to be unoriented; and a potential cycle of a fourientation is the same as a directed cycle of an orientation except that some edges of the cycle are allowed to be bioriented.

sentence: Consider a bipartite graph G=(P,Q) and some 0<β<1. For each q∈ Q, let N(q) denote the set of neighbors of q in P. We say a vertex q∈ Q is β-nondegenerate with respect to P if |N(q)∩ N(q')|<β |N(q)| for any q'∈ Q, q'≠ q (otherwise q is β-degenerate). We say G is a β-nondegenerate graph if every vertex of Q is β-nondegenerate.

sentence:
Let P be a set of finite points in ^3. Given positive integers s,t, we say a  is a good s-dimensional family with respect to P with complexity t in ^3 if 


  * Each element of  is an algebraic surface in ^3 of degree at most t.

  * The parameter space of  is a s-dimensional subvariety of ^t+3 3, the space of all degree t polynomials in three variables.

  * Any two surfaces in  intersect at at most one irreducible curve.

  * Let Γ denote the set of all intersection curves between two surfaces in , then Γ belongs to a family of curves with s-1 degrees of freedom and multiplicities at most t, i.e. for any tuple of s-1 points in P there are at most t curves in Γ passing through all of them.

    p = (v_0, v_1, …, v_n+m-1, v_n+m)      with      v_0 = v_n+m
 
 satisfying v_k-1 v_k if π_k = 0, otherwise v_k-1 v_k.

sentence:
A face in the cylindric poset is a set of four vertices (u ; v1, v2 ; w) satisfying
u  v1  w and u  v2  w.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cylindric growth diagram with profile π∈(n,m) is a subset of cylindric diagram 𝔊(n,m) which lies below a path with profile π (refered to as the upper boundary), whose vertices are labelled by integer partitions, and whose faces are labelled by non-negative integers, in such that the following three conditions are satisfied:



  * If v  w, and if λ is the integer partition labelling the vertex v and μ is the integer partition labelling the vertex w, then λ / μ is a horizontal strip.

  * All but finitely many vertices are labelled with the same integer partition γ.

  * If ( u; v1, v2; w) is a face with label ℓ, and if the labels of u, v1, v2 and w are μ, α, β and λ respectively then:

    𝔘_α,β(ℓ,μ) = λ
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let H be a graph and let G be a cubic graph. Then G is called an inflation of H if G contains a 
2-factor F consisting of chordless cycles such that the graph obtained from G by contracting each cycle of F to a vertex is isomorphic to H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An edge contraction is a surjective simplicial map f K→ L between
simplicial complexes such that every vertex of L has only one preimage, apart
from one vertex, whose preimage is an edge, v*w (written here as the join of
its vertices).
We call f an elementary edge-zipping if any of the following equivalent
conditions hold:



  * (v)∩(w)=(v*w);

  * v*w is not contained in any “missing face” of K, i.e. in
an isomorphic copy of ∂Δ^n in K that does not extend to
an isomorphic copy of Δ^n in K;

  * the PL map triangulated by f is collapsible.


We say that a simplicial complex K edge-zips onto a simplicial complex L
if there exists a sequence of elementary edge-zippings K=K_0→…→ K_n=L.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a poset. Suppose that a p∈ P covers two incomparable elements q,r∈ P so that: ∙ if s

q and s>r, then s≥ p. In this situation P is said to elementarily zip onto the quotient of P by the subposet {p,q,r}. (See concerning quotient posets.) A zipping of posets is a sequence of elementary zippings.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An affine simplicial complex is a finite set 𝒦 of non-empty
affine simplices in some ^d such that


  * if σ∈𝒦 and τ is a non-empty face of σ, then
τ∈𝒦;

  * if σ,τ∈𝒦, then σ∩τ∈𝒦.

The simplices of 𝒦 form the face poset K=(𝒦,)
with respect to inclusion.

An affine simplicial complex is called flag if every subcomplex of K
whose face poset is isomorphic to ∂Δ^S, |S|>2, is the boundary
of some simplex σ∈𝒦.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An affine cone complex is a family 𝒫 of
subcomplexes of an affine simplicial complex 𝒦 such that


  * for each σ∈𝒫, all maximal simplices of σ
(i.e. those simplices of σ that are not faces of other simplices
of σ) share a common vertex, denoted σ̂;

  * for each σ∈𝒫, the set ∂σ of all
simplices of σ disjoint from σ̂ is a union of elements
of 𝒫;

  * if σ,τ∈𝒫 and σ̂=τ̂, then
σ=τ.

The cones (i.e. the elements) of 𝒫 form its face poset
P=(𝒫,) with respect to inclusion.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An element σ of a poset P is called an atom of P, if
σ={σ}.
The set of all atoms of P will be denoted A(P).
A poset P is called atomic, if every its element is the least upper bound
of some subset of A(P).
[In the literature on lattice theory such posets are called “atomistic”,
whereas “atomic” has a different meaning.
Our usage of the term can be found e.g. in <cit.>.]
It is easy to see that A(σ)=A(P)∩σ.
Hence every element σ of an atomic poset is the least upper bound of
A(σ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A simplicial poset is a conditionally complete poset where every cone is
isomorphic to a simplex.
(Compare <cit.>.)
A simplicial cone complex is abbreviated to a simplicial complex.
The cones of a simplicial complex K are thus called its simplices.
Clearly, every simplicial complex is atomic.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let P=(𝒫,≼) be a preposet.
A chain in P is a 𝒬𝒫 that is a totally ordered
by ≺ (that is, for each p,q∈𝒬 either p≺ q or
p≽ q; note that this already implies that ≼ is transitive on
𝒬).
The poset P^♭ of all nonempty finite chains of P ordered by inclusion is
a subcomplex of Δ^𝒫 and so a simplicial poset (a simplicial
complex if P is countable); it is called the barycentric subdivision
of P.

Clearly, if Q is a closed subposet of a poset P, then Q^♭ is a full subcomplex
of P^♭.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A flag complex is a simplicial complex K such that every subcomplex of
K that is isomorphic to the boundary of a simplex of dimension >1 is
the boundary of some simplex of K.
Obviously, every full subcomplex of a flag complex is a flag complex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
By a cubosimplicial complex we mean a conditionally complete cone complex
where every cone is isomorphic to a product of simplices.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If P=(𝒫,≤) is a [pre]poset and
a,b∈𝒫 are such that a≤ b, the interval [a,b] is
the sub[pre]poset a∩ b={c∈ P| a≤ c≤ b} of P.
If P is a poset, we define the canonical subdivision P^# of P to be
the poset of all intervals of P ordered by inclusion.

In the general case some additional care is needed.
We say that an interval [a,b] is pre-included in an interval [c,d] and
write [a,b]⋐[c,d] if a∈ [c,d] and b∈ [c,d].
When P is a poset, this is just the usual inclusion relation.
In general, ⋐ is a reflexive acyclic relation on the set of all intervals
of P (the latter set is really just the relation ≤ which officially is
a subset of 𝒫𝒫).
We define the canonical subdivision P^# of P to be the preposet of
all intervals of P ordered by pre-inclusion.

We note that the canonical subdivision of every poset is an atomic poset.
If P is a conditionally complete poset, then so is P^#.
Clearly, (P^*)^#≃ P^# and (P Q)^#=P^# Q^# for
all preposets P and Q.
It follows that (C^*(P*Q))^#=(C^*P)^# (C^*Q)^# and in particular,
(P*Q)^#=(C^*P)^# Q^#∪ P^# (C^*Q)^#.

Beware that if Q is a full subposet of P, then Q^# need not be full in P^#.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The poset I^S(2^S)^# is called
a cube or the S-cube; or the n-cube (notation: I^n)
if S=[n].
Note that 
    I^S=(C^*Δ^S)^#≃(C^*(S*Δ^0))^#=
    (∏_S C^*Δ^0)^#=∏_S(C^*Δ^0)^#=∏_S I^1.

In particular, I^S⊔ T≃ I^S I^T by an isomorphism natural
in S and T.

A cubical poset is a conditionally complete poset where every cone is
isomorphic to a cube.
(Compare <cit.>.)
A “cubical cone complex” is abbreviated to a cubical complex.
Cones of a cubical complex are thus called its cubes.
Closed subposets of a cubical complex will be termed its subcomplexes.
By the above, the product of two cubical complexes is a cubical complex.
Every cubical complex is atomic, since every cube is.

In contrast to Theorem <ref>, not every cubical complex is isomorphic to
a subcomplex of a cube.
For instance, the simplicial complex ∂Δ^2, which also happens
to be a cubical complex, is not isomorphic to any subcomplex of any cube,
as it contains “a cycle of odd length”.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An affine polytopal complex (compare <cit.>) is a countable conditionally complete poset K where to every
σ∈ K there is associated an isomorphism of σ with
the poset of non-empty faces of a convex polytope P_σ (compare
Example <ref>) so that every face inclusion τσ
is realized by an affine isomorphism between P_τ and the face of
P_σ corresponding to τ.
This includes cubical and simplicial complexes as special cases.
Every affine polytopal complex is atomic since the poset of nonempty faces of
every convex polytope is.
Affine polytopal complexes are not equivalent to “cell complexes” in the sense
of Rourke–Sanderson <cit.>, who additionally require linear embeddability
into some Euclidean space.
For instance, the cubulation of the Möbius band into 3 squares is an
affine polytopal complex (and a cubical complex) but not a cell complex
in the sense of <cit.> (see <cit.>).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P=(𝒫,≤) be a poset, A=(𝒜,≤) a subposet of P
and f A→ Q a monotone map, where Q=(𝒬,≤) is a preposet.
We recall that the adjunction set 𝒫∪_f𝒬 is
the set-theoretic pushout of the diagram
𝒫⊃𝒜f𝒬, that is, the quotient of
𝒫⊔𝒬 by the equivalence relation generated by
a∼ f(a) for all a∈𝒜.

We define the adjunction preposet P∪_f Q to be the preposet
P∪_f Q=(𝒫∪_f𝒬,≤), where q≤ q' in P∪_f Q
if there exist p∈ [q] and p'∈ [q'] such that p≤ p'.
It is easy to see that this relation is reflexive and acyclic
(given a nontrivial cycle in P∪_f Q, it can be shortened to a cycle
in Q using that P is a poset).
It is also clear that P∪_f Q is the pushout of the diagram
P⊃ Af Q in the category of preposets.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a subposet Q of a poset P, it is easy to see that the adjunction
preposet P∪_c pt, where f Q→ pt is the constant map, is a poset.
We call it the quotient poset and denote P/Q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
If A and B are subposets of posets P and Q, respectively, and
h A→ B an isomorphism, then the amalgam P∪_h Q, also written
P∪_A=BQ when h is clear from context or irrelevant, is the adjunction
preposet P∪_jh Q, where j B→ Q is the inclusion.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a monotone map of posets f P→ Q, the mapping cylinder
MC(f)=P[2]∪_f_1Q and the dual mapping cylinder
MC^*(f)=P[2]∪_f_2Q, where f_i is the composition
P{i}≃ PfQ.
Note that MC^*(f)≃ (MC(f^*))^* and that there are natural monotone
bijections (which are not embeddings) MC(f)→ Q+P and MC^*(f)→ P+Q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose we have a covariant [resp. contravariant] commutative diagram,
indexed by a poset Λ, consisting of posets P_λ=(𝒫_λ,≤),
λ∈Λ, and monotone maps f_λμ P_λ→ P_μ whenever
λ>μ [resp. λ<μ] in Λ.
Then the homotopy colimit _Λ (P_λ,f_λμ)
is the preposet Q=(𝒬,≤), where
𝒬=_λ∈Λ𝒫_λ,
and given a p∈𝒫_λ and a q∈𝒫_μ, we have p≥ q
in Q if and only if either λ=μ and p≥ q in P_λ, or
λ>μ and there exists a p'∈𝒫_λ such that p'≤ p in
P_λ and f_λμ(p')=q [resp. there exists a q'∈𝒫_μ
such that q'≥ q in P_μ and f_μλ(q')=p].
If the maps f_λμ are closed [resp. open], it is clear that
_Λ(P_λ,f_λμ) is a poset.
Clearly, MC(P_nf_n…f_2P_1)=_[n](P_i,f_ij),
where f_ij P_i→ P_j is the composition P_if_i…f_j+1P_j.
Similarly MC^*(P_nf_n…f_2P_1)=_[n]^*(P_i,f_ij).
In general, it is easy to see that every homotopy colimit indexed by a poset
is in fact an iterated amalgam of the iterated mapping cylinders.
Since every f_λ_mu is a single-valued (not multi-valued) map,
every subposet P_λ of _Λ (P_λ,f_λμ)
is full in the homotopy colimit.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let X be a poset.
Then [σ,τ]<[ρ,υ] in X^# iff ρ≤σ and
τ≤υ.
The dual cone [σ,τ] is the poset of all such intervals
[ρ,υ]; clearly, it is isomorphic to
(σ)^*τ.
Then every cone [σ,τ]^*=([σ,τ])^*
of the dual poset h(X)(X^#)^* is isomorphic to the product
σ(τ)^*=στ^*.

The maximal cones of h(X) (i.e. those cones that are not properly contained
in other cones) are of the form [σ,σ]^*, where
σ∈ X, and are called the (canonical) handles h_σ of
the poset X.
Each h_σ is isomorphic to the product of the cone σ of
X and the cone σ^* of X^*.
These cones are called the core and cocore of the handle
h_σ.

When σ<τ, the intersection h_σ∩ h_τ is clearly
the cone [σ,τ]^* of h(X).
However, when σ and τ are incomparable in X, it may be
that h_σ∩ h_τ is nonempty (namely, it is nonempty iff both
σ∩τ and σ∩τ are
nonempty).
This distinguishes the canonical handles from the barycentric ones, which will
be discussed in a moment.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
By a subdivision map we mean a monotone map
f P'→ P between posets such that |f^-1( p)| is homeomorphic to
|Cf^-1(∂ p)| by a homeomorphism fixed on
|f^-1(∂ p)| for each p∈ P.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The double mapping cylinder MC(RgPfQ)
is the quotient preposet R∪_g_2P [2]∪_f_1Q, where
f_1 is the composition P{1}≃ Pf Q and g_2 is
the composition P{2}≃ PgR.
Thus there is an monotone bijection MC(RgPfQ)→ Q+R,
and given a q∈ Q and an r∈ R, we have q<r in MC(RgPfQ)
if and only if there exists a p∈ P such that f(p)=q and g(p)=r.
Lemma <ref> implies that MC(RgPfQ) is
a poset if f is closed and g is open.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that f P→ Q is a stratification map if f^-1(∂ q)
is collared in f^-1( q) for each q∈ Q.
When Q is a cell complex, stratification map is a combinatorial form of the notion
of a “polyhedral mock bundle” of <cit.>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that a closed subposet Q of P is of codimension one in P
if every maximal element of Q is covered by at least one maximal element
of P.
If additionally no maximal element of Q is covered by a non-maximal element of
P, then we say that Q is of pure codimension one in P.

We note that if Q is collared in P, then the link in P of every maximal
element of Q is a singleton; in other words, every maximal element of Q is
covered by precisely one maximal element of P, and by no other element
of P.
On the other hand, if Q is of codimension one in P, then it is nowhere
dense in P, in the sense of the Alexandroff topology (i.e. contains no maximal
element of P).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We call a monotone map of posets f P→ Q a [pure] filtration map if
f^-1(∂ q) is of [pure] codimension one in f^-1( q)
for each q∈ Q.
Filtration maps (an in particular stratification maps) are open, since
if q>f(p), then f^-1(∂ q) is contains a maximal element p'
such that p'≥ p, and this p' must be covered by an element of
f^-1( q), which can only be in f^-1(q).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We call a poset P a manifold with [co]boundary ∂ P if ∂ P
is a (possibly empty) closed [resp. open] subposet of P, and |P| is
a PL manifold with boundary |∂ P|.
Clearly, P is a manifold with boundary Q if and only if P^* is a manifold with
coboundary Q^*.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
A poset P is called a cell complex, if ∂ p is a sphere
of some dimension for each p∈ P.
The cones of a cell complex are also referred to as its cells; clearly, they
are balls.
A closed subposet of a cell complex will be referred to as its subcomplex.

sentence:
A poset P will be called a cell complex with coboundary ∂^*P, if
∂^*P is an open subposet of P, and (∂ p)^* is a sphere
for each p∈ P∂^*P and a ball with boundary
(∂ p_∂^*P)^* for each p∈∂^*P.

If P is a cell complex, then C^*P is a cell complex with coboundary P, so
the new definition of coboundary ∂^*P extends the former one.
A closed subposet K of a cell complex P with coboundary is clearly a cell complex
with coboundary K∩∂^*P.

sentence:
Let I denote the 1-simplex.
Given a poset P and a p∈ P, suppose that p is isomorphic to
Q+I for some Q by an isomorphism h such that {p,q,r}:=h^-1(I)
is full in P (in other words, p is the least upper bound of q and r
in P).
In this situation we say that P elementarily zips onto the quotient poset
P/{p,q,r} (see <ref>) along p.
If additionally p^* is collared in q^* and in r^*,
then we say that P elementarily transversely zips onto
P/h^-1(I) along p.
A [transverse] zipping is a sequence of elementary [transverse] zippings.

Non-transverse zipping was introduced by N. Reading <cit.>; the author has been
aware of the notion for a few years before he learned of Reading's paper
from E. Nevo.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We have the following obvious excision rule for shelling: if P is a poset
and Q is a closed subposet of P, then P [transversely] shells onto Q
if and only if P R [transversely] shells onto Q R, where
R=P P Q.
Since P R is open in P, by Lemma <ref> the inclusion
P R P is a stratification map.
Theorem <ref> [resp. <ref>] implies
the following stronger “map excision” rule:

sentence:
A poset P is defined to be [transversely] ∅-shellable if it
∅-shells onto the empty set, where an (elementary) [transverse]
∅-shelling is defined similarly to an (elementary) [transverse] shelling.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Knop–Sahi hook tableau of shape λ is the following data:

    
  * 
    a set of k boxes, called marked boxes , in different columns of λ, such that
no marked box is down-right to another marked box in two adjacent columns;

  * 
    the right box in a pair of two adjacent marked boxes in a row is called critical ;

  *  every critical box has 
    
        
  * either a right arrow pointing at a box 
            which is weakly to its right,
        
  * or a down arrow pointing at a box
            which is strictly below it,
        
  * or no arrow at all.
    

  *  each critical box with a right-pointing arrow has weight α, and all other boxes has weight 1.

The set of Knop–Sahi hook tableaux of shape  is denoted (λ,k).
The weight w of a tableau in (λ,k)
is the product of the weights of the boxes in the tableau.

sentence:
Two rational polytopes Q_1, Q_2 ∈^d are called Ehrhart-equivalent
if they have the same Ehrhart quasipolynomial. That is, if |
kQ_1 ∩^d | = | kQ_2 ∩^d | for all k ∈.

sentence:
We say that two polytopes P, Q ⊂^d are
  []-equi­de­com­posable
  if there are relatively open simplices 
  T_1, …, T_r and
  unimodular transformations U_1, …, U_r∈[d] ⋉^d such that
  
    P = _i=1^r T_i  and  
        Q = _i=1^r U_i(T_i).

  (Here,  indicates disjoint union.)

sentence:
An  i-simplex Δ in ^n is called half-unimodular if 2Δ is a unimodular lattice simplex. That is,

    2Δ≅(0,e_1,…,e_i),

where e_1,…, e_n∈^n are the standard basis in ^n
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An empty simplex is a lattice simplex with no other lattice points
apart of its vertices.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a graph G and a set of distances D, a bijection f:V(G)→{1,2,…,n} is called a D-magic labeling of G if there exists a constant k called the magic constant such that for any vertex x, the weight of x , w(x)=∑_y∈ N_D(x) f(y) = k. 

In the case that the weight w(x) is distinct for every vertex x, f is called	a D-antimagic labeling of G. In particular, if the set of weights {w(x)| x∈ V(G)} constitutes an arithmetic progression starting at α with difference δ > 0, then f is called an (α,δ)-D-antimagic labeling of G. 

Any graph admitting a D-magic (resp. D-antimagic, (α,δ)-D-antimagic) labeling is called a D-magic (resp. D-antimagic, (α,δ)-D-antimagic) graph .

If D={1}, a D-magic (resp. D-antimagic, (α,δ)-D-antimagic) labeling is known as a distance magic (resp. distance antimagic, (α,δ)-distance antimagic) labeling , and if D={0,1}, a D-magic (resp. D-antimagic, (α,δ)-D-antimagic) labeling is called a closed distance magic (resp. closed distance antimagic, (α,δ)-closed distance antimagic) labeling .

sentence: A connected graph G of diameter d is called distance-regular if there are non-negative integers b_i, c_i (0≤ i ≤ d) such that for any two vertices x and y in G at distance i=d(x,y), there are precisely c_i neighbours of y in G_i-1(x) and b_i neighbours of y in G_i+1(x). Clearly, G is regular with degree r=b_0, b_d=c_0=0, and c_1=1. The sequence i(G)={r,b_1,…,b_d-1;1,c_2,…,c_d} is called the intersection array of G; and the numbers a_i, b_i, and c_i (i=0,…,d), where a_i=r-b_i-c_i, are called the intersection numbers of G.

sentence:
A subset A⊆_2^n is said to be balanced if

    |{∈ A| a_i=1}|=|A|/2  (∀ i∈{1,…,n}).

For a subset D⊆{0,1,…,n}, a bijection f:_2^n→_2^n is said to be D-neighbor balanced if f(⋃_i∈ DG_i()) is balanced for every ∈_2^n. If D={1} (resp. D={0,1}), then a D-neighbor balanced bijection is called a neighbor balanced (resp. closed neighbor balanced ).

sentence:
Let 𝒮 = (, , ) be a generalized 2d-gon and let 2 ≤ j ≤ d.
  
    
  * A partial distance-j ovoid of 𝒮 is a set of points  such that all elements of  have distance at least 2j (in the incidence graph) from each other. 
    
  * A distance-j ovoid of 𝒮 is a partial distance-j ovoid  such that every element of ∪ has distance at most j from at least one element of .

sentence:
Let 𝒮 = (, , ) be a generalized polygon and let (·, ·) denote the distance function in the point graph of 𝒮. 


  * A partial distance-j ovoid of 𝒮 is a set of points  such that for every two distinct points x and y we have (x, y) ≥ j. 


  * A distance-j ovoid of 𝒮 is a partial distance-j ovoid  such that (1) for every point a of 𝒮 there exists a point x of 𝒪 such that (a, x) ≤ j/2; (2) for every line ℓ of 𝒮 there exists a point x ∈𝒪 such that (ℓ, x) ≤ (j - 1)/2.

sentence:
(Matroid Union Theorem)
Let M_1,…,M_k be matroids on the same ground set E, with rank functions r_1,…,r_k respectively. The following conditions are equivalent:


  * there exist sets V_i with V_1∪…∪ V_k=E, such that for each i the set V_i is independent in M_i,

  * for each A⊂ E holds r_1(A)+…+r_k(A)≥| A|.

sentence:
Fix composition α=(α_1,…,α_r) 
with α_i<n and n-core λ^(r) 
of degree |α|.  An affine Bruhat countertableau 
of shape λ^(r) and weight α is a skew tableau
λ^(r)=μ^(0)⊂⋯⊂μ^(r)
such that 

    μ^(x)=(μ^(1)_1,…,μ^(x-1)_x-1,
    λ_1^(r-x)+n-1,λ^(r-x)) ,

where (λ^(x-1),λ^(x)) is
a horizontal strong (n-1-α_x)-strip 
for 1≤ x≤ r and λ^(0)=∅.

sentence:
Let { X_ij}, 1≤ i, j < ∞, be binary random
variables. They are separately exchangeable if

    (X_ij = e_ij,  1 ≤ i,j ≤ n) = (X_ij =
    e_σ(i)τ(j),  1 ≤ i,j ≤ n)

for all n, all permutations σ, τ∈ and all e_ij∈{
0,1 }. 
They are (jointly) exchangeable if (<ref>) holds in the
special case τ=.

Equivalently, the array X_ij is jointly  if 
the array X_(i)(j) has the same distribution as
X_ij for every permutation  of , and similarly
for separate exchangeability.

sentence:
Let A, B ⊆ F_q and ξ∈_q^*. The additive energy of A and ξ B is defined in the following equivalent ways.

    E(A, ξ B) 
        = ∑_x ∈_q r_A ±ξ B^2(x) 
        = | { (a_1, a_2 , b_1, b_2) ∈ A × A × B × B : (a_1-a_2) = ξ (b_1-b_2) }.

sentence:
[Pivots and involved elements]
Let V be a vector space over a finite field , W ⊆ V and X ⊆. For ξ in V, define ϕ_ξ W× X→ V by ϕ_ξ(v,α)=v+αξ. We say that ξ is a pivot for (W,X) if ϕ_ξ is injective.

An element is involved with the sets W and X, if it is not a pivot. We denote by ℐ_W,X the set of involved elements.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A block-stable class of (vertex labelled) graphs is called subcritical if

    C^∙(ρ_C) < ρ_B,

where ρ_B denotes the radius of convergence of B^∘(x) and
ρ_C the radius of convergence of C^∙(x).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If P_1=(X_1,≤_1),…,P_n=(X_n,≤_n) are partially ordered sets, their cartesian product , denoted by P_1×…× P_n, is the poset P=(X,≤), where X=X_1×…× X_n and for (x_1,…,x_n),(y_1,…,y_n)∈ X we have (x_1,…,x_n)≤ (y_1,…,y_n) if x_i≤ y_i holds for i∈ [n].
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let k_1,…,k_n be positive integers larger than 1. The cartesian product [k_1]×…× [k_n] is endowed with a natural point-wise ordering ≼: if (a_1,…,a_n),(b_1,…,b_n)∈ [k_1]×…× [k_n], then (a_1,…,a_n)≼ (b_1,…,b_n) if a_1≤ b_1,…,a_n≤ b_n. We shall refer to this poset structure (and every poset isomorphic to it) as an n-dimensional grid . The sides of the grid [k_1]×… [k_d] are k_1,…,k_d. If k_1=…=k_n=k, we shall write [k]^n instead of [k_1]×…× [k_n].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The complete multivel poset , K_r_1,…,r_h, is defined as follows. Let A_1,…,A_h be disjoint sets such that |A_i|=r_i for i=1,…,h. Let K=K_r_1,…,r_h be the poset on the set A_1∪…∪ A_h, where x<_Ky holds if and only if x∈ A_i and y∈ A_j for some 1≤ i<j≤ h. If r_1=…=r_h=r, write K^h_r instead of K_r_1,…,r_h.

sentence: Let Q be a poset and let k,n be positive integers. Q'⊂ [k]^n is a strong copy of Q if Q' is an induced copy of P, and whenever 𝐱,𝐲∈ Q' satisfy 𝐱≺𝐲, we have strict inequality in every coordinate, that is, 𝐱(i)<𝐲(i) for i∈ [n]. Note that we allow incomparable pairs of Q' to have some of their coordinates equal.

sentence: A skew diagram θ is a strip if θ is edgewise connected and it contains no 2× 2 blocks of boxes.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A skew diagram Θ is a thickened strip if Θ is edgewise connected and it neither contains a 3× 2 block of boxes nor a 2× 3 block of boxes.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that Θ_1,Θ_2,…,Θ_g are thickened strips in the skew diagram of λ/μ and every thickened strip has a starting box on the left or bottom perimeter of the diagram and an ending box on the right or top perimeter of the diagram.
Then we say the totally ordered set Φ=(Θ_1,Θ_2,…,Θ_g) is an outside thickened strip decomposition of the skew diagram of λ/μ if the union of the thickened strips Θ_i of Φ is the skew diagram of λ/μ, and for all i,j, one of the following statements is true:


  * two thickened strips Θ_i and Θ_j are disjoint, that is, Θ_i and Θ_j have no boxes in common;

  * one thickened strips Θ_j is on the right side or the bottom side of the other thickened strip Θ_i and they have some special corners in common, where each common special corner (s,t) is a lower corner of Θ_i and an upper corner of Θ_j.
    
    
    
    

Every special corner of a thickened strip in Φ is called a special corner of Φ and every common special corner of any two distinct thickened strips of Φ is called a common special corner of Φ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that Φ=(Θ_1,Θ_2,…,Θ_g) is an outside thickened strip decomposition of the skew shape λ/μ, for every i such that 1≤ i≤ g, and for box (s,t) that is the starting box or the ending box of Θ_i, we shall add new boxes to Θ_i according to the following rules:


  * if box (s,t) is a lower corner of Θ_i and an upper corner of some other thickened strip in Φ, we add boxes (s,t-1),(s-1,t),(s-1,t-1) that are not contained in Θ_i to Θ_i;

  * if box (s,t) is an upper corner of Θ_i and a lower corner of some other thickened strip in Φ, we add boxes (s,t+1),(s+1,t),(s+1,t+1) that are not contained in Θ_i to Θ_i.

where all the coordinates of new boxes are relative to the coordinates of the boxes in the skew diagram of λ/μ. We denote by D(Θ_i) the diagram after adding the new boxes to Θ_i and we call D(Θ_i) an enriched thickened strip. If neither the starting box nor the ending box of Θ_i satisfies (1) or (2), then D(Θ_i)=Θ_i. An enriched diagram D(Φ) is the union of all enriched thickened strips D(Θ_i) for every Θ_i of Φ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a g-tuple

    (P(u_π_1,v_1),P(u_π_2,v_2),…, P(u_π_g,v_g))

of double lattice paths where P(u_π_i,v_i)∈P(u_π_i,v_i). Then (<ref>) is non-crossing if for any i and j, P(u_π_i,v_i) and P(u_π_j,v_j) are non-crossing. This holds if and only if


  * P(u_π_i,v_i) and P(u_π_j,v_j) are non-intersecting, that is, have no points in common;

  * P(u_π_j,v_j) is on the top side of P(u_π_i,v_i) and they have some points in common, where each common point (c+1,q) occurs only when one diagonal step of P(u_π_j,v_j) and one horizontal step of P(u_π_i,v_i) end at the same point (c+1,q). 

Otherwise P(u_π_i,v_i) and P(u_π_j,v_j) are crossing and (<ref>) is crossing. If (<ref>) is non-crossing, we call every common point of any two double lattice paths in (<ref>) a touchpoint of (<ref>).

sentence:
For all c such that neither c nor c-1 is the content of some special corner of Φ, we say that two double lattice paths P̃(u_π_i,v_i) and P̃(u_π_j,v_j) are non-separable at the point (c,y) if and only if P̃(u_π_i,v_i) intersects P̃(u_π_j,v_j) at the point (c,y), that is, P̃(u_π_i,v_i) and P̃(u_π_j,v_j) have the point (c,y) in common.

For a g-tuple P̃ (see (<ref>)) of double lattice paths, we say that P̃ is non-separable at a single point if there exist two double lattice paths in P̃ such that they are non-separable at a single point. Otherwise we say that P̃ is separable at all single points.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For all C-pairs ([y_1,y_2],c) of a g-tuple P̃ (see (<ref>)) of double lattice paths, suppose that (c,y_2),(c,y_1) are the c-points of P̃(u_π_j,v_j) and P̃(u_π_i,v_i), the diagonal step of P̃(u_π_j,v_j) ends at (c+1,b) and the horizontal step of P̃(u_π_i,v_i) ends at (c+1,a). Then we say that P̃(u_π_i,v_i) and P̃(u_π_j,v_j) are non-separable at a C-pair ([y_1,y_2],c) if and only if neither P̃_c(u_π_j,v_j)[b,a] nor P̃_c(u_π_i,v_i)[a,b] is a double lattice path.

For a g-tuple P̃ (see (<ref>)) of double lattice paths, we say that P̃ is non-separable at a C-pair if there exist two double lattice paths in P̃ such that they are non-separable at a C-pair. Otherwise we say that P̃ is separable at all C-pairs.

sentence:
A primitive word w of length n is said to be ins-robust primitive word if the word

    pref(w, i) .  a  . suff(w, n - i)
 is a primitive word for all i ∈{0, 1, …, n } where a∈ V.

sentence: A primitive word w is said to be non-ins-robust if w ∈ Q but w ∉ Q_I. We denote the set of all non-ins-robust primitive words as Q_I. So, Q_I = Q ∖ Q_I, where `∖' is the set difference operator.

sentence:
Let u be a packed word.
Then

    _u^# = ∑_v u∑_ϵ
                  (-1)^m(ϵ)+m'(v,ϵ) _v,ϵ

where m'(v,ϵ) is equal to the number of different signed
letters of v and
where the sum on ϵ is such that the words (v,ϵ) are regular
and such  that if more than two letters of v go to the same letter of
u, all letters but the greatest are signed (the greatest can be
either signed or not).

In particular, the number of such ϵ for a given v
is equal to 2^max(u), so is independent ov v.

A square cannot be cut[By the phrase  polygon B is cut into triangles we mean that B can be presented as a union of a finite number of triangles  so that the interiors of the triangles have an empty intersection with each other.  Fig. <ref> illustrates this.] into an odd number of triangles[Throughout this article "triangle" is taken to include the degenerate case.] of equal areas.

sentence:
The value obtained by adding numbers in binary form without carry is called nim-sum. The nim-sum of nonnegative integers m_1,…,m_n  is written as 


m_1⊕⋯⊕ m_n.

sentence:
We denote the end positions by E. Let G be a game position, and {G'_1,…,G'_n} the set of all positions reached by a single move from G.
The value 𝒢(G) is defined as follows:

    𝒢(G)={[                      0                  (G=E); mex{𝒢(G'_1),…,𝒢(G'_n)}               (G ≠ E). ].

Moreover, 𝒢(G) is called the Grundy number of G.

sentence:
Mating function (x | y) is defined by

    (x | y)={[                2^n+1 -1 (x≡ y 2^n,   x≢y 2^n+1);                      -1                  (x=y). ].

Particularly, if x and y have different parities, then (x | y)=1.

sentence:
For any nonnegative integers a,b,c,d,…, a function f(x) of form 


f(x)=(((x ⊕ a )+b)⊕ c)+d ⊕⋯ 


is called an animating function.
