Let (a_1,…,a_n) be a Welter's Game position. Then we define the value [a_1|⋯|a_n] of Welter function at (a_1,…,a_n) as follows:


[a_1|⋯|a_n]=a_1⊕⋯⊕ a_n⊕∑_1≤ i < j≤ n^⊕ (a_i | a_j).

sentence: A set of dice is non-transitive if each of P( A ≻ B), P(B ≻ C), and P(C ≻ A) exceeds 1/2.  That is, the relation “is a better die than” is non-transitive.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A set of dice is balanced if P(A ≻ B) = P(B ≻ C) = P(C ≻ A).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let σ be a balanced non-transitive word.  If there do not exist balanced non-transitive words τ_1 and τ_2 (both nonempty) such that σ = τ_1 τ_2, we say that σ (and its associated set of dice) is irreducible .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let G be an orientation of K_m, the complete graph on the vertex set {v_1, v_2, …, v_m}.  Define a realization of G to be an m-tuple of n-sided dice A_1, A_2, …, A_m for some n (where now the A_i's partition [mn]) satisfying the following property:

    P(A_i ≻ A_j) > 1/2⇔ (v_i → v_j)  is an edge of  G.

sentence: Let D=(V,A) denote a digraph. A set of arcs S ⊆ A is a dijoin , if S intersects every directed cut.

sentence: A feedback arc set of a digraph D=(V,A) is a set S ⊆ A such that D-S is acyclic.

The dual free colored quasi-ribbon _σ,u labelled by a
colored permutation (σ,u) of size n is the noncommutative
polynomial


    _σ,u := ∑_w∈ A^n ; (w)=(σ,u) w   ∈.

sentence:
The free ℓ-quasi-ribbon _σ,u labelled by a colored
permutation (σ,u) is the noncommutative polynomial


    _σ,u := _σ^-1,u·σ^-1,

where the action of a permutation on the right of a word permutes the
positions of the letters of the word.

sentence:
A nonempty set S⊆ V is a defensive  k-alliance in
Γ=(V,E),  k∈ [-δ_1,δ_1]∩ℤ, if for
every v∈ S,

    δ _S(v)≥δ_S̅(v)+k.

sentence:
Let β∈ℝ_>1 and let A_β={0, 1, …, ⌈β⌉ -1 }.
Every real number x ∈ [0, 1) can be written as a series

    x = ∑_j=1^+∞ c_j β^-j

where c_j ∈ A_β for all j≥ 1, and where ⌈·⌉ denotes the ceiling function defined by ⌈ x ⌉ = inf{ z∈ℤ| z ≥ x }. 
The infinite word c_1 c_2 ⋯ is called a β-representation of x. 
Among all the β-representations of x, we define the β-expansion d_β(x) of x obtained in a greedy way, i.e., for all j≥ 1, we have  c_j β^-j + c_j+1β^-j-1 + ⋯  < β^-j+1.
We also make use of the following convention: if w=w_n⋯ w_0 is a finite word (resp., w=w_1 w_2 ⋯ is an infinite word) over A_β, the notation 0.w has to be understood as the real number ∑_j=0^n w_j β^j-n-1 (resp., ∑_j=1^+∞ w_j β^-j); it actually corresponds to the value of the word w in base β. 

In an analogous way, the β-expansion d_β(1) of 1 the following infinite word over A_β

    d_β(1) := 
    {[                           (β-1)^ω,                               β∈ℕ;; ( ⌈β⌉ -1 ) d_β ( 1 - (⌈β⌉ -1)/ β),                                    ].
 
In other words, if β is not an integer, the first digit of the β-expansion of 1 is ⌈β⌉ -1 and the other digits are derived from the β-expansion of 1 - (⌈β⌉ -1)/ β.

Let d_β (1) = (t_n )_n≥ 1 be the β-expansion of 1. 
Observe that t_1 = ⌈β⌉ -1. 
We define the quasi-greedy β-expansion d_β^*(1) of 1 as follows. 
If d_β (1)= t_1 ⋯ t_m is finite, i.e., t_m ≠ 0 and t_j = 0 for all j > m, then d_β^*(1) = (t_1 ⋯ t_m-1 (t_m - 1))^ω, otherwise d_β^*(1) = d_β(1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A deterministic finite automaton (DFA),
over an alphabet A is given by a 5-tuple 𝒜 = (Q, q_0 , A, δ, F ) 
where Q is a finite set of states, q_0∈ Q is the initial state, δ : Q × A ↦ Q is the transition function and F ⊂ Q is the set of final states (graphically represented by two concentric circles). 
The map δ can be extended to Q × A^* by setting δ(q, ε) = q and δ(q, wa) = δ(δ(q, w), a) for all q ∈ Q,
a ∈ A and w ∈ A^*.
We also say that a word w is accepted by the automaton if δ(q_0,w)∈ F.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let U = (U(n))_n≥ 0 be a sequence of integers such that U is increasing, U(0)=1 and sup_n ≥ 0U(n+1)/U(n) is bounded by a constant. 
We say that U is a linear numeration system if U satisfies a linear recurrence relation, i.e., there exist k≥ 1 and a_0, …, a_k-1∈ℤ such that

    ∀ n ≥ 0,    U(n+k) = a_k-1  U(n+k-1) + ⋯ + a_0  U(n)
     .

Let n be a positive integer. 
By successive Euclidean divisions, there exists ℓ≥ 1 such that 

    n = ∑_j=0^ℓ -1 c_j  U(j)

where the c_j's are non-negative integers and c_ℓ-1 is non-zero. 
The word c_ℓ -1⋯ c_0 is called the normal U-representation of n and is denoted by _U(n). 
In other words, the word c_ℓ-1⋯ c_0 is the greedy expansion of n in the considered numeration system. 
We set _U(0):=ε. 
Finally, we refer to L_U:=_U(ℕ) as the language of the numeration and we let A_U denote the minimal alphabet such that L_U ⊂ A_U^*.  
If d_r⋯ d_0 is a word over an alphabet of digits, then its U-numerical value is

    _U(d_r⋯ d_0):=∑_j=0^r d_j  U(j).

Observe that, if _U (d_r⋯ d_0) = n, then the word d_r ⋯ d_0 is a
U-representation of n (but not necessarily its normal U-representation).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: linear numeration system;normal U-representation;language of the numeration;U-numerical value

sentence: A linear numeration system U = (U(n))_n≥ 0 is a Bertrand numeration system if, for all w ∈ A^+_U, w ∈ L_U ⇔ w0 ∈ L_U.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let U = (U(n))_n≥ 0 be a linear numeration
system. 
Consider the characteristic polynomial of the recurrence (<ref>) given by P(X) = X^k - a_k-1 X^k-1 - ⋯ - a_1 X - a_0.
If P is the minimal polynomial of a Perron number β∈ℝ_>1, we say that U is a Perron numeration system . 
In this case, the polynomial P can be factored as 

    P(X) = (X-β) (X-α_2) ⋯ (X-α_k)

where the complex numbers α_2,… ,α_k are the conjugates of β, and, for all j > 1, we have |α_j | < β. 
Using a well-known fact regarding recurrence relations, we have

    U(n) = c_1 β^n + c_2 α_2^n + ⋯ + c_k α^n_k   ∀ n ≥ 0

where c_1, …, c_k are complex numbers depending on the initial values of U.
Since |α_j | < β for all j > 1, we have  

    lim_n → +∞U(n)/β^n = c_1 .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A vertex-weighted graph G is the composition of
vertex-weighted graphs H and K, G=H∗ K, if the following conditions hold.

(a) V(H)∩ V(K) consists of a single unlooped vertex a.

(b) The vertex a is unweighted in both H and K, i.e., α
(a)=1=β(a) in H and K.

(c) V(G)=(V(H)∪ V(K))-a, and the vertices of G inherit their weights
from H and K.

(d) E(G)=E(H)∪ E(K)∪{vw|va∈ E(G) and aw∈ E(H)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An earlier sibling cover (or es-cover ) in an ordered tree T is
an independent set I that dominates r and has the property that for every
non-root vertex v∈ I, every earlier sibling of v is dominated by I.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For integers s and t the es-number c_s,t(T) is the number of
s-element es-covers in T whose non-root elements have t different parents.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let T be an ordered tree with vertex weights, and let I be an es-cover in
T. Let

    I_r     ={v∈ I:either v=r or I contains a later sibling of
    v},
    
    I_l     ={v∈ I:v≠r and I contains no later sibling of
    v}, and 
    
    I_c^'     ={v∉I:I contains a child of v}

For each vertex v define the I-weight w_I(v) as follows:

    w_I(v)=
    β(v)+α(v)(y-1)    if v∈ I_r
    α(v)·(  (y-1)β(p(v))+(x-1)^2α(p(v)))     if v∈ I_l
    
    1    if v∈ I_c^'
    β(v)    if v∉ I and v∉ I_c^'.

The product

    ∏_v∈ V(T)w_I(v)

is the total weight of I in T, denoted w_T(I).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose G is an unweighted graph with E(G)={e_1
,...,e_m}, and T is a maximal spanning forest of G. An element
e_i∉E(T) is externally active with respect to T if i is
the least index of an element of the unique circuit contained in
E(T)∪{e_i}. An element e_i∈ E(T) is internally active
with respect to T if i is the least index of an element of the unique
cutset contained in (E(G)-E(T))∪{e_i}. The numbers of edges that are
externally and internally active with respect to T are denoted e(T) and
i(T), respectively.

 over α are S-homotopic
 (denoted (𝒜_1 , w_1) ≃_S (𝒜_2 , w_2))
 if (𝒜_2 , w_2) can be obtained from (𝒜_1, w_1) by a
 finite sequence of isomorphism, S-homotopy moves 
 (1) - (3) and the inverse of moves (1) - (3).

 (w_1|w_2|⋯|w_k).

    lim_n→∞Γ_M(n)= 1,

contains an infinite subsequence that converges to one, then M is
weakly fractal .

sentence:
Let r≥ 3 be an integer, and let Δ_r be the graph obtained
from a cycle with r edges by replacing each edge with a parallel pair.
A (tipless) spike is a matroid of the form L(Δ_r,B), where
B is a linear class of Hamiltonian cycles.
Let S denote the class of matroids that are isomorphic to minors of spikes.
Let k be a non-negative integer.
We use S_k to denote the class of matroids that are isomorphic
to minors of spikes of the form L(Δ_r,B),
where B contains at most k Hamiltonian cycles.
Therefore S = ∪_k≥ 0 S_k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let w=w_1w_2⋯ w_k be a word of length k with distinct letters from [n].  An admissible inversion of w is a pair (w_i,w_j) such that 1≤ i<j≤ k and w_i>w_j and satisfies either of the following conditions:
 
 
  * 1<i and w_i-1<w_i or 
 
  * there is some l such that i<l<j and w_i<w_l.
 
Let (w) be the number of admissible inversions of w.
The statistic “" is defined 
  recursively as follows: (∅)=0, 
   if w_i=max{w_1,w_2,…,w_k} 1≤ i≤ k, then

    (w):=
     
    0,   if i=1< k;
    
    1+(w_1w_2⋯ w_k-1),   if i=k;
    (w_i+1w_i+2⋯ w_k),   if 1<i<k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a word w=b_1 t_1 b_2 t_2 ⋯ b_i t_i∈ S^123_k,2i, suppose that all pairs b_jt_j (1≤ j≤ i) in w are distinct. Then b_jt_j is a cut-pair if

 
  * 1 < b_j < k-1 and b_j>b_m for all j+1≤ m≤ i,
and
 
  * 2 < t_j < k and t_j<t_m for 1≤ m≤ j-1.

Furthermore, if w contains repeated pairs then b_jt_j is a cut-pair if it is a cut-pair in the word obtained from w by removing all repetitions of repeated pairs.

sentence: For any fixed edge orientation ε, the signed vertex-edge incidence matrix of G with respect to ε is the n+1× m matrix ∂, with rows indexed by vertices of G and columns indexed by edges of G, whose (v,e)-th entry is 1 if v is the positive end of e, -1 if v is the negative end of e, and 0 otherwise.

sentence:
The vertex Laplacian of G is L:=D-A, where D is the n+1× n+1 matrix indexed by the vertices of G such that the matrix entry d_i,j is the degree of vertex i if i=j and 0 otherwise and A is the 0/1-valued adjacency matrix of G indexed in the same way as D.
Given a graph G, the i-th Laplacian minor of G is L_i, the Laplacian matrix L with row i and column i deleted.

Let L be an ℓ-set with 1≤ℓ≤ j-1 and let i≥ 1.
 
 
  * A jump to L (in step i) occurs when we query a k-set containing L from a j-set in i-1 which did not contain L and the k-set forms an edge of ^k(n,p). Such an edge contributes at most k-ℓj-ℓ to Li.
 
  * A pivot at L (in step i) occurs when we query any k-set from a j-set in i-1 containing L and it forms an edge of ^k(n,p). Such an edge contributes at most k-ℓj-ℓ-1 to Li.

sentence:
Let F ∈_c,(M), x ∈ M, and ξ∈ T^*_x M.


  * The microlocalization of F at x is given by

    μ_x(F) = (ν_x(F))

Thus, μ_x is a functor from _c(M) →_c,_>0(T^*_x M) that takes polyhedral sheaves to conical polyhedral sheaves.

  * The microlocal stalk of F at (x,ξ) is the stalk of μ_x F at ξ.  We denote it by μ_x,ξ F.

  * The singular support of F is the closure of the set of all (x,ξ) such that μ_x,ξ F ≠ 0.  We denote this set by (F).

We say that a quasicoherent sheaf ∈_T(X) has height ≤ h if the following equivalent conditions are satisfied:


  * → j_* j^* is a quasi-isomorphism.

  * i^*  = 0 whenever i is the inclusion of a T-orbit of codimension > h.

sentence:
Here are some basic definitions.


  * A color c's index positions with a tuple S_i(r,k) are the set of its positions within that tuple.

  * The tuples S_i(r,k) are sometimes called a block .

  * The acronym k-TMAP is short for a k-term monochromatic arithmetic progression.

  * If x_1,x_2,…,x_k is an arithmetic progression, then the common value x_i+1-x_i is called the common difference .

  * For a fixed k and r, a valid r-coloring of {1,2,3,…,n} is one which contains no k-TMAP.

sentence:
Let X be a mixed cycle of order n. Then, X is switching equivalent to exactly one of the three following mixed cycles:
	
		
  1. C_n: The mixed cycle whose all edges are undirected.
		
  2.  C_n^1: The mixed cycle which has exactly one directed edge.
		
  3.  C_n^2: The mixed cycle which has two consecutive directed edges with the same direction and all its other edges are undirected.
	
	We call them mixed cycles of Type 0, 1 and 2, respectively.

sentence:
Let A be an ω×ω matrix with rational entries. Then A is said to be a segmented
image partition regular matrix if and only if


  * A contains no row as →0;

  * the set {j ∈ω : a_i,j≠ 0} is finite, for each i ∈ω; and

  * there is an increasing sequence ⟨α_n ⟩_n=0^∞ with elements from ω satisfying  α_0 = 0 and for each n ∈ω,

    {⟨ a_i,α_n, a_i,α_n+1, a_i,α_n+2, ⋯ , a_i,α_n+1−1⟩ : i ∈ω}∖{→0}

is either empty or forms the set of rows of a finite image partition regular matrix.

We shall say that A is a segmented first entries matrix if each of these finite image partition regular matrices is a first entries matrix. Moreover A is said to be a monic segmented first entries matrix if in addition  the first non-zero entry of each ⟨ a_i,α_n, a_i,α_n+1, a_i,α_n+2, ⋯ , a_i,α_n+1−1⟩, if any, is 1.

plain_text_term: segmented first entries matrix;monic segmented first entries matrix

sentence:
An ω×ω matrix A is said to be a restricted triangular matrix if
and only if all entries of A are from ℤ and there exist d ∈ℕ and an increasing function j : ω→ω such that for all i ∈ω,


  * a_i, j(i)∈{1, 2, ⋯ , d},

  * a_i,l = 0, whenever l > j(i), and

  * for all k > i and all t ∈{1, 2, ⋯ , d}, t|_a_k,j(i).

sentence:
Let G=(V,E,ω) be a weighted graph. We define the following:


  * A vertex u ∈ V is useless if u has no loop attached to it, and all the neighbors of u have a loop attached to them.

  * A vertex u ∈ V is heavy if u has no loop attached to it, and ω(u) ≥∑_v ∈ N(u)ω(v).

  * Two non-adjacent vertices u and v are false twins if N(u) = N(v), and (u) = (v).

sentence: An edge (v_1, v_2) ∈ E(_m,n,k) is called an x-sibling pair (resp. y-sibling pair ) if v_2 = v_1 x^± 1 (resp. v_2 = v_1 y^± 1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let T be a tree and C⊆ V(T). A mapping ψ V(T)∖
C→𝔾 satisfies the walk condition if for
any x,y∈ V(T)∖ C such that there is a path P_x,y from x to
y whose internal vertices are all in C there is a walk ℙ_x,y between ψ(x) and
ψ(y) in 𝔾 such that the length of P_x,y and the length of 
ℙ_x,y have the same parity.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[fork, fork system]
  An r-fork (or simply fork ) is the complete bipartite graph
  K_1,r. We also say that an r-fork has r prongs and
  one center by which we refer to the vertices in the two partition
  classes of K_1,r. A fork system F in a graph G is a set of
  pairwise vertex disjoint forks in G (not necessarily having the same number
  of prongs). We say that F has ratio r if all its forks have at
  most r prongs. Then we also call F an r-fork system.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[m-odd, (m,f,r)-good]
  Let G be a coloured graph on n vertices. Then G is called
  m-odd if G contains a monochromatic odd connected matching of
  size at least m. We say that G is
  (m,f,r)-good (in colour c) if G contains a c-coloured
  connected matching M of size at least m as well as a c-coloured
  connected fork system F of size at least f, and ratio at most r.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[valid assignment]
Let 𝔾 be a graph on vertex set [], let T be a tree,
ρ∈[0,1] and L∈ℕ. A mapping h V(T)→ [] is
a (ρ,L)-valid assignment of T to 𝔾 if 
  
  
  *  h is a homomorphism from T to
  𝔾,
  
  * |h(_T(x))|≤ 2, for every x∈ V(T),
  
  *  |h^-1(i)|<(1-ρ)L, for every i∈[].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[cut, shrubs]

  Let S∈ℕ and T be a tree with vertex set V(T). A set
  C⊆ V(T) is an S-cut (or simply cut ) of T if all
  components of T-C are of size at most S. The components of T-C are
  called the shrubs of T corresponding to C.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
[walk condition]
Let T be a tree and C⊆ V(T). A mapping ψ V(T)∖
C→𝔾 satisfies the walk condition if for
any x,y∈ V(T)∖ C such that there is a path P_x,y from x to
y whose internal vertices are all in C there is a walk ℙ_x,y between ψ(x) and
ψ(y) in 𝔾 such that the length of P_x,y and the length of 
ℙ_x,y have the same parity.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For M ∈, an M-Lipschitz mapping of a connected graph G = (V,E) with root v_0 ∈ V is a
mapping f: V → such that f(v_0) = 0 and for every edge (u,v) ∈ E
it holds that |f(u) - f(v)| ≤ M. The set of all M-Lipschitz mappings of a
graph G is denoted by ℒ_M(G).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For M ∈, a strong M-Lipschitz mapping of a connected graph G = (V,E) with root v_0 ∈ V is a
mapping f: V → such that f(v_0) = 0 and for every edge (u,v) ∈ E
it holds that |f(u) - f(v)| = M. The set of all M-Lipschitz mappings of a
graph G is denoted by ℒ_± M(G).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The range of a Lipschitz mapping f of G is the size of the
homomorphic image of f. Formally:

    _G(f) := |{ z ∈ | z = f(v)  for some  v ∈ V(G) }|.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(Average range)
The average range of graph G over all M-Lipschitz mappings is defined as

    _M(G) := ∑_f ∈ℒ_M(G)(f)/|ℒ_M(G)|.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A star graph S_n is a tree with n vertices; one vertex of degree
  n-1 and n-1 leaves (vertices of degree one). Or, alternatively, it is 
  a complete bipartite graph K_1,n-1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(Trinomial triangle and central trinomial coefficient)
Trinomial numbers (coefficients) n k_2 are defined as:

    0 0_2=1


    n+1  k_2=n  k-1_2+n  k_2+n  k+1_2  for  n ≥ 0,

where n k_2=0 for k< -n and k>n.

Central trinomial coefficients are the numbers n  0_2, where n ∈_0.

sentence:
The irregular trinomial coefficients are defined as
  
    T^*(n,k) = n  k + n_2.

sentence: We call a graph unicyclic if it contains exactly one cycle.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
We call a graph pseudotree if it is a tree or a unicyclic graph.
  Equivalently, pseudotrees are graphs with at most one cycle.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A corolla graph is a unicyclic graph obtained by taking a cycle graph
  and joining some path graphs to it by identifying their endpoints with some vertex of that cycle.
  Every path is joined to exactly one vertex of the cycle. And every vertex
  of the cycle has at most one path attached.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a graph G, the partition of V(G) into A and B is the cut A| B = B | A.
The edge set { ab ∈ E(G) | a ∈ A,   b∈ B} induced by the cut  A | B is also denoted A | B when no confusion arises.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The cut ideal of the graph G , I_G, is the kernel of the ring homomorphism
ϕ_G : 𝕂[q]→𝕂[s,t] defined by

    q_A| B↦∏_ij  is in  A| B s_ij∏_ij  is not in  A| B t_ij,

where

    𝕂[q]  =  𝕂[q_A | B | there is a cut A | B of G],


    𝕂[s,t] =  𝕂[s_ij,t_ij | ij is an edge of G].
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: cut ideal of the graph G

sentence:
Let u,v be two vertices of G and
   A_1 | B_1, A_2| B_2,⋯,A_n| B_n a list of
   cuts. The height , h_u,v(q), of
   
    q=q_A_1| B_1q_A_2| B_2⋯ q_A_n| B_n

   with respect to u and v is the number of cuts in
   the list with u and v in different parts.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A set of generators
   
    q_A_i,1| B_i,1q_A_i,2| B_i,2⋯ q_A_i,n_i| B_i,n_i 
          -  q_A_i,1'| B_i,1'q_A_i,2'| B_i,2'⋯ q_A_i,n_i'| B_i,n_i'

   of I_G is slow-varying with respect to the vertices u and v of G if
   
    | h_u,v(q_A_i,1| B_i,1⋯ q_A_i,n_i| B_i,n_i)
         -h_u,v(q_A_i,1'| B_i,1'⋯ q_A_i,n_i'| B_i,n_i') | ≤ 2

   for all i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[The Euler monoid]
	The Euler monoid _d=(EM_d,) is given by the 
	set of integer points x∈^d that satisfy the Euler equation
	and the trivial lower bound inequality,
	
    EM_d := { x∈_d: x≥ f(Δ_d)}∩^d,

	with the reduced addition operation
	
    x  y := x+y-f(Δ_d).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[The Dehn–Sommerville monoid]
	For any d≥2,
	the Dehn–Sommerville monoid is the
	pair _d:=((𝒫^d_s),).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
[The class of adapter polytopes]
	Let 𝒫^d_ap, the adapter polytopes , be the class of all d-polytopes
	P that have 
		a simple vertex v that is contained in d simplex facets of P, and
		an additional simplex facet F that does not contain v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S⊂^d.
A limit direction is a unit vector u∈ S^d  
such that for every ε>0 there are arbitrarily large 
vectors in v∈ S with |1/|v|v -u|<ε.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let B_0 be a skew-symmetrizable n× n  matrix. A green sequence for B_0 is a sequence 𝐢 = (i_1, …, i_l) such that, 

for any 1 ≤ k ≤ l with (,B)=μ_i_k-1∘⋯∘μ_i_1(_0,B_0), we have _i_k>0 ; here if k=1, then we take (,B)=(_0,B_0).


A green sequence 𝐢 = (i_1, …, i_l) is maximal if, for (,B)=μ_i_l∘⋯∘μ_i_1(_0,B_0), we have _k<0 for all k=1,...,n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A pure simplicial complex Δ is called shellable if Δ is a simplex or if one of the following equivalent conditions is satisfied. There exists a linear ordering F_1,…,F_m of the facets of Δ such that


  (a) ⟨ F_i⟩∩⟨ F_1,…,F_i-1⟩ is generated by a non-empty set of maximal proper faces of ⟨ F_i⟩, for all 2≤ i≤ m.

  (b) the set {F | F∈⟨ F_1,…, F_i⟩, F∉⟨ F_1,…,F_i-1⟩} has a unique minimal element for all 2≤ i≤ m. This element is called the restriction face of F_i. We denote it by (F_i).

A linear order of the facets satisfying the equivalent conditions (a) and (b) is called a shelling of Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let 𝒞 be a pure (d-1)-dimensional polytopal complex. A shelling of 𝒞 is a linear ordering F_1,F_2,…,F_m of the facets of 𝒞 such that either 𝒞 is 0-dimensional, or it satisfies the following conditions:

	
  (i) The boundary complex 𝒞(∂ F_1) of the first facet F_1 has a shelling.
	
  (ii) For 1<j≤ m the intersection of the facet F_j with the previous facets is non-empty and is the beginning segment of a shelling of the (d-2)-dimensional boundary complex of F_j, that is,
	
    F_j∩(⋃_i=1^j-1F_i)=G_1∪ G_2∪…∪ G_r

	for some shelling G_1,G_2,…,G_r,…,G_t of 𝒞(∂ F_j), and 1≤ r ≤ t.


A polytopal complex is called shellable if it is pure and has a shelling.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A labeling of G is a bijection V(G) ≃ [n] =
{1,…,n}, and given a labeling, we typically assume V(G) =
   [n].  A labeling is closed if whenever we have distinct edges
   {j,i}, {i,k}∈ E(G) with either j > i < k or j < i > k,
   then {j,k}∈ E(G).  Finally, a graph is closed if it
   has a closed labeling.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
A connected graph G is narrow if for every v ∈ V(G) and
every longest shortest path P of G, either v ∈ V(P) or
{v,w}∈ E(G) for some w ∈ V(P).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A word m_x'^c' obtained as described above is called a standard form of x'∈𝒫_c'
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let A be an ASL on P over a field K. An A-module M is called module with straightening laws on a finite poset Q ⊂ M if the following conditions are satisfied:


  (MSL 1) For every x ∈ Q there exists a poset ideal ℐ(x) ⊂ P such that the elements

_1_2…_i x,   with   _1 ∉ℐ(x),  _1≤_2≤…≤_i    i≥0,

form a basis of M as a K-vector space. These elements are called standard elements .

  (MSL 2) For every x ∈ Q and ∈ℐ(x)  one has 

    x ∈∑_y < x Ay.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A signed k-partition of [± n]_0 is a set partition
of [± n]_0 with k+1 non-empty blocks B_0, B_1,… B_k with the following rules:


  * 0∈ B_0 and ∀ i ∈ [n],  { i,-i }⊄B_0,

  * ∀ j∈ [k] and ∀ i∈ [n],  we have
{i,-i}⊂ B_j⟺ i=min B_j∩ [n].
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A simply hooked k-quasi-permutation of [n]
is a subset Q of [n]× [n] such that


  i) Q ⊂(σ) for some permutation  σ of [n],

  ii) |Q|=n-k and _x(Q^-)∩_y(Q^+)=∅.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A  supdiagonal  (resp. subdiagonal )
quasi-permutation of [n] is a simply hooked  quasi-permutation Q of [n]
with  Q^-=∅ (resp. Q^+=∅).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a word w=w(1)… w(ℓ) on the finite alphabet [n],
a  letter w(j) is a  record of w if w(k)>w(j) for every k∈{1,…, j-1}.
We define (w)  to be the number of records of w and _0(w)=(w)-1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let a∈ X, the set σ_w(F,a)={η∈φ_w(F):a∈η∖φ_w^-1(η)} is called the set of spurious elements of ℱ with respect to a. The set π_w(F,a)={η∈φ_w(F_a):η{a}∉φ_w(F)} is called the set of pure elements of ℱ with respect to a.
  

  Let η∈ℱ, the set of pure elements of η , denoted by π_w(F, η), is the set {a∈ X: η∈π_w(a)} and analogously the set of spurious elements of η is the set σ_w(F, η)={a∈ X: η∈σ_w(a)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: pure elements of η;spurious elements of η

sentence:
Let a be an integer. An n-vertex graph is called a-arrangeable if its vertices
can be ordered as (x_1,… ,x_n) in such a way that

    |N(N(x_i)∩{x_i+1, x_i+2,…, x_n}) ∩{x_1, x_2,…, x_i }| ≤ a

for each 1 ≤ i ≤ n. 

Here, for a set of vertices S, we denote by N(S) the set of 
those vertices not in S that are adjacent to some vertex in S.

sentence:
The system signature is the probability vector s(ϕ)=N(ϕ)/n!,
whose i-th entry s_i(ϕ) is the probability that the system stops working exactly
as the i-th failure of a component takes place.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A subset C⊆ X is called a cut set if the system is down when all the components
in C are broken. A subset P⊂ X is called a path set if the system is up whenever all
the components in P work. 
A set of either type is said to be minimal if none of its proper subsets
enjoy the same property.

sentence:
Given a system with structure function ϕ, for all A⊆ X 
the dual system has structure function ϕ^*

    ϕ^*(A)=1-ϕ(X∖ A) .

sentence: A vertex x ∈ G is an eventual cut vertex if in G ∖ x there is a connected component S such that x has either 1 or 2 neighbors in S and for all v ∈ S, (v) = 3 in G.

sentence:
Let f_n be the number of rows with the value “false” in the truth tables 
of all bracketed formulea with n distinct propositions p_1,…,p_n 
connected by the binary connective of implication. Then in <cit.> 
we have shown that the following results are true:

    f_n =∑_i=1^n-1 (2^iC_i-f_i)f_n-i,   with   f_1=1

and for large n, f_n ∼(3-√(3)/6)2^3n-2/√(π n^3).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let g_n be the total number of rows in all truth tables for
bracketed implications with n distinct variables. 
Let t_n be the number of rows with the value “true” in the truth tables 
of all bracketed formulea with n distinct propositions p_1,…,p_n 
connected by the binary connective of implication. Then in <cit.> 
we have shown that the following results are true:

    t_n =g_n-f_n,   with   t_0=0

and for large n, t_n ∼(3+√(3)/6)2^3n-2/√(π n^3).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

[prism, Möbius ladder]

the prism _r be defined by 
(_r) := {  x_0, …, x_r-1, y_0, …, y_r-1} and
(_r) := _i=0^r-1 { x_i x_i+1 } 
⊔ _i=0^r-1 {  y_iy_i+1 } ⊔ 
_i=0^r-1 {  x_iy_i }, and the Möbius ladder 
_r be defined by (_r) := (_r) and 
(_r) := ( (_r) ∖ 
{ x_0x_r-1, y_0y_r-1 } ) ⊔ 
{ x_0y_r-1, y_0x_r-1 }.

sentence: Let 𝐤 be a field of characteristic zero. We say that the statistic f:𝒮→𝐤 on a set of combinatorial objects 𝒮 is homomesic with respect to the action of a group G on 𝒮 if there is some c ∈𝐤 such that 1/#𝒪∑_s ∈𝒪 f(s) = c for each G-orbit 𝒪. In other words, we say f is homomesic with respect to G if the average of f is the same for each G-orbit. In this case we also say the triple (𝒮,G,f) exhibits homomesy.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A matroid is dyadic if and only if it is representable over both GF(3) and GF(5).

sentence: Let M_1 and M_2 be 𝔽-represented matroids on ground set E. If there is some 𝔽-represented matroid M on ground set E∪{e} such that M_1=M\ e and M_2=M/e, then M_1 is an elementary lift of M_2, and M_2 is an elementary projection of M_1.

sentence: Let M_1 and M_2 be 𝔽-represented matroids on a common ground set. Then M_2 is a rank-(≤ t) perturbation of M_1 if there exist matrices A_1 and P such that M(A_1) = M_1, the rank of P is at most t, and M(A_1 + P) = M_2.

sentence: A frame template Φ=(Γ,C,X,Y_0,Y_1,A_1,Δ,Λ) over 𝔽 is Y-reduced if Δ[C]=Γ(𝔽_p^C) and Δ[Y_0∪ Y_1]={0}, and there is a partition (X_0,X_1) of X for which 𝔽_p^X_0⊆Λ[X_0] and Λ[X_1]={0}. We will call the partition X=X_0∪ X_1 the reduction partition of Φ.

sentence:
A frame template Φ=(Γ,C,X,Y_0,Y_1,A_1,Δ,Λ) is reduced if there is a partition (X_0,X_1) of X such that

 
  * Δ=Γ(𝔽^C_p×Δ') for some additive subgroup Δ' of 𝔽^Y_0∪ Y_1,

  * 𝔽_p^X_0⊆Λ[X_0] while Λ[X_1]={0} and A_1[X_1,C]=0, and

  * the rows of A_1[X_1,C∪ Y_0∪ Y_1] form a basis for a subspace whose additive subgroup is skew to Δ.

sentence: A frame template Φ=(Γ,C,X,Y_0,Y_1,A_1,Δ,Λ) is refined if it is reduced, with reduction partition X=X_0∪ X_1, and if Y_1 spans the matroid M(A_1[X_1,Y_0∪ Y_1]).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let w ∈ S_n and set

    w = {(i,j) ∈ [n] × [n] : i < j  and  w(i) > w(j) }.

The set w is called the inversion set of w and each pair (i,j) ∈w is called an inversion of w . Regarding w ∈ S_n as a permutation in S_n+1 satisfying w(n+1) = n+1, set

    w = { (i,j) ∈ [n] × [n+1] : i ≤ j  and  w(i) ≤ w(j) }.

We call w the set of non-inversions of w and each pair (i,j) ∈w is called a non-inversion of w.

sentence: Let w ∈ S_n. For i ∈ [n] and j ∈ [n + 1], define ijw as the number of inversions (i,k) ∈w satisfying k < j. This defines a matrix of values that we call the extended Lehmer code for w .

sentence: A family ℱ is said to be a maximal intersecting family (in short MIF) if ℱ<∞ and ℱ=ℱ^⊤. We use MIF(k) as a generic name for MIF's with ℱ=k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An intersecting set pair system (in short ISP) is a collection {(A_i, B_i):1≤ i≤ n} of pairs of finite sets with the property that, for 1≤ i,j≤ n, A_i∩ B_j=∅ if and only if i=j. Clearly, in such a system, the sets A_i (as well as the sets B_i) are distinct. The set ni=1∪(A_i⊔ B_i) is called the point set of the ISP. We denote by 𝕀 the number of points of an ISP 𝕀. If in 𝕀, #(A_i)=k and #(B_i)=t for 1≤ i≤ n, then we say that 𝕀 is an ISP with parameter (k,t). We use ISP(k,t) as a generic name for an ISP with parameter (k,t).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let H∈𝒢_n be a graph on the vertex set {x_1,x_2,…,x_m} such that the labeled vertices are S={x_1,x_2,…,x_n}. Then the restricted subgraph density of H in W:[0,1]^2→ℝ is the n-variable function defined as

    t_S(H,W)=𝔼_S(∏_(x_i,x_j)∈ E(H)W(x_i,x_j)).

sentence: Reflection of a subgraph H_2 induced on K⊂ V(H) in H along an independent set S⊂ K is the operation which produces the graph HH_2 where the vertices in K are labeled in both H and H_2 in the same way.

sentence: A reflection tree is a graph obtained from a tree T by applying the reflection operation to a collection of sub-trees in T.

sentence: Let H be a graph and S⊂ V(H) be a subset of its vertices. We say that S (Or the graph H_2 spanned on S) is a retract of H if there is a graph homomorphism ϕ:H→ H_2 such that ϕ restricted to H_2 is the identity map.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let r ≥ 4 be given. There exists some ϵ = ϵ(r)>0 such that, for any p=p(n) ≤ n^-2/r + ϵ, the following holds. For some π=π(n) ∼ p^r  2, we may couple the random graph G=G(n,p) with the random hypergraph H=H_r(n,π) so that, whp[We say that an event E=E(n) holds with high probability (whp) if lim_n →∞(E) =1.], for every hyperedge in H there is a copy of K_r in G with the same vertex set.

sentence:
Given a function P: G → K between additive groups G,K, as well as subgroups H_1,…,H_d of G for some non-negative integer d, we say that P has rank <(H_1,…,H_d) or rank <(H_i)_1 ≤ i ≤ d according to the following recursive definition:


  (i)  If d = 0, we say that P is of rank <() if and only if it is identically zero.

  (ii)  If d ≥ 1, we say that P is of rank <(H_1,…,H_d) if and only if, for every 1 ≤ i ≤ d and h ∈ H_i, there exists a polynomial P_h G → K of rank <(H_1,…,H_i-1,H_i+1,…,H_d) such that P(x+h) = P(x) + P_h(x) for all x ∈ G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G = (G,+) be an at most countable additive group.  A G-system (, T) is a probability space = (X, ℬ, μ), together with a collection T = (T^g)_g ∈ G of invertible measure-preserving maps T^g X → X, such that T^0 is the identity and T^g+h = T^g T^h for all g,h ∈ G.  For technical reasons we will require that the probability space  is countably generated modulo null sets (or equivalently, that the Hilbert space L^2() is separable).  Given a measurable function f→ and g ∈ G, we define T^g f   f ∘ T^-g.  We shall often abuse notation and abbreviate (,T) as .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A (symmetric) coset progression is a (multi-)subset[Strictly speaking, one should refer to the tuple (Q, H, r, (v_i)_i=1^r, (N_i)_i=1^r) as the coset progression, rather than just the multi-set Q, as one cannot define key concepts such as rank or the dilates Q without this additional data.  However, we shall abuse notation and use the multi-set Q as a metonym for the entire coset progression.] Q of an additive group G of the form

    Q = H + {n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r |n_i| ≤ N_i ∀ i=1,…,r}

where H is a finite subgroup of G, r ≥ 0 is a non-negative integer (which we call the rank of Q), v_1,…,v_r are elements of G, and N_1,…,N_r > 0 are real numbers.  Here we count the sums n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r with multiplicity, and we view H as a multiset in which each element has an equal multiplicity (not necessarily 1).  Given any > 0, we define the dilate Q of Q by the formula

    Q   H + {n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r: |n_i| ≤ N_i ∀ i=1,…,r}.

sentence:
[Polynomials]  Let P G → K be a function from one additive group G = (G,+) to another K = (K,+).  For any subgroup H of G and for any integer d, we say that P is a polynomial of degree <d along H according to the following recursive definition[Our conventions here are somewhat nonstandard, but are chosen so that the proofs of our main theorems, such as Theorem <ref>, resemble the proofs of warmup results such as Proposition <ref>.]:


  (i)  If d ≤ 0, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if it is identically zero.

  (ii)  If d ≥ 1, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if, for each h ∈ H, there exists a polynomial P_h: G → K of degree <d-1 along H such that 

    P(x+h) = P(x) + P_h(x)

for all x ∈ G.

sentence: [G-system]  Let G = (G,+) be an at most countable additive group.  A G-system (, T) is a probability space = (X, ℬ, μ), together with a collection T = (T^g)_g ∈ G of invertible measure-preserving maps T^g X → X, such that T^0 is the identity and T^g+h = T^g T^h for all g,h ∈ G.  For technical reasons we will require that the probability space  is countably generated modulo null sets (or equivalently, that the Hilbert space L^2() is separable).  Given a measurable function f→ and g ∈ G, we define T^g f   f ∘ T^-g.  We shall often abuse notation and abbreviate (,T) as .

sentence:
[Gowers uniformity norm]  Let G be an at most countable additive group, and let (, T) be a G-system.  If f ∈ L^∞(), Q is a non-empty finite multiset and d is a positive integer, we define the Gowers uniformity (semi-)norm f _U^d_Q() by the formula

    f_U^d_Q()^2^d_h_1,…,h_d,h'_1,…,h'_d ∈ Q∫_X Δ_h_1,h'_1…Δ_h_d,h'_d f dμ

where Δ_h,h' is the nonlinear operator

    Δ_h,h' f   (T^h f) (T^h' f).

More generally, given d non-empty finite multisets Q_1,…,Q_d, we define the Gowers box (semi-)norm
f _^d_Q_1,…,Q_d() by the formula

    f_^d_Q_1,…,Q_d()^2^d_h_i,h'_i ∈ Q_i ∀ i=1,…,d∫_X Δ_h_1,h'_1…Δ_h_d,h'_d f dμ,

so in particular

    f _U^d_Q() = f_^d_Q,…,Q().

Note that the Δ_h,h' commute with each other, and so the ordering of the Q_i is irrelevant.

sentence:
[Coset progression]  A (symmetric) coset progression is a (multi-)subset[Strictly speaking, one should refer to the tuple (Q, H, r, (v_i)_i=1^r, (N_i)_i=1^r) as the coset progression, rather than just the multi-set Q, as one cannot define key concepts such as rank or the dilates Q without this additional data.  However, we shall abuse notation and use the multi-set Q as a metonym for the entire coset progression.] Q of an additive group G of the form

    Q = H + {n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r |n_i| ≤ N_i ∀ i=1,…,r}

where H is a finite subgroup of G, r ≥ 0 is a non-negative integer (which we call the rank of Q), v_1,…,v_r are elements of G, and N_1,…,N_r > 0 are real numbers.  Here we count the sums n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r with multiplicity, and we view H as a multiset in which each element has an equal multiplicity (not necessarily 1).  Given any > 0, we define the dilate Q of Q by the formula

    Q   H + {n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r: |n_i| ≤ N_i ∀ i=1,…,r}.

sentence:
A EW-tableau T is a 0/1-filling of a Ferrers diagram with the following properties:


  1. The top row of T has a 1 in every cell.

  2. Every other row has at least one cell containing a 0.

  3. No four cells of T that form the corners of a rectangle have 0s in two diagonally opposite corners and 1s in the other two.

The size of a EW-tableau is its semiperimeter less one, that is, one less than the sum of its numbers of rows and columns. Let (F) be the set of EW-tableaux on the diagram F.

T ∈(F) and 


  * 0 ≤ x_i < # if i ∈(F),

  * 0 ≤ x_i < # if i ∈(F).

Let (F) be the set of all decorated EW-tableaux on F.

sentence:
Let T be a EW-tableau of shape F. Let S=S(T) be the supplementary tableau
corresponding to T.  Let us call a pair of cells a and b in a tableau non-attacking if they are in different rows and different columns.  We also say 
that b is non-attacking with respect to a if a and b is a non-attacking pair, or simply that b is non-attacking if it is clear from context what a is.
We say that an entry x ∈{0,1} in T_jk is a ∟ entry if and only if there exists a non-attacking x≠x in S_j'k' such that S_j'k and S_jk' both contain x.  We say a cell is a ∟ if it contains a ∟ entry and we say S_j'k' induces T_jk to be a ∟.

  * 0≤ a_i < |{j∈πk : j<i, k<ℓ}| if i∈πℓ,

where π0,π1,π1,π2,… = (π), with the convention π0={0} (see end of Section <ref>).

sentence:
Let us have a family of graphs ℱ. Let 𝒢_n,q be the set of all multigraphs on n vertices with maximum edge multiplicity q and let H ≺ G denote that H is a submultigraph of the multigraph G. Then we define

    _q(n,ℱ) = max{|E(G)| : G∈𝒢_n,q and ∀ F ∈ℱ,  ∄H≺ G, H≅ F}.

This takes the maximum number of edges of a graph that does not contain any F ∈ℱ as a subgraph , not just an induced subgraph.

sentence:
If 𝒜 = (1A,…,kA) is a k-tuple of square matrices and f as above, then

    ∑_σ∈Σsgn(σ) f(σ^-1.𝒜) = ℐ(f,𝐧) det(1A)⋯det(kA)

where det(A) denotes the determinant of a square matrix A, and ℐ(f,𝐧) ∈𝔽 is a scalar depending only on f and on the shape 
𝐧 = (n_1,…,n_k) of 𝒜.

sentence:

and the contraction H/S are defined by

    𝐇|_S={H∈𝐇  :  H⊆ S},

sentence:
Let Γ be a digraph, let G be a group of automorphisms of Γ transitive on the vertices of Γ and let N be a normal subgroup of G. Let α^N denote the N-orbit containing the vertex α of Γ. Then the
normal quotient Γ/N is the digraph whose vertices are the N-orbits on the vertices of Γ, with a directed
edge from α^N to β^N if and only if there is a directed edge of Γ from
α' to β', for some α'∈α^N and some β'∈β^N. The normal quotient is non-trivial
if N  1 and N is not transitive.

Note that the group G acts as a group of automorphisms on Γ/N and induces a transitive action on the vertices of the normal
quotient Γ/N. Also, for adjacent α^N, β^N of Γ/N, each vertex of α^N is adjacent to the same number of vertices in β^N (because N is transitive on both sets). Moreover, the stabiliser in G of the vertex α^N  in Γ/N is G_α N.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Γ be a digraph whose vertex set V has been partitioned into a collection of sets, ℬ, with the additional property that given any two sets B, B' ∈ℬ, and any vertex v ∈ B, the number of arcs from v to B' does not depend on the choice of v ∈ B. Define the odd quotient digraph of Γ  with respect to the partition ℬ to be the digraph whose vertices are the sets B ∈ℬ, with an arc from B to B' if and only if the number of arcs from each v ∈ B to B' is odd.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A signed graph G on the vertex set [n] is a multiset E of one-element subsets of [n], called half-edges , and two-element subsets of [n], called edges , together with a sign map σ:E∩[n]2→{1,-1} such that σ^-1(1) and σ^-1(-1) are each the edge set of a simple graph on [n].
For an edge e∈ E, if σ(e)=1, then e is called a positive edge of G.
If σ(e)=-1, then e is called a negative edge of G.

sentence:
Let G be a signed graph on [n].  
A c-coloring of G is a map 

    ϕ:[n]→{-c,-c+1,…,-1,0,1,…,c}  .

A c-coloring ϕ is proper if ϕ(i)≠ϕ(j) for all positive edges {i,j} in G, ϕ(i)≠ -ϕ(j) for all negative edges {i,j} in G, and ϕ(i)≠ 0 for all half-edges i∈ E(G).
Denote by χ_G(2c+1) the number of proper c-colorings of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a signed graph with sign map σ, and let v be a vertex of G.
We say that the signed graph G' is obtained by switching G at v if the vertex and edge sets for G' are V(G) and E(G), while the sign map σ' for G' is given by

    σ'({i,j}):={[        -σ({i,j}) if  v=i  or  v=j;         σ({i,j})             else ].   .

If H is obtained from G by a finite sequence of switches, we say that G and H are switching equivalent .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let G be a signed graph with an edge e={i,j}∈ E(G) with sign σ(e).
The deletion of G by e, denoted G∖ e, is the signed graph obtained by removing e from E(G).
A contraction of G by e, denoted G/e, is a signed graph in the same switching class as the graph obtained from G by the following process (which is well-defined up to switching equivalence).


  * If σ(e)=1, then delete e from E(G) and contract as in the ordinary graph case by identifying i and j in V(G).
When {i,j} is also present in E(G) as a negative edge, add a half-edge at the vertex given by i=j after contracting (if this half-edge is not already present).

  * If σ(e)=-1, then first switch at an endpoint of e so that σ(e)=1 and proceed as in the positive edge contraction case.


Given a half-edge i∈ E(G), the deletion of G by i, denoted G∖ i, is the signed graph obtained by removing i from E(G).
The contraction of G by i, denoted G/i, is the signed graph with vertex set V(G)∖{i} and edge set {e∖{i}| e∈ E(G)}.

sentence:
A map is a triple M=(V, E, {O_v |  v∈ V}) such that
(V,E) is a graph (See <cit.>) and each O_v is
a cyclic order for the edges incident to the vertex v. For a vertex
v of M, the set A_v of angles around v is

    A_v:={(v_1, v, v_2),  (v_2, v, v_3), …, (v_n-1, v, v_n), (v_n, v,
          v_1)}
  
where the list v v_1, v v_2, …, v v_n is the enumeration of { v
u |  v u ∈ E} without repetition by the cyclic order O_v. We
write an inner angle (u,v,w) by ∠ u v w.  The mirror of
a map M is the map M^R with the cyclic orders reversed. Thus ∠
u v w is an inner angle of the original map, if and only if ∠ w v
u is an inner angle of the mirror of the map.

sentence:
A graphical degree sequence is a sequence of nonnegative integers (d_1, d_2, …, d_n) with even sum such that
    there is a simple graph G on vertex set V={v_1, v_2, …, v_n} in which the degree of of vertex v_i is d_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ n.

    ()    = min{μ(G) : G realizes }, 
    ()    = max{μ(G) : G realizes }.

We refer to these as lower μ and upper μ of a degree sequence, respectively.

sentence:
Given a graph G on n vertices and a nonnegative integer weight b(v) for each vertex v of G,
a subgraph F is called a b-factor if d_F(v)=b(v) for every vertex v∈ V.

sentence: For even k, the k-regular circulant on n vertices, denoted by C(k,n), is the graph with vertex set {1,2,…,n}, where i and j are adjacent if |i-j|≤ k/2. For i<j, here |i-j| denotes min(j-i,  i+n-j).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A split <cit.> of a graph G with vertex set V is
  a bipartition (V_1,V_2) of V ( i.e. ,
  V=V_1∪ V_2, V_1∩V_2=∅)
  such that
  
  
  
  
  * |V_1|>2 and |V_2|>2;
  
  * every vertex of N(V_1) is adjacent to every of N(V_2).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graph G=(V,E) is a k-leaf power graph[This is a
    specialization, introduced by Nishimura  <cit.>,
    of the concept of graph powers , in which the root is a
    tree—but the definition can be extended to the case where T is not
    a tree, but is a graph H (in which case, we consider the distance
    between any two vertices in graph H, not two leaves of a tree).], if
  there is a tree T (called a k-leaf root of graph G) such that:
  
  
  * the leaves of T are the vertices V;
  
  * there is an edge xy∈ E if and only if the distance in T
    between leaves x and y is at most k,
    d_T(x,y)⩽ k.

sentence:
[Decompositions, Decomposition sets]
A decomposition is a triple ( x,z,y ) of elements of P with x < z<y 
such that [x,z]× [z,y] ≅ [x,y] via an isomorphism ψ which sends (u,z)↦ u and (z,v)↦ (v). 
A decomposition is trivial if either z =x or z=y. 
Otherwise the decomposition is proper . 

A decomposition set  is a set of decompositions in P which 
contains all trivial decompositions.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Decomposition complexes]
Let P be a finite poset and  a decomposition set of P. 
The decomposition complex of P resp. the decomposition set  is defined as 

𝒟(P,) := {  |   C  non-empty chain in  P}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A proper decomposition (x,z,y) is said to be minimal with respect to A ⊆ P if it is minimal 
among all proper decompositions for which x,y ∈ A. 

Given a decomposition (x,z,y), its complementary decomposition is (x,ψ(x,y),y). 
It is easy to see that a decomposition if proper if and only if its complementary decomposition if proper. 
A decomposition set  is called symmetric if for any decomposition its complementary decomposition 
is contained in , too.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Realizations of decomposition sets]
Let  be a symmetric, downwards closed decomposition set of P. 
A -realization is an embedding ϕ : P → B_n 
of P to the power set lattice of some finite set [n]:={ 1, … , n} 
such that for all pairs of complementary decompositions (x,z,y),(x,z',y)∈ the following holds: 

ϕ(x)=ϕ(z)∩ϕ(z')      as well as      ϕ(y)=ϕ(z)∪ϕ(z').

If there exists such an embedding P is called -realizable.   
ϕ is called the realization of the decomposition set .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Polytopal pseudo-complexes]
A polytopal pseudo-complex ℱ 
is a finite set of polytopes such that faces of polytopes of ℱ are 
contained in ℱ and intersections of polytopes of ℱ
are unions of polytopes of ℱ.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Realizations of decomposition complexes]
Let 𝒟(P,) be a decomposition complex with -realization ϕ. 
Then clearly, the set of polytopes

𝒟(P,):=  { Γ(A)   |    A ∈𝒟(P,) }
 
forms a polytopal pseudo-complex. 
We call it a realization of the decomposition complex of P respective .

sentence:
Let τ be a transportation from μ_A to μ_B.
Let E_1, E_2 be nonempty sets such that E_1 ∪ E_2 = {(a,b):τ(a,b)>0} and if (a_1,b_1) ∈ E_1, (a_1, b_2) ∈ E_2, then m(a_1, b_1) ∩m(a_2, b_2) = ∅.
Then E_1, E_2 form a partition of τ.
Let η_1 = ∑_(a,b) ∈ E_1τ(a,b), define probability functions μ_A,1(x) = η_1^-1∑_(x,b) ∈ E_1τ(x,b) and μ_B,1(y) = η_1^-1∑_(a,y) ∈ E_1τ(a,y), and let us define transportation τ_1: μ_A,1→μ_B,1 as τ(a,b) = η_1^-1τ(a,b) if (a,b) ∈ E_1 and τ(a,b) = 0 otherwise.
Define η_2, μ_A,2, μ_B,2, τ_2 similarly.

sentence:
A string x is primitive if  x cannot be expressed as a non-trivial power of any string.
For any string x, there is a primitive string y so that x=y^m for some integer m≥ 1. Such y and m are unique and y is called the primitive root of x.
Two strings x and y are conjugates if there are strings u and v so that x=uv and y=vu. Note that x is a trivial conjugate of
itself. Often the term rotation is used for conjugates.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
[Notation and terminology] 

If a  satisfies one of three conditions (a), (b), or (c) of Lemma <ref>,
we will refer to such  as factorizable .
We use the following notational convention for s:
a  U consists of two squares u^2 and U^2, where |u|<|U| and so  we refer  to u^2 respective U^2 as the shorter respective longer , square of U,  and to the starting position of u^2 and U^2 as the starting position of U.
The unique exponents are denoted as U and U, the repeating primitive part of u is denoted as u_1, the prefix of u_1 completing u is denoted as u_2.  Thus u=u_1^Uu_2 and
U=uu_1^U=u_1^Uu_2u_1^U.
Since u_2 is a non-trivial proper prefix of u_1, there is complement øu_2 of u_2 in u_1 so that u_1=u_2øu_2.
The conjugate øu_2u_2 of u_1 is denoted as u̧_1, i.e. 
u̧_1=øu_2u_2.

sentence:
A factor u=x[i..j] of x can be cyclically shifted
right by 1 position if x[i]=x[j1]. The factor u can be cyclically 
shifted right by k positions if u can be cyclically shifted right by 1 position and the factor x[i1..j1] can be cyclically
shifted right be k­1 positions. Similarly for left cyclic
shifts . By a trivial cyclic shift we mean a shift by 0 positions.

sentence:
For two substrings u and v of a string x such thatu<v,
the gap G(u,v) is defined as v­u and the tail T(u,v)
is defined as v­u.
For two s U and V such thatU< V, the gap G( U, V)=G(u,v)
and the tail T( U, V)=T(u,v).

sentence:
Let μ∈ [0,1], G be a graph with maximum degree Δ, and A ⊆ V(G). We say that G[A] is a μ-quasirandom subgraph of G if for every pair of not necessarily distinct vertices u, v ∈ V(G), we have 
    ||N(u)∩ N(v) ∩ A|-μ |N(u)∩ N(v)|| ≤√(Δ)(logΔ)^5.

sentence: Let G be a graph and C be a correspondence assignment of G. We say C is total if C_uv and C_vu are total for every edge uv of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph and let C be a total correspondence assignment of G. If uv ∈ E(G), c_1∈ C(u), c_2∈ C(v), then we say c_1 and c_2 correspond under C if C_uv(c_1) = c_2, or equivalently, C_vu(c_2) = c_1. If the correspondence assignment is clear from the context, then we simply say that c_1 and c_2 correspond .

sentence:
Let Γ=(V,E) and Γ'=(V',E') be simple graphs, with no loops or parallel edges.


  * A graph map f:Γ→Γ' is a set map V → V'
that preserves adjacency, that is, if vw ∈ E, then either  f(v) is
adjacent to f(w) in Γ', denoted by f(v) ∼_Γ' f(w), or f(v)=f(w).


  * Let v ∈ V and v' ∈ V' be distinguished vertices.  A based graph map
is a graph map f:(Γ, v) → (Γ', v') such that f(v)=v'.

sentence:
The cartesian product ΓΓ' of two graphs, Γ and Γ',
is the graph with vertex set V × V' and an edge between (v,v') and (w,w') if
either


  * v=w and v' ∼_Γ' w', or

  * v ∼_Γ w and v'=w'.

sentence:

σ^-1(n)=τ^-1(n), or vertical if σ^-1(n)=τ^-1(n)± 1.


  * All vertices in a horizontal 6-cycle are at the same level.
A vertical 6-cycle contains two vertices in each of three consecutive levels.

sentence:
Let k_*, n_2 be given with n_2 > (2k_*)^2. Then there is N=N(n_2, k_*) such that any finite graph G, 
|G|>N with the non-k_*-order property admits a partition G = ⟨ G_i ⟩ 
into disjoint pieces G_i which satisfies:


  * for each G_i ∈G, |G_i| ∈{ n_2, n_2+1 }

  * (after possibly omitting one element) each G_i is either a complete graph or an empty graph

  * for all pairs G_i, G_j ∈G (after possibly omitting one element from each) there exists a truth
value t(G_i, G_j) ∈{0,1} such that for all but ≤ 2k_* a∈ G_i,
for all but ≤ 2k_* b ∈ G_j, aRb ≡(G_i, G_j).


Moreover, N=n_1n_2 suffices for any n_1 > (c n_2)^(2+r)^k_*, as computed in Theorem
<ref> in the case where Δ = Δ_k_* (in that calculation 
c=t^k_*/(2+r)^k_* was a constant depending only on Δ, i.e. Δ_k_*) .

sentence: A anchored pair of sequences is a triplet (X,Y,z_0), where X∈{U,D}^n, Y∈{L,R}^n and z_0 ∈ [n]. We say that the pair (X,Y) is anchored at z_0.

sentence:
[Annealed version of the Benjamini–Schramm convergence]
	We say that (σ_n)_n∈ converges in the annealed Benjamini–Schramm sense to a random variable σ_∞ with values in  if the sequence of random variables (σ_n,i_n)_n∈ converges in distribution to σ_∞ with respect to the local distance d.
	In this case we write σ_naBS⟶σ_∞ instead of  (σ_n,i_n)d→σ_∞.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: converges in the annealed Benjamini–Schramm sense

sentence:
[Quenched version of the Benjamini–Schramm convergence]
	
	We say that (σ_n)_n∈ converges in the quenched Benjamini–Schramm sense 
	to a random measure ν^∞ on 
	if the sequence of conditional laws (ℒaw((σ_n,i_n)|σ_n))_n∈
	converges in distribution to ν^∞ with respect to the weak topology induced by the local distance d.
	In this case we write σ_nqBS⟶ν^∞ instead of ℒaw((σ_n,i_n)|σ_n)d→ν^∞.

plain_text_term: converges in the quenched Benjamini–Schramm sense

sentence:
Let  be the family of trees that:


  * contains all trees of order at most 4,
 [-1.75em]

  * is closed under the four Operations _1, _2, _3, and _4 that are listed below, which extend the tree T' to a tree T by attaching a tree to the vertex v ∈ V(T'), called the attacher of T', and
 [-1.75em]

  * is closed under the Operations _5, and _6 listed below, which extend the tree T' to a tree T by attaching trees to the vertices v_1 and v_2 of T', called the attachers of T'.
 [-1.75em]



  * Operation _1: Let T_∈{T_1,T_2,T_8} be a PDI-subtree of T' and let v = v(T_). Add a new vertex u and the edge vu.
 [-1.75em]

  * Operation _2: Let T_∈{T_4,T_11,T_12,T_13,T_15} be a PDI-subtree of T' and let v = v(T_). Add a path u_1u_2 to T' and the edge vu_1. 
 [-1.75em]

  * Operation _3: Let v be an arbitrary vertex of T'. Add a path u_1u_2u_3 to T' and the edge vu_2.
 [-1.75em]

  * Operation _4: Let T_∈{T_1,T_2,T_3,T_5,T_6,T_7,T_9,T_10} be a PDI-subtree of T' and let v = v(T_). Add a path u_1u_2u_3 to T' and the edge vu_1.
 [-1.75em]

  * Operation _5: Let T_≅ T_6 be a PDI-subtree of T' and let v_1 = v_1(T_), v_2 = v_2(T_). Add a path u_1u_3 to T' and the edge v_1u_1, and add a new vertex u_2 and the edge v_2u_2.
 [-1.75em]

  * Operation _6: Let T_≅ T_14 be a PDI-subtree of T' and let v_1 = v_1(T_), v_2 = v_2(T_). Remove the edge v_1v_2, and add a path u_1u_2u_3 and the edges v_1u_1 and v_2u_2.

     ∀∈^⊗  3,

  
  * a unit u :→ satisfying:
    
    m∘(u⊗𝕀)(1⊗)=   =m∘(𝕀⊗ u)(⊗ 1), ∀∈.

sentence:
A (coassociative, counital) coalgebra  over a field  is a -linear space endowed with two linear homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a coproduct Δ :→⊗ satisfying the coassociativity condition:
    
    ∀∈, (Δ⊗𝕀)∘Δ()=   (𝕀⊗Δ)∘Δ(),

  
  * a counit :→ satisfying:
    
    ∀∈, (⊗𝕀)∘Δ()=   =(𝕀⊗)∘Δ().

sentence:
For every c>0 and every positive integer R we say that a graph
G=(V,E) is  an (R,c)-expander if |N(U)|≥ c|U| for
every subset of vertices U⊆ V such that |U|≤ R.

sentence:
For every graph G, we say that a non-edge uv∉ E(G) is a
booster with respect to G, if either G ∪{uv} is
Hamiltonian or ℓ(G ∪{uv})>ℓ(G). We denote by
ℬ_G the set of boosters with respect to G.

sentence:
When the general fibers of γ_k have positive dimension, the k-dual variety has 
lower dimension than expected, and in this case we say that the embedding is k-defective , 
with positive k-dual defect

    _k (X):=m+n-n+kn- X^(k).

When X^(k) has the expected dimension, we set

    _k X^(k) := (γ_k) X^(k).

 is said to be k-jet ample 
 if for every collection of points x_1,…,x_t∈ X and integers 
 k_1,…,k_t such that ∑ k_i=k+1, the map H^0(m, 𝒪(1)) → H^0(X,)
 →⊕ _i=1^t H^0(X,  /m_x_i^k_i) is surjective.

sentence: A partition of n is a non-increasing sequence of integers summing to n, i.e. a sequence λ = (λ_1, …, λ_k) with λ_1≥λ_2≥…≥λ_k and ∑_i=1^kλ_i=n; we write λ⊢ n. For example, (3,2,2) ⊢ 7.

sentence: A divisor D as above is said to be a lifting of D_G. If D_G admits a lifting to a divisor D with r(D)=r_G(D_G), then we say that D_G is smoothable .

sentence:
A rank 3 simple matroid M consists of a finite set ℰ and a collection of subsets ℱ satisfying:


  * Every E_1 and E_2 in ℰ are contained in exactly one element of ℱ.

  * ℱ contains at least two elements. 

We refer to every E in ℰ as an element of the matroid, and to F in ℱ as a flat . The unique flat containing a pair E_i and E_j of elements will be denoted F_ij.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A rank 3 simple matroid is realizable over k if there is a bijection between its elements and a collection {ℓ_1,…,ℓ_m} of lines in ℙ^2_k, such that ℓ_i_1,…,ℓ_i_k have non-empty intersection  if and only if the corresponding elements of M are contained in a flat.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let 𝒟 be a divisor on a metrized complex C with underlying graph G. If D is the divisor obtained from 𝒟 by forgetting the metrized complex structure, we say that 𝒟 is an extension of D.

sentence:
For a monotone increasing graph property P, the
global resilience of G with respect to P is the
minimum number 0≤ r≤ 1 such that by deleting r· e(G)
edges from G one can obtain a graph G' not having P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a monotone increasing graph property P, the
local resilience of G with respect to P is the
minimum number 0≤ r≤ 1 such that by deleting at each vertex
v at most r· d_G(v) edges one can obtain a graph not having
P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Suppose that T and H are fixed graphs and assume that T is 2-balanced. The T-resolution of H is the sequence F_1, …, F_k of all types of T-coverings of H whose T-density does not exceed m_T(F_T,H^e), ordered by their T-density (with ties broken arbitrarily). The associated threshold sequence is the sequence p_0, p_1, …, p_k, where p_0 = n^-v_T / e_T and p_i = n^-1/m_T(F_i) for i ∈ [k].

sentence: A hypergraph H is called a rank-i hypergraph if for any hyperedge e ∈ E(H) with |e|>i there exists a hyperedge e' ⊂ e with |e'|=i.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a family of simply connected regions bounded by simple closed curves in general position in the plane. Let k be an even integer. C is called k-admissible if for any pair C_1,C_2 ∈




  * C_i ∖ C_j and C_j ∖ C_i are connected, and

  * ∂ C_i and ∂ C_j cross in at most k points.

sentence: For a finite family 𝒞={C_1,C_2,…,C_n} of geometric objects in the plane, the union complexity of 𝒞 is the number of faces of all dimensions of the arrangement of the objects' boundaries, which lie on the boundary of ∪_i=1^n C_i.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
 Let G be an embedded graph with canonically checkerboard coloured embedded medial graph G_m, and let W_m(G_m)=(α, β, γ) be a medial weight system. Then the topological transition polynomial of G is:

    Q(G, (α, β, γ), t) :=q(G_m; W_m,t).

sentence:
Consider a finite planar simply connected domain R⊂]0,n+1[×[0,1]. Given a bead configuration 𝐁 of the domain R, the height function H=H^𝐁 (for convenience we omit 𝐁) is the function

    H:R∩(ℤ×[0,1])→ℝ

unique up to a constant which verifies the following conditions. The constant is fixed once we fixe the height of any point of R∩(ℤ×[0,1]).


  * The function H is up-continuous, i.e. , for any point (i_0,y_0)∈ D,
      
    lim_y→ y_0^+H(i_0,y)=H(i_0,y_0).


  * For any i∈{1,...,n}, and for any y_1,y_2∈[0,1], y_1<y_2, H(i,y_2)-H(i,y_1) is equal to the number of beads on the i^th thread between y_1 and y_2.

  * If there is a bead at some point (i_0,y_0), then on the neighboring threads i=i_0±1, we have
      
    lim_y→ y_0^-H(i_0± 1,y)=H(i_0,y_0)-1/2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For any planar simply connected domain R⊂]0,n+1[×[0,1], the bead model on it is said to have fixed boundary condition if, given a fixed exterior bead configuration 𝐁^ext on (ℤ×ℝ)\ R, the union of any bead configuration of R and 𝐁^ext is a bead configuration of ℤ×ℝ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For the bead model on R=[1,n]×[0,1], a function

    H^∂:({0,n+1}×[0,1])∪({1,2,...,n}×{0,1})→ℝ

is called boundary height function if


  * H^∂ takes value in 1/2ℤ up to a constant.

  * Restricted to {0}×[0,1] or {n+1}×[0,1], H^∂ viewed as a function of y is non-decreasing, piecewise constant and every jump is equal to 1.

  * For every i∈{0,1,...,n+1}, H^∂(i,1)-H^∂(i,0)∈ℕ.

  * For every i∈{0,1,...,n}, H^∂(i+1,1)-H^∂(i,1) and H^∂(i+1,0)-H^∂(i,0) take values in {±1/2}.

A bead model on R is said to have fixed boundary condition given by H^∂ if every bead configurations 𝐁 can be extended to a bead configuration of {0,...n+1}×[0,1], and the height function of the extended configuration coincides with H^∂ where H^∂ is defined.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: boundary height function;fixed boundary condition given by

sentence:
For every given pair

    (a,b)∈{-n/2+1,-n/2+2,...,n/2-2,n/2-1}×ℕ^*,

we say that a toroidal model has periodic boundary condition (a,b) if its height change (H_x,H_y) is equal to (a,b).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a fixed, resp. periodic, boundary condition of the bead model with N beads, the uniform bead measure is the uniform probability measure of the vertical coordinates on the convex set determined by the fixed, resp. periodic, boundary condition, viewed as a subspace of [0,1]^N, resp. 𝕋^N, equipped with the Lebesgue measure.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a bead model with fixed number of beads. Let N be the number of beads and n be that of threads. Consider a random bead configuration as a random vector X taking values in [0,1]^N, where every component of X is the vertical coordinates of the corresponding bead (in the toroidal case the coordinates are in the sense of modulo 1).

For any point 𝐲=(y_1,y_2,...,y_N)∈[0,1]^N, define ρ(𝐲) as the density of the bead measure ℙ at the point 𝐲 with respect to the Lebesgue measure of [0,1]^N whenever it exists, i.e. ,

    ρ(𝐲)=lim_ε→ 0ℙ(X∈∏_i=1^N[y_i-ε,y_i+ε])/(2ε)^N

whenever this limit exists.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
If the density ρ is well defined almost everywhere, then for the bead model with a fixed boundary condition or periodic condition, we define the (adjusted) combinatorial entropy S associated to the random variable X of the bead model as

    S(X)=∫_[0,1]^N-ρ(𝐲)lnρ(𝐲)dy_1...dy_N+Nln n,

where N is the number of beads and n is the number of threads.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any slope (s,t)∈[-1/2,1/2]×[0,∞], define the local entropy function ent(s,t) of the bead model as the following function:

    ent(s,t)=
    
    0     if t=0,
    
    -∞    if s=±1/2, t≠ 0,
    (1+ln(cos(π s)/π t))t     otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a bead configuration 𝐁 on threads x∈{i-1/n-1,i=1,2,...,n}, y∈[0,1], the normalized height function h=h^𝐁 (again for convenience we omit 𝐁) is defined as

    h(x,y)=1/n-1H((n-1)x+1,y)

along every thread

    {i-1/n-1,i=1,2,...,n}×[0,1],

then extended to the whole unit square D in the following way: for every y∈[0,1], the height function x↦ h(x,y) viewed as a function of x is taken to be the piecewise linear extension of h(i-1/n-1,y).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a bead model with n threads defined on D. The normalized height function h:D→ℝ is said to have
one of the boundary conditions below if there exists a normalized bead model height function h':[-1/n-1,1+1/n-1]×[0,1]→ℝ such that h'|_D=h and

(a) if 𝒰 is a subspace of the functions h^∂_n:∂([-1/n-1,1+1/n-1]×[0,1])→ℝ, then we say h has a
boundary condition lying in 𝒰 if

    h'|_∂([-1/n-1,1+1/n-1]×[0,1])∈𝒰.


(b) we say h has a fixed boundary condition h^∂_n:∂([-1/n-1,1+1/n-1]×[0,1])→ℝ if

    h'|_∂([-1/n-1,1+1/n-1]×[0,1])=h^∂_n,

i.e. , 𝒰 has only one element.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O
plain_text_term: boundary condition lying in;fixed boundary condition;i.e.;(c)

sentence: Given the unit square D and a boundary condition h^∂ defined on ∂ D, a function h is called admissible if it is horizontally 1/2-Lipschitz, vertically non decreasing, and when restricted on ∂ D it is equal to h^∂. Denote by ℋ the space of admissible functions.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any admissible function h∈ℋ, its entropy is defined as

    Ent(h)=∬_Dent(∂h/∂x,∂h/∂y)dxdy,

and for any admissible function h∈ℋ, its entropy is defined as

    Ent(h)=Ent(h).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence: Given a tilt (s,t)∈]-1/2,1/2[×]0,+∞[, for any n∈ℕ^*, a fixed boundary condition h^∂,0_n of a bead model with n threads is called almost planar if there exists a plane of tilt (s,t) and h^∂,0_n is chosen to give the best approximation of that plane.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a tilt (s,t)∈]-1/2,1/2[×]0,+∞[, for any n∈ℕ^* and m∈ℕ^* large, an almost planar region R_mn,n^0 is a tall region tileable by lozenges corresponding to h^∂,0_n constructed as in Section <ref>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let r ≥ 1 be an integer. A triangulation of the cylinder of height r is a rooted planar map such that all faces are triangles except for two distinguished faces verifying:


  * The boundaries of the two distiguished faces form two disjoint simple cycles.

  * The boundary of one of the two distinguished faces contains the root edge, and this face is on the right hand side of the root edge. We call this face the root face and the other distiguished face the exterior face.

  * Every vertex of the exterior face is at graph distance exactly r from the boundary of the root face, and edges of the boundary of the exterior face also belong to a triangle whose third vertex is at distance r-1 from the root face.

For every intergers r,p,q ≥ 1, a triangulation of the (r,p,q)-cylinder is a triangulation of the cylinder of height r such that its root face has degree p and its exterior face has degree q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: triangulation of the cylinder of height r;triangulation of the (r,p,q)-cylinder

restricted if and only if G contains no alternating cycle with respect to
M, i.e., M is alternating cycle-free.

sentence:

(V,ℱ), where ℱ⊆2^V is a non-empty set system
satisfying the following conditions:

Accessibility: for every non-empty X∈ℱ there is an x∈
X such that X-{x}∈ℱ;

Exchange: for X,Y∈ℱ,| X| =|
Y| +1, there is an x∈ X-Y such that Y∪{x}∈ℱ.

sentence:
Let  be the set of monotone kernels on , ,
the set of all symmetric measurable functions W:→ that satisfy (<ref>).

Let  be the
corresponding class of graph limits, , the class of graph limits that can
be represented as _W for some W∈. We call these graph limits
monotone .
