sentence:
The index r is reversibly deletable for p with respect to B if the map
 
    d_r: nBpw→n-1Bd_r(p)d_r(w)

is a bijection for all w failing the gap vector criterion for every gap vector of p with respect to B (i.e., d_r is a bijection for all w such that nBpw≠∅).

The set of indices R is reversibly deletable for p with respect to B if the map 

    d_R: nBpw→n-|R|Bd_R(p)d_R(w)

is a bijection for all w failing the gap vector criterion for every gap vector of p with respect to B (i.e., d_R is a bijection for all w such that nBpw≠∅).

sentence:
Let (σ, X) be a vincular pattern of length ℓ and let p∈k be a prefix pattern with known set of gap vectors G.  Let w∈{1,2,…, n,   }^n+m be a word with m copies of  and no other letters repeated.  Then w is a containment scenario for p if the following criteria are satisfied:
 
  
  * w_1 ⋯ w_k  p.  Note this implies  does not appear in the first k letters.
  
  * w_1 ⋯ w_k fails all gap vector criteria in G.
  
  * There is some subsequence 1≤ i_1 < ⋯ < i_ℓ≤ n+m such that w(i_1) ⋯ w(i_ℓ) σ and w(i_x+1)= for each x such that i_x≥ k and there is a dash between σ_x and σ_x+1 (i.e., x∉X).
  
  * No subsequence of w is a containment scenario (i.e., w has minimal length).

sentence:
Let t_0<<t_1 be real numbers. The branching process family
(_t)_t∈ (t_0,t_1)=(_Y_t,Z_t,Y^0_t,Z^0_t)_t∈ (t_0,t_1)
is -critical if the following hold:

  
  *  There exist δ>0 and R > 1 with (-δ,+δ) ⊆ (t_0,t_1) such that the
probability generating functions
	
    g_t(y,z) :=  g_Y_t,Z_t(y,z) = (y^Y_tz^Z_t)     and    
     g^0_t(y,z) := g_Y^0_t,Z^0_t(y,z) = (y^Y_t^0z^Z_t^0)

are defined and analytic on the domain 

    { (t,y,z)∈×^2 :   |t-| < δ and  |y|,|z| < R}.


  *  We have

    Y_ =1,      Y^0_ >0 
        and    .  Y_t|_t=  > 0 .


  *  There exists some k_0∈ such that

    min{Y_=k_0, Z_=k_0,  Y_=k_0+1, Z_=k_0,  Y_=k_0, Z_=k_0+1} > 0 .

sentence:
Let (_t)_t∈ (t_0,t_1) be a -critical branching process family,
and let δ, R and k_0 be as in Definition <ref>.
Given t,η≥ 0 with |t-|< δ, 
we say that the branching process _Y,Z,Y^0,Z^0 is of type (t,η)
(with respect to (_t), δ, R, and k_0) 
if the following hold:

  
  *  Writing := {(y,z) ∈^2:   |y|,|z|<R}, 
the expectations
	
    (y,z):=g_Y,Z(y,z) = (y^Yz^Z)     and    ^0(y,z) := g_Y^0,Z^0(y,z) = (y^Y^0z^Z^0)

are defined (i.e., the expectations converge absolutely) for all (y,z) ∈.

  *  For all (y,z) ∈ we have

    |(y,z)-g_t(y,z)|≤η    and    
     |^0(y,z)-g^0_t(y,z)|  ≤η .

sentence: A quasigroup is a set Q endowed with a binary operation x· y such that the equation x· y=z can be uniquely resolved whenever two of the three values x,y,z∈ Q are known. Quasigroups with a multiplicative unit element are called loops. Two quasigroups Q(·) and R(∘) are isotopic if α(x)∘β(y)=γ(x· y) holds for some bijective maps α,β,γ:  Q→ R. If Q(·) and R(∘) are isotopic groups and the are isomorphic.

sentence: Let  be an algebraically closed field and (Q,·) be a finite quasigroup of order n. A dual multinet labeled by Q is a triple (α_1,α_2,α_3) of maps Q→(2,) such that for any x,y∈ Q, the points α_1(x), α_2(y) and α_3(xy) are collinear. The dual multinet is said to be light if the maps α_1,α_2,α_3 are injective.

sentence:
Let Q,R be quasigroups, Λ=(Λ_1,Λ_2,Λ_3), Δ=(Δ_1,Δ_2,Δ_3) dual multinets labeled by Q and R. Let (α_1,α_2,α_3) and (β_1,β_2,β_3) be the respective labelings. We say that Λ is a dual submultinet of Δ, if Q≤ R and α_i=β_i|_Q for i=1,2,3.

We say that a group-labeled light dual multinet Λ cannot be extended if it is not the proper dual submultinet of a group-labeled light dual multinet Δ.

sentence:
If G is an embedded graph, then H is a twisted dual of G if it can be written in the form

    H=G^∏^6_i=1_i(A_i),
 
  
where the A_i's partition E(G), and the _i's are the six elements of . 

Equivalently, if l is an arbitrary ordering of the edges of G, then H is a twisted dual of G if (G,ℓ)= (H,ℓ) for some ∈^e(G), i.e. H is a twisted dual of G if (H,ℓ) is in the orbit of (G,ℓ) under the ribbon group action. Note that twisted duality is symmetric, so we may speak of H and G as being twisted duals of one another.

sentence:
Let G be an embedded graph with embedded medial graph G_m.  Define the medial weight system W_m(G_m) using the canonical checkerboard colouring of G_m as follows.  A vertex v has state weights given by an ordered triple (α_v, β_v, γ_v), indicating the weights of the white split, black split, and crossing state, in that order. We write (α, β, γ) for the set of these ordered triples, indexed equivalently either by the vertices of G_m or by the edges of G.  Then the topological transition polynomial of G is:

    Q(G, (α, β, γ), t) :=q(G_m; W_m,t).

sentence:
The   Kadanoff sand pile model with parameter D, KSPM(D), is defined by:
  
    
  * A set of configurations , consisting in ultimately null non-negative integer sequences.
    
  * A set of iteration rules: we have a transition from a configuration σ to a configuration σ ' on column i, and we note   σi→σ' when
    

  * σ'_i-1=σ_i-1 + D-1 (for i ≠ 0)

  * σ'_i = σ_i - D

  * σ'_i+D-1 = σ_i+D-1 + 1

  * σ'_j = σ_j for j ∉{i-1, i, i+D-1 }. 

We also say that i is fired.

sentence:
[In-degree and in-edges]
Consider graph G := G_1 + G_2 + G_3 +2edges. Let G^' := G_1 + G_2 + G_3 be subgraph of the graph G. Let g ∈ V(G) and let d_0(g) to be the degree of vertex g ∈ V(G^'). Then define in-degree of vertex g ∈ V(G) to be d^+(g) := d(g) - d_0(g). We say that for some i ∈{ 1,2,3 } G_i has t in-edges if and only if 
    ∑_g ∈ V(G_i)d^+(g) = t.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let K ∈ℝ and n ∈_+. We say
  that (G,μ, σ) satisfies the CD^σ inequality CD^σ(K,n) if we have for any
  vector field f: V→𝕂^d and any vertex x∈ V,
  
    Γ_2^σ(f)(x)≥1/n| Δ^σ f(x) |^2+KΓ^σ(f)(x).

  We call K a lower curvature bound of (G,μ, σ) and n a dimension parameter. We define the n-dimensional Ricci curvature K_n(G,μ,σ;x) of (G,μ, σ) at the vertex x∈ V to be the largest K that the inequality (<ref>) holds for a given dimension parameter n. We further define the precise n-dimensional Ricci curvature lower bound K_n(G,μ,σ) of (G,μ, σ) as

    K_n(G,μ,σ):=min_x∈ V K_n(G,μ,σ;x).

We also simply write K_n(σ;x) and K_n(σ) when the setting (G,μ) is clear.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (G,μ,σ) be given. We define the frustration index ι^σ(S) for ∅≠ S ⊆ V as

    ι^σ(S) :=   min_τ: S →  H∑_{x,y}∈ E_S
    w_xy|σ_xyτ(y)-τ(x)|_2,1
    
    =   min_τ: S →  H∑_{x,y}∈ E_S
    w_xy|σ^τ_xy-id|_2,1,

where E_S is the edge set of the induced subgraph of S in G.

sentence:
Let (G, μ, σ) be given.
The k-way Cheeger constant h_k^σ is defined as

    h_k^σ := min_{S_i}_i=1^kmax_1 ≤ i ≤ kϕ^σ(S_i),

where the minimum is taken over all possible nontrivial  k-subpartitions {S_i}_i=1^k of V and

    ϕ^σ(S):=ι^σ(S) + |E(S,V∖ S)|/μ(S).

sentence:
[CD^σ(K,∞) inequality]
Let K∈ℝ. We say the graph G with a signature σ satisfies the curvature dimension inequality CD^σ(K,∞) if we have for any vector field f:V→𝕂^d and any vertex x∈ V,

    Γ_2^σ(f)(x)≥ KΓ^σ(f)(x).

The precise ∞-dimensional Ricci curvature lower bound K_∞(σ) is defined as the largest constant K such that (<ref>) holds.

sentence:
[CD^σ inequality]
  Let K ∈ℝ and n ∈_+. We say
  that (G,μ, σ) satisfies the CD^σ inequality CD^σ(K,n) if we have for any
  vector field f: V→𝕂^d and any vertex x∈ V,
  
    Γ_2^σ(f)(x)≥1/n| Δ^σ f(x) |^2+KΓ^σ(f)(x).

  We call K a lower curvature bound of (G,μ, σ) and n a dimension parameter. We define the n-dimensional Ricci curvature K_n(G,μ,σ;x) of (G,μ, σ) at the vertex x∈ V to be the largest K that the inequality (<ref>) holds for a given dimension parameter n. We further define the precise n-dimensional Ricci curvature lower bound K_n(G,μ,σ) of (G,μ, σ) as

    K_n(G,μ,σ):=min_x∈ V K_n(G,μ,σ;x).

We also simply write K_n(σ;x) and K_n(σ) when the setting (G,μ) is clear.

sentence:
Given a (d× d)-matrix A=(a_ij), we define the average (2,1)-norm |A|_2,1 of A as

    |A|_2,1:=1/d∑_i=1^d(∑_j=1^d|a_ij|^2)^1/2.

If we denote the vector of the i-th column of A by A^i, this norm can be rewritten as |A|_2,1:=1/d∑_i=1^d |A^i|. Recall that |A^i|^2:=(A^i)^TA^i.

sentence:
Let (G,σ) be a finite, connected graph the signature σ: E^or→ H. A function τ: V→ H is constant on G with respect to σ if, for all (x,y) ∈ E^or, we have

    σ_xyτ(y) = τ(x).

In other words, τ is a switching function such that σ^τ is trivial, i.e., σ^τ_xy=id∈ H for all (x,y)∈ E^or.

sentence:
[Skeletons]
  A skeleton is a  tree T that admits a black-red
  coloring λ of V(T), a sequence T_0,T_1, …, T_t of
  trees, and a sequence P_1, …,P_t of paths, each of which is a 4-path or a 6-path, 
  such that: 
  
  
  * T_0 is a 3-path, T_t = T, and
  for i∈[t] the tree T_i is obtained from T_i-1 by
  adding P_i so that the joint of P_i is identified
  with a vertex of T_i-1;
   
  * for T_0=x_0x_1x_2x_3, we have λ(x_0)= λ(x_3)= black 
  and λ(x_1)= λ(x_2)= red;
  
  * for each P_i=x_0⋯ x_k, i∈[t], it holds that
  λ(x_0)= λ(x_k)= black, λ(x_1)= λ(x_k-1)= red,
  if k=4, then x_k/2= red, 
  and if k=6, then x_k/2= black 
  and λ(x_2)=λ(x_4)= red.

sentence:
[Bunch of squares] 
  Let k ≥ 1. A bunch B of k squares (or simply, a bunch ) is a graph obtained from the union of k pairwise
  edge-disjoint squares, say Q_1,…,Q_k, such that each of these squares contains
  two non-adjacent vertices a, b,
  and V(Q_i)∩ V(Q_j)={a,b} for 1≤ i<j≤ k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Hanging-square graphs] 
A graph H is a hanging-square graph if it is the union of a skeleton T_H
and a set ℬ of maximal bunches so that the following holds.


  (i) For each B ∈ℬ, at least one joint of B is identified with vertices of T_H;
accordingly, if only one joint is identified, then
we refer to B as a 1-bunch 
and if two joints are identified, then
we refer to B as a 2-bunch . Moreover, if B' ∈ℬ and V(B) ∩ V(B') ≠∅, then V(B) ∩ V(B') ⊆ V(T_H).


  (ii) If B is a 2-bunch, then there exists a brrb-path P_B=x_0x_1x_2x_3 in T_H  
such that either x_0, x_2, or x_1, x_3 are the joints of B. Moreover, 
if B' ∈ℬ and B ≠ B', then P_B ≠ P_B'. We say that the path P_B is occupied 
at x_0, x_2 (or at x_1, x_3) by B. Each brrb-path is occupied either at none, or at 2 vertices.


  (iii) For each brrb-path P_B=x_0x_1x_2x_3 occupied at x_0, x_2 
(symmetric condition in the case that P_B is occupied at x_1, x_3),
it holds that d_H(x_1)=2  and for H' = H-E(B) exactly one of the following properties is satisfied.

 
  * d_H'(x_0) ≥ 1, d_H'(x_2) = 2 and d_H'(x_3) ≥ 1 
 
  * d_H'(x_0) = 1, d_H'(x_2) > 2 and d_H'(x_3) ≥ 1. 
 
 
 
 In other words, item (iii) says that x_1  is neither the joint of a 1-bunch, nor 
 the joint of a building path of T_H, and that 
 joints of 1-bunches and joints of building paths of T_H may
 correspond either to x_0 and x_3, 
 or to x_2 and x_3 (namely, such joints cannot simultaneously correspond to x_0 and x_2).

sentence: Given integers s≥ 2 and q≥ 0, a multigraph (V,w) is an (s,q)-graph if for every X∈V s we have ∑_xy∈X 2w(xy)≤ q.  An (n,s,q)-graph is an (s,q)-graph with n vertices, and F(n,s,q) is the set of (n,s,q)-graphs with vertex set [n]:={1,…, n}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a multigraph G=(V,w), define 

    S(G)=∑_xy∈V 2 w(xy)     and      P(G)=∏_xy∈V 2w(xy),


    (n,s,q) = max{S(G): G∈ F(n,s,q)}   and   (n,s,q)=max{P(G): G∈ F(n,s,q)}.

An (n,s,q)-graph G is sum-extremal ( product-extremal ) if S(G)=(n,s,q) (P(G)=(n,s,q)). Let (n,s,q) ((n,s,q)) be the set of all sum-extremal (product-extremal) (n,s,q)-graphs with vertex set [n].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given integers s≥ 2 and q≥s 2, define the asymptotic product density and the asymptotic sum density , respectively, as the following limits (which both exist): 

    (s,q)=lim_n→∞((n,s,q))^1/n 2     and     (s,q)=lim_n→∞(n,s,q)/n 2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Sjöstrand]
If D is a distribution of pebbles on the graph G such that D(v)
≥ 1 for every vertex v in V(G), then π(G, D) is the smallest
number n with the property that if n pebbles are placed on a
single vertex, then D is reachable, regardless of which
vertex contained the initial pebbles.  Thus, we only have to look at
starting distributions in which all pebbles are on the same vertex.
In particular, this allows us to compute γ(G) easily.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
In  with a minimal syntax, the classes of all formulas (F), affirmative formulas (A), negative formulas (N), direct formulas (M) and cross formulas (X) are given by the following productions:

    [                F::=A |  N,; A::=F F  |  N→ F  |  F→ A,;             N::=  |  A→ N,;                  M::= A N,;                   X::= M→. ]

In words, any  formula is either affirmative or negative. Each negative formula is either , or is of the form A→ N', where A is an affirmative formula and N' is a smaller negative formula; and so on.

sentence: We say that an  formula is -like if it is locally -like, or negative, or direct, or of the form (G'→), where G' is a smaller -like formula. We denote -like formulas by the letter G.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a matrix, a critical set is 
a collection of rows whose sum is all-even 
(i.e., the sum is the 0 vector in ).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A square path ending east of size n is a lattice paths going from (0,0) to (n,n) consisting of east or north unit steps, always ending with an east step. The set of such paths is denoted by (n). We call base diagonal of a square path the diagonal y=x+l with the smallest value of l that is touched by the path (so that l≤ 0). The shift of the square path is the non-negative value -l. We refer to the line x=y as the main diagonal . A Dyck path is a square path whose shift is 0, i.e. its base diagonal is the main diagonal. The set of Dyck paths is denoted by (n). Of course (n)⊆(n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: square path ending east;base diagonal;shift;main diagonal;Dyck path

sentence:
A labelling or word of a square path π of size m+n ending east  is an element w∈ℕ^m+n such that when we label the i-th vertical step of π with w_i
	
		
  * the labels appearing in each column of π are strictly increasing from bottom to top;
		
  * there is at least one nonzero label labelling a vertical step starting from the base diagonal of π;
		
  * if π starts with a vertical step, then this first step has a nonzero label.
		
	
	The set of such labellings with m labels equal to 0 is denoted by (π, m), and we set (π)(π,0). 
	
	A partially labelled square path ending east is an element P=(π, w) of 
	
    (m,n){(π, w) |π∈(m+n), w ∈(π,m) }.

	We also define the subset of labelled Dyck paths as
	
    (m,n){(π,w)∈(m,n) |π∈(m+n)}⊆(m,n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O
plain_text_term: labelling;word;partially labelled square path ending east;labelled Dyck paths

sentence: Let π be a square path ending east of size m+n. We define its area word to be the sequence of integers a(π) = (a_1(π),a_2(π), ⋯, a_m+n(π)) such that the i-th vertical step of the path starts from the diagonal y=x+a_i(π). For example the path in Figure <ref> has area word (0,   -3,   -3,   -2,   -2,   -1,   0,   0).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We define for each P∈(m,n) a monomial in the variables x_1,x_2,…: we set 
    x^P ∏_i=1^m+n x_l_i(P)
 where l_i(P) is the label of the i-th vertical step of P (the first being at the bottom), and where we conventionally set x_0 = 1. The fact that x_0 does not appear in the monomial explains the word partially .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The rises of a square path ending east π are the indices 
    r(π) {2≤ i ≤ m+n| a_i(π)>a_i-1(π)},
 or the vertical steps that are directly preceded by another vertical step. 
	
	A decorated square path (respectively Dyck path) is a pair P=(π, dr) where π is a square path (respectively Dyck path) and dr⊆ r(π). We set 
	
    (n)^∗ k{(π, dr)|π∈(n), dr⊆ r(π), | dr|= k }
       (n)^∗ k{(π,dr)∈(n)^∗ k|π∈(n) }

	A partially labelled decorated square path (respectively Dyck path) is a triple (π, dr, w) where π is a square path (respectively Dyck path), dr⊆ r(π) and w is a labelling of π. We set 
	
    (m,n)^∗ k{(π, dr, w)| (π,w)∈(m,n), dr⊆ r(π), | dr|= k }
       (m,n)^∗ k{(π,dr,w)∈(m,n)^∗ k|π∈(m+n) }⊆(m,n)^∗ k.
 We will also use the following natural identifications
	
    (n,m)^∗ 0= (n,m)       (m,n)^∗ 0= (m,n)
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: rises;decorated square path;partially labelled decorated square path

sentence: Given a partially labelled square path, we call zero valleys its vertical steps with label 0 (which are necessarily preceded by a horizontal step, hence the name valleys).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a partially labelled square path P of shift s, we define its reading word σ(P) as the sequence of nonzero labels, read starting from the base diagonal y=x-s going bottom left to top right, then moving to the next diagonal, y=x-s+1 again going bottom left to top right, and so on.
	
	If the reading word of P is r_1… r_n then the  reverse reading word of P is r_n… r_1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
Let P=(π, dr, w) ∈(m,n)^∗ k. For 1 ≤ i < j ≤ m+n, we say that the pair (i,j) is an inversion if
	
		
  * either a_i(π) = a_j(π) and w_i < w_j ( primary inversion ),
		
  * or a_i(π) = a_j(π) + 1 and w_i > w_j ( secondary inversion ),
	
	where w_i denotes the i-th letter of w, i.e. the label of the vertical step in the i-th row.
	
	Then we define 
	
    (P)    #{ 0≤ i < j ≤ m+n | (i,j)  is an inversion}
          + #{0≤ i≤ m+n | a_i(π)<0 and  w_i ≠ 0 }.
 
	This second term is referred to as bonus dinv .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Given P∈(m,n)^∗ k we define its diagonal composition (P) to be the composition of n-k whose i-th part is the number of rows of P without a 0 label or a decoration ∗ that lie between the i-th and the (i+1)-th vertical step of P on the base diagonal not labelled by a 0 (or from the i-th step onwards if it is the last such step). See Figure <ref> for an example. If P∈ D(n)^∗ k, its diagonal composition is defined identically, without the conditions concerning the labels (since there are none).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given P∈(m,n)^∗ k we define a touching point of P to be a starting point of a vertical step of P that lies on the base diagonal, and whose label is not zero. The touching number (P) of P is defined as the number of touching points of P or equivalently as the length of its diagonal composition. See Figure <ref> for an example. For P∈(n)^∗ these definitions are the same, without the condition concerning the labels (since there are none).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let π∈(n). We define its bounce path as a lattice path from (0,0) to (n,n) computed in the following way: it starts in (0,0) and travels north until it encounters the beginning of an east step of π, then it turns east until it hits the main diagonal, then it turns north again, and so on; thus it continues until it reaches (n,n). 
	
	We label the vertical steps of the bounce path starting from 0 and increasing the labels by 1 every time the path hits the main diagonal (so the steps in the first vertical segment of the path are labelled with 0, the ones in the next vertical segment are labelled with 1, and so on). We define the bounce word of π to be the string b(π) = b_1(π) ⋯ b_n(π) where b_i(π) is the label attached to the i-th vertical step of the bounce path.
	
	We define the statistic bounce on (n) and (n) as 
    (π) ∑_i=1^n b_i(π).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A corner (or valley ) of a Dyck path π is one of the indices 
    c(π) {2≤ i ≤ n| a_i(π)≤ a_i-1(π)}.
 Corners will often be identified with the vertical steps of π that are directly preceded by a horizontal step.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The set of pairs (π, dc)  with  π∈(n), dc⊆ c(π) and | dc | = k will be denoted '(n)^∙ k. The indices in dc will be referred to as decorated corners: we decorate the i-th vertical step of π with a ∙ for all i∈ dc.
	
	The set of triples (π, dc, w') with (π,dc)∈'(n)^∙ k and w'∈'(π) will be denoted by 𝖫𝖣' (n)^∙ k.  In this set, we represent w' inside the squares containing the main diagonal x=y, starting from the bottom. See Figure <ref> on the right for an example.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Consider (π,dc,w')∈'(n)^∙ k. An inversion of (π,w') is a pair (i,j) with i<j and w'_i<w'_j such that the square whose upper right corner is the intersection of the lines x=i and y=j (i.e. the square lying in the same column as the label w'_i and the same row as w'_j) lies under the path π. We set (π, w')=(π, dc, w') to be the total number of inversions of (π, w') (the  statistic is also called ' in the literature).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For π∈(n), we define the zero-weight characteristic function of π as 
    χ(π) ∑_w ∈'(π) q^(π, w) x^w.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An augmented Dyck path is a labelled Dyck path with labels in ℕ∪{∞}, such that all the labels ∞ lie on the main diagonal and they are the only labels in their own columns. See Figure <ref> for two examples.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A partial preference function is a  partially labelled square path in (m,n)^∗ 0 whose nonzero labels are exactly the numbers 1,2,…, n. The subset of these paths is denoted by (m,n).
	
	A partial parking function is a partial preference function whose shift is 0. The set of such paths is denoted by (m,n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For every S⊆{1,2,…,n-1}, let Q_S,n denote the Gessel fundamental quasisymmetric function of degree n indexed by S , i.e.
	
    Q_S,n∑_i_1≤ i_2≤⋯≤ i_n_i_j<i_j+1 if j∈ Sx_i_1 x_i_2⋯   x_i_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The descent set of a given permutation τ is the set of indices i such that τ_i>τ_i+1, denoted by 𝖣𝖾𝗌(τ). We define the inverse descent set  of a permutation τ as 
    (τ)𝖣𝖾𝗌(τ^-1).

	
	Take P∈(m,n). We set r(P) to be the reverse reading word of P (see Definition <ref>). The inverse descent set of a preference function P is defined by 
    (P)(r(P))
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O
plain_text_term: descent set;inverse descent set  of a permutation;inverse descent set of a preference function

sentence:
Take P∈(m,n) with shift s and set lmax{a_i(P) | 1≤ i ≤ m+n }. 
	For i=l,l-1,…, -s define ρ_i to be the labels of P contained in the diagonal y=x+i, in increasing order. Define the diagonal word of P as
	
    (P)ρ_lρ_l-1⋯ρ_0 ρ_-1⋯ρ_-s.
 It is clear from the definition of a preference function that the ρ_i are the maximal substrings of consecutive weakly increasing numbers of (P): we will call them runs of (P). We set |ρ_i| to be the number of elements in ρ_i. A run ρ_i will be referred to as positive, zero or negative , referring to the sign of its index i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weak AMD code] 


Suppose (, , , E) is an AMD code.


  * The value Δ∈∖{0} is chosen according to the adversary's strategy.


  * The source s ∈ is chosen uniformly at random by the encoder
(i.e., we have equiprobable sources).

  * The source is encoded into g ∈ A(s) using the encoding function E.

  * The adversary  wins if and only if g + Δ∈ A(s') for some s' ≠ s.

The success probability of the strategy σ, denoted 
ϵ_σ, is the probability that the adversary wins this game using the
specific strategy σ.

We will say that the code (, , , E) is a weak (m,n,)-AMD code where
 denotes the success probability of the adversary's optimal 
strategy.
That is, 

    = max _σ{ϵ_σ} .

sentence:
[Strong AMD code] 


  * The source s ∈ is given to the adversary  
(here there is no probability distribution defined on ).

  * The value Δ∈∖{0} is chosen according to the adversary's strategy.

  * The source is encoded into g ∈ A(s) using the encoding function E.

  * The adversary  wins if and only if g + Δ∈ A(s') for some s' ≠ s.

For a given source s the success probability of the strategy σ, denoted 
ϵ_σ,s, is the probability that the adversary wins this game using the
specific strategy σ.

We will say that the code (, , , E) is a strong (m,n,)-AMD code where
 denotes the maximum success probability of any strategy over all sources s.
That is,

    = max _σ,s{ϵ_σ,s} .

sentence:
[External difference family]
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,k,λ)-external difference family (or (n,m,k,λ)-EDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following multiset equation holds:

    ⋃ _{ i,j : i ≠ j}^(A_i,A_j)  = λ (∖{0}).

sentence:
[Bounded external difference family]
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
A (n,m,k,λ)-bounded external difference family 
(or (n,m,k,λ)-BEDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following condition holds for every g ∈∖{0}:

    |{ x-y: x-y = g, x ∈ A_i, y ∈ A_j,  i ≠ j}|  ≤λ .

sentence:

Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,k;λ)-strong external difference family

is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that

(or (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-GSEDF)

Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-bounded generalized strong external difference family

sentence:
[Real case]
Let F∈[x,y,z] be a polynomial of degree d
that is irreducible over , such that Z_(F) has dimension 2.
Then property (ii) in both Theorems <ref> and <ref> can be replaced by:

(ii)_ 
There is a one-dimensional subvariety Z_0⊂ Z_(F)

such that for all v∈ Z_(F) Z_0,
there are open intervals I_1,I_2,I_3⊂ and one-to-one real-analytic functions[
  A real function f:I→ on an interval I is real-analytic if it has a power series expansion at each point of I.]
φ_i: I_i→ with real-analytic inverses, 
for i=1,2,3,
such that v∈ I_1× I_2× I_3 and for all (x,y,z)∈ I_1× I_2× I_3,

    (x,y,z)∈ Z(F)   if and only if   φ_1(x)+φ_2(y)+φ_3(z) = 0.

sentence:
Let Π be a finite set of distinct points in ^2, 
and let Γ be a finite multiset of curves in ^2.
We say that the system (Π,Γ) has (λ,μ)-bounded multiplicity 
if [In both (a) and (b) the curves should be counted with their multiplicity.]
 
(a) for any curve γ∈Γ,
there are at most λ curves γ'∈Γ such that 
there are more than μ points contained in both γ and γ'; and

(b) for any point p∈Π, 
there are at most λ points p'∈Π such that there are more than μ curves that contain both p and p'.

sentence:
Let Π be a finite set of distinct points in ^2, 
and let Γ be a finite multiset of curves in ^2.
We say that the system (Π,Γ) has (λ,μ)-bounded multiplicity 
if
 
(a) for any curve γ∈Γ,
there are at most λ curves γ'∈Γ such that 
there are more than μ points contained in both γ and γ'; and

(b) for any point p∈Π, 
there are at most λ points p'∈Π such that there are more than μ curves that contain both p and p'.

(In both (a) and (b) the curves should be counted with  multiplicity.)

The anti-uniform space of level 
d is defined to be the dual space of 
L^2^d-1(μ) endowed with the norm U(d).

given by  duality is called the anti-uniform norm of level 
d and is denoted by ·_U(d)^*.

sentence:
Let f,g ∈ R. We define the k-jet J_k   f as the image of f in R/𝔪^k.
We say that f is right equivalent to g, denoted f ∼ g, if there exists an automorphism φ of R such that φ(f) =g. We say that f is
 right k-determined if  f ∼ h for each h ∈ R with J_k   f = J_k   h.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A simple game is a monotone Boolean function, i.e., a mapping χ 2^N→{0,1} with χ(S)≤χ(T)
  for all S⊆ T, which additionally satisfies χ(∅)=0, χ(N)=1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A simple game χ is called complete (also called directed ) if the binary relation ⊐ is a total
  preoder, i.e.,
  
   
  (1) i⊐ i for all i∈ N,
   
  (2) i ⊐ j or j ⊐ i (including “i ⊐ j and j ⊐ i”) for all i,j∈ N, and
   
  (3) i ⊐ j, j ⊐ h implies i ⊐ h for all i,j,h∈ N.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A simple game χ is weighted if there exist non-negative weights w_i∈ℝ_≥ 0 and a positive quota
   q∈ℝ_>0 such that χ(S)=1 if and only if ∑_i∈ S w_i≥ q.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a given n-player simple game χ the absolute Penrose-Banzhaf index B'_i(χ) for player i is defined as

    B'_i(χ)=1/2^n-1·∑_∅⊆ S⊆ N\{i}χ(S∪{i})-χ(S).

The (normalized) Penrose-Banzhaf index (PBI) B_i(χ) for player i is defined as

    B_i(χ)=B'_i(χ)/∑_j=1^nB'_j(χ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(<cit.>)
A structure ⟨ A, τ⟩ is arithmetic if there is a bijection #: A →N such that Def(A,τ) ⊆Def(A, +_#,×_#).


An arithmetic structure ⟨ A, τ⟩ has the maximal definability property if Def(A, τ) = Def(A, +_#, ×_#)

sentence:
[Strongly quadrangular matrix]We say that an m× n {0,1}-matrix
X=[X_i,j] is row strongly quadrangular ( RSQ ) if there does
not exist R⊆{1,2,...,m} with | R|≥2 such
that, defining R^'={k:X_i,kX_j,k=1 for some i≠ j in R},
we have | R^'| <| R| and
X_R^R^' has no zero-rows. We say that an m× n
{0,1}-matrix X is strongly quadrangular ( SQ ) if both X
and X^T are RSQ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The sowing of a mancala configuration λ
is an operation on λ that results in a new configuration μ
= (λ) defined as follows:


    μ_i = 
    λ_i+1 + 1        if 1 ≤ i ≤λ_1,
    
    λ_i+1       if i > λ_1 .



Conventionally,  maps the empty configuration into itself.

gap as an absent seed , and in this respect we can follow
